PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Sex Discrimination Legislation
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to
undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms.
entrench abortion funding and render liable to action hospitals, doctors and nurses who consciously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations.
deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment conducive to the development, including the moral development of their children.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:

should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of the principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Harradine (from 240 citizens), Tate (from 470 citizens), Townley ( from 112 citizens) and Walters (from 161 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:

Although many occurrences of sexual harrassment in the workforce have been reported to various State government authorities, such as the Victorian Commission for Equal Opportunity, the real incidence of sexual intimidation in employment will not be known, or countered, until a national policy towards sexual harrassment is determined and implemented.
We therefore submit that:

1. The National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation be commissioned to conduct a nation-wide study of discrimination based on sex, both in the private sector and the Public Service, with a view to advising the Government on the development of national policy.
2. The major priority of such study should be to determine a legally- enforceable definition of sexual harrassment.

3. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations should bring forward in Parliament legislation, arising from such a study, to outlaw discrimination and intimidation in employment based on sex.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, concerned with the cut in funding to the Brisbane Airport, concerned that this cut means loss of jobs, concerned that this cut could seriously affect the economy of Queensland.
Humbly petition the Senate to request the Australian Government to:
1. Reverse its decision to cut funding to the Brisbane Airport.
2. Abide by the guarantee given by the Minister for Housing and Construction that the Airport would receive priority funding.
3. Assure the citizens of Queensland that the Brisbane Airport as the domestic and economic gateway to this State will be fully completed by 1987.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Grape Spirit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the 1983 Budget imposition of the excise on grape spirit used in fortifying wine places at risk the future of the fortified wine industry in Australia.
That the requirement to pay the excise within 7 days of the fortification occurring is inequitable.
That the excise will be reflected in increased costs to the consumers of fortified wines of up to 100 per cent and consumer choice will be restricted.
That this will cause reduced fortified wine sales which will result in reduced intake of grapes from grapegrowers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will reconsider their previous decision and either withdraw this tax or modify its method of application and collection.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Means Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of Australia in Parliament assembled. This petition of members of the New South Wales Retired Teachers Association concerned with the assets/means/income test of pensioners respectfully showeth that:

We call on the Government to dispense with the asset/ means/income test for aged persons bringing Australia into line with other western countries and thus saving the fears and confusion of our pensioners and avoiding the many areas of evasion at present practised. The aged have paid for these pensions in taxes over the years and the government will benefit from extra taxation from the pensions given.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the honourable Minister: Government dispense with the assets/means/income test for pensioners.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES LEGISLATION (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend laws relating to companies and securities.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I am introducing today a Bill pursuant to the Commonwealth's obligations under the co-operative companies and securities scheme. I would like to outline, for the benefit of honourable senators, the administrative and legislative context in which the Bill has been prepared, and some of the principal amendments proposed. A detailed description of the provisions of the Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated to honourable senators for information.
CO-OPERATIVE COMPANIES AND SECURITIES SCHEME

The formal agreement executed by the Commonwealth and all the States on 22 December 1978 provides the framework for a co-operative Commonwealth-State scheme for a uniform system of law and administration regulating the companies and securities industry. The scheme covers the relevant law operating in the six States and the Australian Capital Territory. In accordance with the formal agreement, this legislation has been agreed to by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. If passed by this Parliament, it will have the effect of automatically amending the corresponding State legislation.

As indicated in our business regulation policy, the Government considers that the co-operative scheme should be retained while it demonstrates progress in the achievement of its aims. However, in the longer term we would prefer to move to a national system of companies and securities regulation administered by the national Parliament. Neither system can be effective if it does not extend to the whole of Australia, including the Northern Territory. I am currently corresponding with the Northern Territory Government seeking its entry to the scheme.
LAW REFORM PROGRAM

It is the view of the Government that reform of companies and securities law is a high priority. The need for reform of the law is recognised by all governments in Australia, by the commercial community and the investing public. These reforms will take place on a number of fronts. First, there are Bills such as the one that I am introducing today. This is the first significant reforming Bill in the companies and securities area for quite some time. Up to now, changes made in the co-operative companies and securities legislation have generally been more of a fine tuning than a law reform nature. Work is already proceeding on the next in the series of Bills of this nature and I would anticipate that an exposure draft would be released for public comment in 1984.

In addition to work of this nature, I am confident that there will be a quantum leap forward in this field with the establishment of the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee and the Accounting Standards Review Board. As promised in the business regulation policy statement, the Commonwealth Government has been active in ensuring the establishment of these bodies. The Ministerial Council has decided that the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee will be in operation as from the start of next year. This Committee will be charged with the function of undertaking root and branch reform of the law. Establishment of the Committee will enable examination of fundamental issues of company law in a systematic fashion rather than on the basis of ad hoc amendments to meet individual difficulties emerging from the administration of the scheme legislation. References to the Committee will be determined by the Ministerial Council following consultation with members of the Committee.

This Bill lays the groundwork for the establishment of the Accounting Standards Review Board which will start operations on 1 January 1984. The Accounting Standards Review Board will consider existing and proposed accounting standards prepared by the joint accounting bodies through the Australian Accounting Research Foundation and legislative backing will be given to those standards. This, I anticipate, will improve the quality of financial reporting and will result in more meaningful information being given to investors, creditors, and employees.

Although this Bill contains some significant amendments affecting corporate insolvencies, and in particular receiverships, it does not reflect a fundamental overhaul of the provisions relating to winding up. Accordingly, I am now considering giving the Australian Law Reform Commission a general reference on insolvency. The reference would need to contain clear directions to the Law Reform Commission to collaborate closely with the various bodies concerned with companies and securities law and administration. I am having discussions with the State members of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities on this question and hope to be in a position to announce further details in the not too distant future.
PUBLIC CONSULTATION ON BILL

I should emphasise that the Bill takes account of the many contributions that have been made in public submissions over the years. Some of the proposals in the Bill such as those relating to the objects and powers of companies can be traced to the calls made by the commercial community in submissions on the Companies Bill 1980 to further limit the scope of the doctrine of ultra vires as it affects the impact of actions by company officers on third parties.

Other aspects of the Bill, such as those concerning the statements and reports to be prepared by company directors, reflect the comments made on the exposure draft of the Bill that was released for public comment in December 1982. The exposure draft was given considerable attention by the commercial community with over 100 submissions being received. In most instances these submissions have been prepared by busy professionals in their spare time and I am grateful for their constructive contributions.
CONTENT OF BILL

An outline of the principal features of the Bill and in particular the main changes it makes to existing companies and securities legislation is set out at paragraphs 23 and 24 of the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated. I will briefly mention some of the more important amendments.
OBJECTS AND POWERS OFCOMPANIES

The Bill in clause 34 contains provisions which replace sections 67 and 68 of the Companies Act with new provisions designed to ensure that, unless it determines otherwise in its constituent documents, a company has the powers of a natural person. The related question of whether or not companies should be required to have specified objects was tackled in the exposure draft of the Bill by the preparation of alternative provisions, one set requiring companies to have objects and the other containing no such requirements. The overwhelming majority of commentators favoured companies not being required to have specified objects and this view is reflected in the Bill.
REMEDIES FOR SHAREHOLDERS IN CASES OF OPPRESSION

Significant amendments are made in clause 89 of the Bill to the remedies available to aggrieved shareholders where they believe that the affairs of a company are being conducted in an oppressive manner. The categories of conduct which would give rise to a remedy will be broadened so as to overcome a number of restrictive interpretations which the courts have placed on the precursors to the present provision, section 320 of the Companies Act.
DIRECTORS' STATEMENTS REPORTS

There are amendments to section 269 of the Companies Act concerning preparation of the directors statement accompanying the accounts which will improve the usefulness of the informations now provided by directors. Directors will now be required by clause 80 of the Bill to advise persons reading the accounts of relevant circumstances that have arisen and information that has become available since the end of the financial year to which the accounts relate.

The Bill takes account of concerns that were expressed in response to these provisions as they appeared in the exposure draft by enabling this update on the accounts to be completed up to eight weeks before an annual general meeting rather than within the period of six weeks prior to the meeting. Similarly, the provisions modifying the content of the directors reports as required by section 270 of the Companies Act have undergone significant changes in the light of public comments on the exposure draft.

Directors will now be required by clause 81 of the Bill to furnish in their reports a review of the operations of the company and of the expected results of those operations; to note any significant changes in the state of affairs of the company; and to refer to any likely developments in the operations of the company in future years. These new requirements will produce more informative reports but, at the same time, companies will not be required to disclose information which would, in the opinion of the directors, be prejudicial to the interests of the company.
TRACING BENEFICIAL INTERESTS IN SHARES

The Bill also extends the operation of the provisions currently contained in section 261 of the Companies Act which enable tracing of beneficial interests in shareholdings. Relatively minor amendments were proposed in the exposure draft released in December 1982. Following calls from directors and shareholders for more extensive amendments to enable inquiries to be initiated as to the beneficial ownership of shareholdings, new proposals were released for comment in April 1983. These provisions contained in clause 76 of the Bill will put directors and shareholders in a better position to ascertain the identity of the persons whose voting power may affect a company's operations.
PURPOSIVE INTERPRETATION

Clause 132 of the Bill inserts a new provision in the Companies and Securities (Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions) Act that will require the courts, when interpreting co-operative scheme legislation, to have regard to the purpose or object of the relevant legislation. The provision is similar to that contained in section 15AA of the Acts Interpretation Act. It is hoped that this provision will ensure that a less legalistic approach to interpretation is taken by the courts and that greater regard is had to the objectives of the co- operative scheme, as spelt out in the formal agreement as well as in the constituent legislative codes.
OTHER AMENDMENTS
Other clauses in the Bill designed to improve the operation of the co-operative scheme legislation are:

(a) clause 17, which amends section 60 of the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act to enable the National Companies and Securities Commission to make a declaration of unacceptable conduct under the takeover code even though a Part A statement has not been served or a takeover announcement made;

(b) clause 31, which inserts proposed sections 30A to 30S of the Companies Act so as to make adequate provision for the conduct of hearings by the Companies Auditors and Liquidators Disciplinary Board;
(c) clause 68, which is designed to give greater flexibility to the administration of the prospectus and prescribed interests provisions;
(d) clause 74, which rationalises the requirements of section 241 of the Companies Act for convening meetings upon requisition of members; and
(e) clause 93, which inserts proposed sections 324A to 324F of the Companies Act so as to clarify the powers and duties of receivers.
Some of these provisions were not included in the exposure draft, but are considered sufficiently important to warrant legislation action at this stage.
LODGMENT OF ACCOUNTS BY EXEMPT PROPRIETARY COMPANIES

Many people will no doubt be relieved to see that the Bill does not contain any provisions requiring exempt proprietary companies to lodge accounts with the National Companies and Securities Commission. During the public exposure period, comments were sought on a proposal made jointly by the Australian Society of Accountants and the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia that exempt proprietary companies should be required to lodge accounts with the NCSC whether or not those accounts were audited.

The Ministerial Council has decided that, in the light of public criticism of this proposal and of the work being done by the NCSC on Schedule 7 of the Companies Regulations and the financial reporting requirements of the Companies Act, no such amendment should be made at this stage. It was considered more appropriate for the issues raised by the joint accounting bodies to be considered in the context of a general examination of the use of the corporate form to be undertaken by the proposed Companies and Securities Law Review Committee.
FINANCIAL IMPACT STATEMENT

Finally, I should make some references to the financial impact that this Bill will have on government revenues. As mentioned previously, this Bill puts in place machinery to enable accounting standards approved by the proposed Accounting Standards Review Board to have the force of law.

The Board will commence operations from the start of 1984. The Ministerial Council has authorised interim arrangements on a restricted funding basis for the Board's operations for the period 1 January to 30 June using NCSC staff and facilities to service the Board. The estimated cost of these arrangements is $35 ,000. In the first full year of the Board's operations with its own staff and premises, the cost of the Board's operations is expected to be $235,000 and $195 ,000 in subsequent years, of which 50 per cent is to be funded by the Commonwealth and the other 50 per cent by the States on a pro rata basis.

Although this Bill does not contain provisions relating to the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee that I mentioned earlier, the expected cost to the Commonwealth of its 50 per cent contribution would be $70,000 in the current financial year, based on a 1 January 1984 commencement, and $140,000 in a full year.
The Government commends the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill to the Senate.

Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) proposed:
That the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly to this motion. I make my comments really by way of a question to the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans). The Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill is a very detailed Bill, as he will acknowledge. It has been the subject of an exposure draft and a great deal of public consultation, which he referred to in his second reading speech. I should like him to indicate, firstly, whether he intends to make available to the Senate any precis or details of the submissions that have been received, particularly the ones that have not been acceded to by the Government, for the purpose of having a more intelligent debate on the second reading and, secondly, what his timetable will be in relation to the consideration of these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-As to the first point, I think perhaps the best way of proceeding would be to undertake, as I now do, to make available departmental officers, including in particular Mr Kennedy and Mr Starr, to give such briefing to honourable senators as they would require as to the content of the Companies and Securities Legislation ( Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, and in particular as to the content and Government response to any submissions that are received on the exposure draft. Such is the mass of paper that exists in relation to this measure, since it has been exposed for a large number of months, as the shadow Attorney-General would be well aware, that that is probably a more sensible course of action than to try to think in terms of tabling a bundle of material. Certainly on a measure of this kind there is no question but that full briefing will be available. Indeed, I understand some such briefing has already been set in train this morning. As to the timing of the debate, I note that, as is the practice with Bills such as this, the Bill was made available to the Opposition and the Australian Democrats , and I think Senator Harradine as well, some days ago, although not a terribly long time ago.
—We have not been free to discuss it.

—I appreciate that. Under those circumstances, I am sure we would react sympathetically to any request to hold over the debate on this for longer than the ordinary period of a week between introduction and debate. I cannot make any such final undertaking now because it does depend on the overall shape of the Government's legislative program. There are a number of matters which seem to be the subject of request for deferral. But certainly we will do our best to accommodate the very reasonable request that has been made by Senator Durack.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 September 1983, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Senate take note of the papers and the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to discuss the Budget as far as it effects the Australian Capital Territory because the Budget in Canberra is much more than just a Federal Budget. It is at the same time our State budget and our municipal budget. So we need to examine it from all points of view. Of course, the underlying and important theme of the whole document is the extent to which it assists in providing more jobs in this community, and I will address myself to that as I go through the Budget Papers. One of the difficulties we are faced with is the statement of the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) made in the papers he released that ' Canberra has done well in a tight Budget framed in difficult economic circumstances'. This led to the Canberra Times headline 'Canberra does well in the Budget: Uren'. This is the sort of statement that is totally harmful to our position.

SPEECH.PARA: Many people in Australia seem to regard Canberra as a pampered community which does not pay rates and does not pay its way. However, one will find when the Commonwealth Grants Commission presents its report that this is not correct. A document recently produced by the Parliamentary Library on the geography of electorates shows a number of relevant facts as far as Canberra is concerned. For the Minister to put out a statement which allowed Canberra to be presented in this way is really rather irresponsible because the figures do not in fact reflect an allocation for the Australian Capital Territory up by 19 per cent as he said in the way in which he presented it. Let us just have a closer look at the figures that relate to the Australian Capital Territory. The Department of Territories and Local Government was allocated an $8.6m or 6.2 per cent increase on last year's figure. We all remember the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) which indicated that the inflation rate for the last 12 months was 11.5 per cent. So there is no way that we can turn a 6.2 per cent increase into an 11 .5 per cent increase and certainly not a 19 per cent increase. The allocation in those areas administered by the Department of Territories and Local Government- the Minister's own Department-is considerably down on what it was last year.

The Budget of the National Capital Development Commission has been increased by $13.5m or 11.96 per cent, which is just short of the inflation rate but is substantially the same amount of money as last year. The increase that is relevant is that portion relating to the new Parliament House-a 58 per cent or $ 34.7m increase. As was said in the Canberra Times article, $90.1m has been made available to maintain the progress of that building which is a national project, a national monument, to be finished by 1988. There is not one amongst us who would not want it to be finished on time and to have its financing maintained at the appropriate rate to do so. To lump that figure in with Australian Capital Territory finances is misleading indeed. Of course, in Canberra we welcome national projects for the jobs that they provide in our community, but we also want the financial set-up to be described in a way that is meaningful and the national projects and local expenditure clearly identified so that it is not made to look as though we are getting all the extra money.

To return to the Department of Territories and Local Government, there is a fall-off in services and a lowering of the maintenance cost of parks, gardens, recreation areas and reserves. There is a cutback, effectively, in the budget of the Tourist Bureau of the Australian Capital Territory. I will deal with that again. There is a cutback in the amount of money allocated for bushfire control. It is to be hoped that the bushfires which plagued this Territory last summer are not repeated this year. There is a cutback in the money for the operation of Lake Burley Griffin and for lighting and cleaning in non-municipal areas. In a number of areas there is a reduction in the amount of money allocated. Interestingly enough, at the same time there is an increase in motor vehicle registration fees and motor vehicle licence fees. All the people in this community know that they are paying higher rates this year. There is an increase in sewerage rates. It is very clear that in the Australian Capital Territory we are paying more for less. Two days after the presentation of the Budget it was announced that the rent for Government houses would be increased.

In presenting these Papers the Minister claimed that there would be 1,600 additional jobs as a result of this Budget. I invite him to spell out where these jobs will occur and from where the funds are to come. I see no evidence to support this claim. Certainly not from the figures presented can one see any area where that could be the result. Hopefully, the buildings and projects that have been referred to-the National Biological Standards Laboratory and others- will occur and will develop. The Canberra Association for Regional Development has asked that there be a plan for a five-year building and construction program in the Australian Capital Territory. That has not been agreed to and presented. I can understand government's difficulty with it, but it is to be hoped that the projects that have been mentioned will proceed and that the funds will be allocated for that purpose in future years.

Within the budget of the NCDC-I welcome this decision-500 government houses are to be constructed, 50 of which will be allocated to elderly people and will be suitable for them. There is to be an increase in land servicing, which is also necessary. Thirty million dollars of the Budget is for the purpose of servicing 2,500 blocks of land during the next 12 months. The Government's role is very significant as far as construction is concerned in the national capital, and always has been. I think it is necessary that government recognises the lead that it needs to show in this area. I hope that the withholding tax which was introduced will not greatly increase costs and will not cause disruption to the industry, as the industry certainly feels it will. There are a number of smaller projects in the NCDC's program, which I welcome, as they will fill community needs and finish off work which has been commenced in a number of areas. I will not go through them all now.

The Canberra Times referred to the Budget as 'not perfect'. In particular it referred to the fact that there was a complete mix-up as far as national and local activities were concerned. I ask the Minister to take note of these comments and to see that in future the Budget is presented in a more meaningful way. It is necessary that it be seen that Canberra residents are not, as the Canberra Times said, a pampered lot and have not been given an increase in funds that is equivalent to the inflation rate over the last 12 months. It was described by Senator Jack Evans on radio locally a couple of days after the Budget as a band-aid Budget. In some respects that is a description which applies also in Canberra.

From my point of view, the most significant area where the Budget falls down is in the area of tourism and the Government's recognition of the place of tourism in the Australian Capital Territory. The Budget really was quite definite about the place of tourism in Australia and the allocation to the Australian Tourist Commission went up 75 per cent. I certainly welcome that; I think it is money well spent. When we think of what other countries spend on tourism-Singapore, for example-it is necessary that we lift our game, so to speak, as far as promotion is concerned. But I seriously regret that the Minister for Territories and Local Government does not see it that way as far as Canberra is concerned. The amount for promotion of tourism is $500,000, the same as last year. It has not even kept up with the inflation rate. The Canberra Development Board in its annual report of the previous year referred to tourism and said that tourism offered the best opportunities to develop new jobs quickly.

It is necessary to diversify jobs in this community in order to give a wider range of choice for all young people and for it not to be just a Public Service town. I do not think anybody disagrees with the fact that it would be a more interesting and more lively community if we could diversify and offer opportunities in other areas. It was with great disappointment that I noted the Minister's attitude to tourism in Canberra by the amount he allocated in the Budget for tourism promotion. In addition, $30,000-the same as last year-is the contribution to the promotion by the Canberra Visitor and Convention Bureau, again on a dollar for dollar basis. But last year the Canberra Visitor and Convention Bureau spent $80,000, of which the Government contributed $30,000. The Bureau certainly put in a great deal more than a dollar for dollar. The local tourist industry is helping itself and doing what it can, and I think the Government's attitude is very disappointing indeed. We were entitled to expect more. Let us look at what was said during the election campaign. The Canberra Times on 18 February 1983 had an article entitled 'ALP Plans to Upgrade ACT Tourism'. It stated:

A Labor Government would upgrade the access roads to Canberra, begin immediate talks with the New South Wales Government to improve the rail link and make air travel more attractive, according to the Member for Canberra, Mrs Kelly.
Certainly, we have seen the XPT since then. The article continued:
She said she had talked to the ALP's spokesman on tourism, Mr Brown, and both had agreed that the ACT could have a much bigger tourist industry.
I wish they would talk to our local Minister and impress him in the same way. The article continued:
'The development of tourism in Canberra will be a high priority under a Labor Government', she said.

Air travel would be improved by abolishing the add-on airfare for overnight stays in Canberra, allowing more flexibility for off-peak travel and package deals, and by having Canberra airport upgraded quickly.
All we have seen so far as that matter is concerned is the $115,000 for a study of the Canberra airport. The article continued:

Mrs Kelly said the ALP was committed to a convention centre for Canberra, without the requirement for a casino. It supported the White Industry proposal which provides for a five-star hotel and convention centre.

Because tourism was labour intensive, it would be an excellent way to diversify Canberra's employment base, she said. Private-sector tourism development proposals for Canberra would be given a high priority by a Labor government.

How disappointing for those who believed this and felt that tourism would flourish under a Labor Government, because it clearly is not happening. The White Industries Ltd proposal, which had been approved prior to the election, has not moved forward in the slightest. I understand that for some reason it is back before Cabinet. It has been held up now for seven months. It will involve about 600 jobs in construction, which we need, and about 1,200 jobs will be available when the project is completed. In spite of promises we are still waiting for something to happen. We need the office space as Senator Gietzelt will tell you, Madam Acting Deputy President. Only recently, in this place, he explained the difficulties that his Department had in finding office space for the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service. That service has now found an office but Senator Gietzelt is aware of the need for this White Industries development to go ahead. The Budget states that 6,500 extra jobs are to be created in the Public Service. Of course, they would be spread throughout the country, but it would be expected that a number of them would be created here. The Department of Social Security would gain an extra 2,500 positions. If they are to be here at least let us get on with the construction program that will enable us to have office space in which to house them.

The other part of the Budget to which I wish to refer relates to the allocation for incentives. We fought hard to get incentives. They were recognised by the Liberal Government, for the first time, and an amount of $750,000 was included in the previous Budget for the Canberra Development Board to attract industry and business to the Australian Capital Territory. That Board has been very successful. Just over $100,000 of that amount was actually paid out in that financial year. But I do not think anybody would doubt that there is a considerable lead time from negotiating with a company to its actually being set up. But $750,000 was committed. This year, $750,000, the same amount, has been allocated for the incentives program. It has been allocated in such a way that the Board cannot commit it for the next year but must spend it this year. This means there is a significant decrease in the amount available and a decrease in the significance of the incentives program. Indeed, it is disappointing to find out the attitude of the Government to the Canberra Development Board. The executive director resigned some months ago and has not been replaced.

I feel rather disappointed that the Minister does not appreciate the need for an adequate amount to be made available, bearing in mind the competition from Victoria and New South Wales and bearing in mind the need for us to expand, diversify and attract industry and business to Canberra. If the money were not available I would prefer that some of the community employment program funds be diverted for this purpose. I think that would result in there being permanent jobs and real careers for young people, not just short term jobs that will be available under that scheme. As I said yesterday, I welcome the Minister's announcement that he had obtained $1.5m as a State supplement to add to our share of the community employment program funds. I urge him to consider how some of that money is to be spent. I believe it could be spent in the better interests of people obtaining long term employment and careers.

As I said before, I asked the Minister to take the question of jobs seriously and to consider the area of tourism and incentives for getting jobs into Canberra. The White Industries project must get underway. He must respond to the wage pause committee's report which had about 70 recommendations on how to increase shared employment, and permanent part time employment in Canberra especially in the Public Service. He must give consideration to incentives and preferences to small business in Canberra. It is all very well to say that national projects should be tendered nationally. Of course one could not argue with that happening with the building of battleships or aeroplanes. But given that New South Wales and Victoria give preference to small local businesses I do not see why that could not occur in the Australian Capital Territory. I ask the Government to reconsider its position on this matter.

One other wage pause committee recommendation was that there should be a payroll tax rebate for, say, two years to encourage people to employ. When it comes to jobs, let me again mention the Australian Federal Police computer centre. It was black banned on 6 August 1982 and finally cancelled on 26 August 1983. Quite apart from the issue of the upgrading of the efficiency of the police force, jobs in that project were just thrown away and apparently nobody was prepared to do anything about it.

The financial future of Canberrans is that they will be paying more and getting less, as I said earlier. They will be paying out all the national increases which have been aired. They will be paying the local increases to which I have referred. They lose their mortgage rebates, as do other Australians. They lose the right to claim a rebate on medical benefit fund contributions. They will be paying the Medicare levy. They certainly are threatened by the superannuation proposals because there are more people in superannuation schemes in the Australian Capital Territory than in any other electorate, and they are certainly worried about the implications of the assets test. Costs will go up in Canberra, and by this time next year, or considerably before then, Canberrans will have a great deal less disposable income than they have had previously. It was indeed very misleading of our Minister to suggest that Canberra does well in the Budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Budget Statement and Papers for 1983-84, the first Hawke Labor Budget. We have heard Senator Reid go through a nit-picking exercise in which she has glossed over a number of significant issues for the people of Canberra. For example, she dismissed lightly the fact that this Government will build 500 houses and organise 2,000 blocks of land in Canberra, with the consequent improvement in employment that that will create. She conveniently forgot that only yesterday we lifted the wages freeze, which has particularly affected people in Canberra because of the high number of public servants who were the victims of the Fraser Government. With its lack of real policies, it continually attacked public servants. Then Senator Reid presumed to endorse the suggestion that the Hawke Government's Budget is some sort of band-aid. The reality is that the Labor Government came into power when the economy in Australia had a gaping wound of a deficit that caused the Australian people to bleed economically and put this country in a very serious position.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian community knows how hollow these protestations from Senator Reid are. The seven years of Liberal Government was a disaster. When the Australian Labor Party came into office the economy was undergoing its worst recession in 50 years. Conveniently, Senator Reid did not refer to what the experience of the Fraser Government has done to the people of Canberra and the rest of Australia, with three-quarters of a million Australians out of work. When the Fraser Government was dismissed from office by the Australian people we had an inflation rate running at 11 1/2 per cent. The Fraser Government gave us economic growth in reverse. There was an actual decline of 2 per cent in 1982-83 . This is the Fraser-Howard inheritance that the Australian people have found the Labor Government struggling with. I should like to analyse some of the problems that we face and some of the things that have been said by leading members of the Opposition Liberal Party. For example, Senator Chaney asserts that this Budget 'fails utterly to make any real commitment to full employment'. Mr Peacock, the Leader of the Opposition, considers that our Government has no understanding of the real needs of the community. How impertinent of these former Ministers in the Fraser Government! How committed to full employment was the former Fraser Government? How understanding was it of the real needs of the Australian community? I refer to the indictment of the former Liberal Government made this weekend at the council of the national organisation of the Liberal Party. In the report of the Liberal Party Committee of Review, known as the Valder report, it was stated of the Fraser Government:

. . . our performance in Government simply did not match our rhetoric. We did not practise what we preached. Too often we were seen to be inconsistent, too pragmatic and, finally, too expedient. Bit by bit our credibility was eroded.

The Fraser Government left a legacy of three-quarters of a million people unemployed. In its last 12 months of Government it allowed unemployment to increase by 270,000 people. The Australian people have condemned the Fraser Government.
The way that the Australian Press has reacted in commenting on the confessions of the Liberal Party and the former Government is interesting. The editorial in the Australian on 3 October 1983 noted:
. . . during the Fraser years it became very difficult to define what the Party believed in. It was not so much straying from the platform, but the seeming non- existence of any platform at all.
On the other key issue to which I have referred-a wages policy-Michelle Grattan from the Melbourne Age, in commenting about the weekend council of the Liberal Party observed:
The coalition will have to continue to operate without a wages policy. Indeed, this is how it is in many other areas.

So the Australian Press endorses the confessions of the Liberal Party. I mention these matters only because the Liberal Party has not learnt. This is evidenced by the audacity of the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, at the weekend conference in saying:
It is the Liberal approach which will ensure that the weak are safe and the strong are just.

At the beginning of this year, according to the Australian Council of Social Service, three million Australians were living below the poverty line and tax avoidance, which I will refer to later, became a growth industry under the Fraser Government. How dare the Liberal Party say that the strong will be just when we know that the Fraser Government allowed tax avoiders to pay whatever they wanted, and avoidance was such a shocking development under the Fraser Government. With more people joining the dole queues and more people not having enough money to eke out a minimum subsistence the Fraser Government callously and cold-heartedly cut spending in real terms on social security by $2 1/2 billion.

Those lucky enough to have jobs were not much better off. The Fraser Government redistributed income in such a manner that the burden of taxation borne by the lower and middle income wage and salary earners, that is pay as you earn taxpayers, climbed from 41.7 per cent of total tax collections in 1975-76 to 45 per cent in 1981-82. Mr Valder in his report argued for tax relief. But the Australian people know that the experience for the vast majority of Australian wage and salary earners was that they paid more while others paid less.

While increasing tax for wage and salary earners, the Fraser Government consistently and savagely cut the social wage. The social wage which I refer to is the provision of health, housing, recreation, transport, communication, education and social security. It is true that now it is defeated, the Liberal Party is talking about a needs basis for these issues. But the truth is that in practice it whittled away the social wage that is a component of everybody's standard of living. It is significant that the Australian Financial Review, in an editorial on 3 October, said of the Valder report:
It shows that the Liberals are aware of how directionless they have seemed for quite some time and that they are aware of how vapid Liberal 'philosophy' has become.

So, combining the increased tax grab and the reductions in the benefits of the social wage, a total wage of $47 billion was ripped off Australian wage and salary earners in the seven Fraser Budgets. The present Treasurer, Mr Keating, made this Labor Government's position very clear on Budget night, 23 August, when he stated:

This Government sought and received a very clear mandate from the Australian people to put the country back on the path to economic prosperity and to deal with inflation and unemployment simultaneously-with a spirit of consensus and fairness.

As well as providing a framework for economic recovery, the Budget is about fairness and equity. This Budget, of a Labor Government, begins to provide assistance in a responsible way to those people who have suffered most from the recession, to those people who have been disadvantaged by the economic mismanagement and discriminatory policies of the previous Government.

I should like to comment on some of the initiatives of the 1983-84 Labor Budget . Help for the unemployed is a high priority. The Budget contains significant changes to unemployment benefits. Benefits to single persons aged 18 years and over will increase from $68.65 to $73.60 a week. The single adult unemployment benefit will, with pensions, be indexed twice yearly in line with the consumer price index, and a $2 supplement will be provided in November 1983 and May 1984. The Fraser Government removed the indexation provisions for the single unemployed in 1978. In seven years of the Fraser Government, the unemployment benefit for those under 18 years of age was increased only once. This Budget has increased the unemployment and sickness benefit by $5 to $45 a week.

There must be a recognition that many young people must live away from home, for family reasons or to seek work, and that they need a liveable pension. I am not suggesting that the pension is yet completely adequate, but it is certainly correcting the abuse of young people that occurred during the Fraser period. In addition, in relation to unemployment, education initiatives have been introduced and will be directed towards increasing the participation rate of young people in post-compulsory education. Direct spending on education will rise by 11 per cent to $4,211,000 in 1983-84. An indication of the Labor Government's effort to re-order priorities and to innovate services that will benefit those in most need is the spouse carer's pension, which will be introduced from December 1983. This pension will be paid to men caring for an aged or invalid pensioner spouse. This is a new and innovative pension that recognises the growing number of elderly and handicapped people in our community who are in need of the support of a single carer. It is a pension that encourages care within the family setting. It will redress the inequity between husband and wife care givers and will thus enable several thousand men each year to cope better in caring for their spouses.

Through the introduction of Medicare, the Government is ensuring that a high quality of health care will be provided for all people and that we have a satisfactory health scheme. I do not think that anyone needs to be reminded that the Fraser Government killed Medibank, the most equitable health scheme we ever had. The latest Australian Bureau of Statistics survey shows that 1,953,000 Australians are without any health cover, through either private insurance or the Commonwealth cover provided to pensioners, the unemployed and low income earners-a tremendous indictment of the Fraser Government's health care provision .

One of the innovations in this Budget of which I am very proud is that under the new Medicare arrangements community health provision has been restored to the 1975 real level of the Whitlam Government. The Fraser Government cut back community health provision by $20m in real terms. An example of the present Government's commitment to community health services and an important element of health care are the recent announcement by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) of a grant of $100,000 each year for three years to the Lidcombe Workers Health Centre in the western suburbs of Sydney, in my own State. The Centre is the only one of its kind in New South Wales and it is involved in the treatment of and the provision of information on occupational health and safety for workers and unions in my State. This funding is further evidence of this Government's commitment to the accord between the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Labor Party, which states that there should be improvement in the quality of the working environment in Australia. It is also consistent with the major initiative proposed by the Hawke Labor Government of the setting up of a national occupational health and safety commission. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, has outlined the broad thrust of this program. Before this financial year is out, I hope that the occupational health and safety commission will be in operation.

If one considers for a moment the fact that the average person spends probably at least a third of his/her life in his/her working environment, and if one considers the inadequacy over many years in the provisions relating to health, safety and the standards which should be maintained in a modern community, one realises that this particular initiative, and the indication that the Lidcombe Workers Health Centre has of the Government's commitment to gaining knowledge in this area, are very commendable and are in sharp contrast to the inequity that was the catchcall of the former Fraser Government. Not only was the tax system turned into an instrument for transferring money from wages to profits and from lower to higher income earners, but the social security system was also abused to assist those people least in need of it. Even Senator Chaney was reported in the Melbourne Age of 27 August this year as saying:

I think we cannot escape the fact that there are some genuinely needy pensioners in the country who do not receive enough help, which some other people, by the advantageous arrangement of their assets, are able to draw on a system to a greater extent than their real degree of need would seem to justify.

Senator Chaney said that when he was a Minister, but nothing happened under the Fraser Government to prevent the millionaire-type person going on to the pension under that Government. It is one reason why another newspaper, the Australian, in commenting on the Valder report, said in its editorial that the Liberal Party was flawed:
. . . by the slowness of the Federal Parliamentary Party in trying to make up its mind on what it stands for.

One of the problems of the Liberal Party is that when in government it just did not do the things which were so patently obvious, and which were acknowledged by Senator Chaney; of course, nothing happened. In an effort to stop wealthy people exploiting or even cheating our pension system, the present Government will introduce an assets test. In 1976 the Fraser Government stopped counting large asset holdings in assessing pensions. This resulted in an explosion of shady investment schemes which often contrived ways of converting income to capital gains. The assets test is an effort to restore equity. It is one way of ensuring that those in need receive their share of government assistance and that those less in need make their fair contribution.

The assets test does not mean that aged persons alone are being asked to make a contribution. The Hawke Government takes equity and redistribution seriously. We intend to take these principles across the board to include employers, wage earners and their unions. The Government is trying to arrange for all of those people to be involved in contributing to redistribution and equity. Elderly Australians can be assured that when the proposals are brought down in their final form, after consultation with pensioner organisations and all of the people concerned, through the consultations organised by the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, we will have a system which will ensure that all honest wage and salary earners who become pensioners can be certain of an adequate pension and that all of those people who have been free loading on the Australian people will pay their fair share towards retirement.

Already these are some examples. The Government is attempting to reorder priorities in such a way that fairness and equity will prevail in our community. I refer to the Government's commitment to the Australian Council of Trade Unions -Australian Labor Party economic accord which covers, amongst other things, a fairer taxation system and social wage involving increased provision by the Government in the areas of health, education, housing and social services. The accord with the trade union movement further provides the opportunity for a united approach to the current economic crisis which can result in improving the welfare and well being of most Australians.

Hand in hand with these redistributive moves, this Government has signalled major changes in taxation. It is attempting to stamp out tax avoidance and tax evasion, the rorts and distortions of the Income Tax Assessment Act that characterised the Fraser Government's taxation policy. It has already been pointed out that, under the Fraser Government, the taxation system became a major instrument for redistributing income. Wealthy people have benefited. Professor Mathews, I think, summed it up when he pointed out that from 1965 to 1966 the non-pay-as-you-earn taxpayers paid one-third of total personal income tax. This figure had dropped by a staggering 13 per cent in 1982-83 to only 18 per cent. That is the tremendous burden that wage and salary earners had under the Fraser Government.

Tax avoidance and tax evasion exploded during the term of the Fraser Government . It is worth while recalling that in the 1980 election campaign Malcolm Fraser thundered 'we are clamping down on tax avoidance'. We know how hollow that proclamation was. According to the Australian Financial Review, by the end of the financial year 1981-82, the amount of tax uncollected from tax avoidance schemes had soared by 50 per cent to $150m. The number of persons participating in tax avoidance schemes increased by more than 25 per cent to over 28,000 people. They were the people the Fraser Government favoured during its seven years of office and seven Budgets in this country.

The Fraser Government showed that it did not have the necessary will to take action to destroy tax avoidance once and for all. As the McCabe-Lafranchi report stated, legislation introduced in 1978 to stop the trafficking in current year profits companies 'had no effect in curbing the sale-on of companies as a means of tax avoidance'. This Labor Government has already moved in a number of important areas of tax avoidance. Two major areas remain. The Treasurer, Mr Keating, has announced the Government's intention to strengthen, through amendment, section 26 (a) of the Income Tax Assessment Act so that it will operate effectively to tax speculative profits. I hope that this move will be successful but I must say that I agree with Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, when he says that in his view there should be a capital gains tax in Australia. He has said that he will continue to argue for it.

One of the distortions that we have in Australia is that the smart people have converted the smart money into capital gains and the remainder in the Australian community, the wage and salary earners, have subsidised the smart people, those 26,000-odd who comprise the elite group that the Fraser Government favoured. The Labor Government is introducing a redrafted form of the bottom of the harbour tax Bill in order to recoup tax avoided as a result of the notorious anti-social schemes to which I have referred. The efforts to block the bottom of the harbour tax Bill by members of the Opposition indicate that they have no concern about equity. We have always expected that the Liberal Party will continue to be a bit soft on tax dodgers, as I have already said. As far as the Australian Democrats are concerned, in the past they have supported measures for which we, the elected Labor Government, have a clear mandate. We look forward to seeing how the Democrats will shape up when they have the responsibility of letting the Labor Government move in this decisive way to clean up, not only in practice but also in a symbolic way, the tax avoidance industry which is the legacy of the Fraser Government to the Australian people.

For all these reasons I believe that the Fraser Government and its Ministers have been discredited. They still hang on in positions of influence within the Opposition, but the Valder Committee report commissioned by the Liberal Party has condemned the very leaders of the Liberal Party for the inefficiencies of the Fraser Government. The Hawke Government, despite the inheritance from the Fraser, Howard, Peacock, Carrick and Durack Liberal Government, if I can put it that way, has been left with great problems. Our Government is dealing with those problems and we are now in a position to turn the economy of Australia around. I am certain that the endorsement which the Australian people have given to the Labor Party will be reaffirmed time and again. The Liberal Party is dominated by its Western Australian branch and its dry and dismal policies. The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, said that he should occupy the middle ground in Australia. He took that literally. When he was pummelled by the Western Australian Liberal Party he ended up in the middle of Australia, somewhere between the Nullarbor Plain and Ayers Rock, dry and with nowhere to go . He is the creature of the conservative wing of the Liberal Party. That is the reason why the Hawke Government will introduce many more Budgets into this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On quiet analysis, this Budget will be shown to be a giant confidence trick, a hoax, a stream of broken promises. Its rhetoric does not match with the fine print of the supporting papers.
—Stop talking about Fraser's Budgets.

—Indeed, this Hawke Budget says one thing but the attached papers reveal the reverse. I will now proceed, by quiet analysis, to indicate why I say that. Let us look first at the stream of broken promises and ask ourselves where the Budget stands.
—What about Fraser's broken promises?

—The Hawke Government said that it would give an income tax cut to six million workers. It did nothing for six million workers, Senator Gietzelt. It did nothing. It said it would introduce a new six-step tax scale and it did nothing.
—You never talk about Federalism any more.

—Every time Senator Gietzelt interjects I will remind him that it did nothing. It said that it would increase the tax threshold to $5, 000. Since there is no interjection from Senator Gietzelt I remind him that it did nothing. It said that it would increase the pensioner tax threshold to $5, 893. It did nothing. It said it would increase the spouse and sole parent rebate .
—What about your Government?

—Senator Gietzelt now interjects. The Hawke Government did nothing. It said that there would be no capital gains tax yet it is to alter substantially section 26 (a) of the Income Tax Assessment Act to provide such a tax. Senator Gietzelt's own leader says that he favours and will work for a comprehensive capital gains tax. For three years the Australian Labor Party said with a bleeding heart that it would lower the price of petrol. The Treasurer, Mr Keating, went on platforms all over Australia saying that there would be cheaper petrol but the Government put up the price of fuel in Australia. It said that there would be no devaluation. It devalued promptly. It promised that there would be no change to superannuation arrangements in Australia and it broke that promise substantially. It said it would raise the age pension to 25 per cent of the average wage over three years. It has done nothing. It said that it would give pension increases three months earlier. It did nothing. The Government and its leaders said that they would bring down unemployment by 2 per cent in their first three years of office. Not only is the Government not doing that but also is its Budget predicting an increase in unemployment this year and an increase over three years. It said that it would lower inflation. It is, in fact, in its small print, budgeting for increased inflation. It said that it would index income tax. Instead, it is increasing indirect taxes against people. That is not a bad record of broken promises.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget is contrived on the greatest hoax that one could inflict upon the Australian people. It is contrived on the basis of a consumer price index increase of 7.5 per cent. That figure is derived by removing an amount of 2.6 per cent from the CPI because health insurance payments will be taken by direct tax and not by indirect tax in the future. Let me make this perfectly clear to the Australian people. Prices will not fall in any way. Costs will not fall. In fact, they will rise. Because the Government will be taking the money for health insurance out of people's taxes, out of their pay packets, and the people will not be paying private funds out of their side pockets, the Government will discount the CPI by 2.6 per cent and, therefore, people will receive less money. Because costs will not fall-in fact they will rise-the single pensioner will lose $2.30 a week. The married pensioner couple will lose $3.90. These are the people whom Labor speakers have been saying are protected by Labor. There can be a no more cynical raid upon the Australian public than a pretence that inflation has fallen by the simple device of altering the figures even though prices will have risen.

Prices must rise. Demonstrably all the State governments are putting up their indirect taxes in a very large way and the independent economists have predicted that inflation will be running at between 11 and 12 per cent in Australia in the current year. That is demonstrable. Nevertheless, by a snide method, there is the pretence that there will be a 7.5 per cent inflation rate and pensions and wages will be geared to that. Can there be a bigger fraud than that? These are the people who are claiming that they are representing the poor people and the average people of Australia.

This is a Budget that is supposed to move towards recovery-a Budget which, beyond its rhetoric and its small print, shows that company tax revenue this year will be 13.1 per cent lower than last year. How can we have recovery if the Budget is predicting that there will be less profit and less ability for companies to produce revenue? This is a Budget whose supporting papers say-I use the phrases from them-that there will be a marked fall in private business investment this year. There will be a marked fall in company profits and company tax. Yet this is recovery!

Let us pause on that and see what the Budget says. As we know, the Government said in its election policies and at its National Economic Summit Conference that there is only one issue and that is jobs. A certain Premier, now in some strife, the Federal President of the Labor Party, Mr Wran, has said there is only one issue-jobs, jobs, jobs. But let me show the deception in that statement as in other matters. Whilst members of the Labor Party were talking about jobs, jobs, jobs, at the National Summit they were conniving with the Australian Council of Trade Unions to adopt an option at the Summit which was rejected by all other interests, by business and commerce. I pause to say that there was no consensus at the Summit. The option that the Labor Party and the ACTU adopted was in the face of the advice they received from commerce and industry. Option A , according to the document of the National Economic Summit Conference of April 1983, will have an effect upon the percentage of unemployment in the first year of 8.9 per cent, in the next year of 10 per cent, and in the next of 10.1 per cent. The Government was saying to the people of Australia that by the end of its third year in office there would be a substantial rise in unemployment. The Budget itself says that. It shows that this year more people will be seeking employment than before, that is, the growth in jobs will not equal the number of extra people coming on the market. The Government is budgeting for higher unemployment at the end of this year. What kind of a Budget is it that honourable senators are now lauding which, on its own papers, not by any rhetoric of the Opposition, says that there will be a decline in company investment, a decline in company tax and, therefore, a decline in company profits? There will be an increase in unemployment and inflation. Where now are the feathers to fly with?

Let us bear in mind that that is the whole basis on which the Government stands . The Budget itself is one of three distinct steps-the Summit, the mini-Budget and the Budget. Taken together they make the pattern of the Budget for this year . It is a deception to look at the August document alone and not look at the three together. The Summit document had one characteristic-it rejected the consensus view of commerce and industry and accepted a device with the ACTU which would create more inflation and unemployment. The only kind of economic policy that could run from then onwards was one that the Fraser Government had brought in and which remained; that was the wages pause. What a fascinating piece of cynicism it is that the Labor Party under Mr Hawke, which in the months before March of this year together with the ACTU was setting out to destroy the wages pause, now depends upon it as the only platform that it has in its so called wages accord. What a strange situation that is. When the Treasurer brought in his mini-Budget in May he said there would be an improvement in the Australian economy, and he cited a number of reasons why that would be. He said:
As I noted in my address to the Summit Conference, we expect some improvement in economic activity in the course of 1983-84 with the main impetus coming from:

I pause to emphasise the words 'the main impetus coming from', and as I read his words one by one honourable senators will see that the only things he drew upon were the policies of the Fraser Government already in place, the first platform being:
The fiscal stimulus implicit in the Commonwealth Budget for 1982-83 and in prospect for 1983-84;
I interpolate that that was a Fraser Government Budget. He then referred to an improvement in the international economy-scarcely a Hawke initiative. He went on :
a marked slowing in stock decumulation so that a greater proportion of increased demand will be met from additional production;
That is scarcely a Hawke initiative. He continued:
the improved prospects for farm production and exports;

I suppose that, since the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, claims credit for the America's Cup, the Victorian Football League, the rugby league, and now the Davis Cup, he will claim that he broke the drought. The only drought he broke was the drought of rhetoric. Let me say that, of all those things, none was as a result of actions by the Hawke Government. The Treasurer's statement continued:
the pick-up in dwelling construction already under way;
Now they are claiming that is a result of one of their magic measures. The Treasurer went on:
and finally, but of fundamental importance, the improved prospects for on going moderation of income claims as the prices and incomes accord is implemented.

The only element that had some function in that regard was the wages pause of the Fraser Government. So at that stage the Hawke Government and its Treasurer had claimed basically that all those elements that were working for the good of the country were by way of nature, the overseas scene improving, or Fraser Government policies.

I come fundamentally to the mini-Budget, because in all this debate people are forgetting what happened. I seek leave to table a document, which the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) has seen, based entirely on the mini- Budget figures and tables setting out the nature of the mini-Budget.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the people of Australia of the nature of the mini-Budget and its impact. I deal with its adverse impact. As to taxpayers in general, we have had the abolition of the income tax rebate for health insurance ; the reduction of the current $1,040 threshold for minors to $416-a miserable amount indeed; the increase in the block concessional rebate level from $1,590 to $2,000; and another miserable one, the abolition of the $1,000 dividend rebate from which employees of companies might have gained some benefit. Are they good concessions? The taxpayers have been raided.

SPEECH.PARA: For retired people, the income test has been re-instituted for age and service pensions for those 70 years of age and older. Did the Government say it would do that? No. Indeed, it made it quite clear that it would not. Then, of course, we have had the raid upon superannuation by taxing in a severe way lump sum payments, something the Government undertook to the people that it would not do.

As to home buyers, when one listened to debates on this matter one was sure that members of the Government were creatures of policies to stimulate home buying. They have terminated the home deposit assistance scheme from 1 October, they have terminated the housing interest income tax rebate scheme from 1 July, and they have terminated the housing interest rebate from 1 October. They are silent on all these things now, and they want to make it apparent that they have invented a home savings scheme of some kind.

They remain silent in regard to public works. Proposed expenditure on the Brisbane Airport has been reduced and they have suspended and deferred elements of the aerodrome local ownership plan. Remember the miserable cutting of the money for the Alice Springs-Darwin railway?

There has been a huge rejection of all the basic supplementary elements of the bicentennial water resources program. The Government has rejected the allocation of some $350m to that program, even though it would have involved first class job creation schemes, even though those water projects would have helped create jobs for the future, even though the experts of the departments both State and Federal had said that these projects had priority, and even though the committee on the prospects for water for the future, to the year 2000, had vetted them. Still the Government rejected this program. What about the termination of the special youth employment training program? Remember also that the Government increased the interest rate on capital for Telecom Australia and Australia Post.

Do honourable senators remember the raid on rural dwellers, with the reduction of the freight equalisation for petroleum products, the alteration of the primary producing averaging scheme and the income equalisation deposit scheme interest rates, the extension of the depreciation of farm plant and equipment from three years to five years and, as to the Australian Wheat Board, the removal of the subsidy in regard to commercial borrowings? All these things were a part of a Budget that was supposed to be good for the people. As to aviation fuel, the Government has increased the excise by 2c a litre on avgas and avtur.

As to industry, it has reduced to no more than 5c the difference in multibrand pharmaceuticals. It has terminated the special depreciation allowance on petrol storage, along with the special tax concessions for the conversion of oil-fired and liquefied petroleum gas plant. It has removed exemptions on interest in regard to withholding tax, a matter which to some extent comes under the umbrella of the Australian Industry Development Corporation.

Do honourable senators recall in regard to hospitals the reduction in the Commonwealth contribution to the Hospital Benefits Reinsurance Trust Fund? Do they recall in regard to migrants the income test on the living allowance for adult migrants and education? Do we recall, as to the Public Service, the reduction of activities in overseas posts and, as to repatriation, paying certain pensions fortnightly in advance? That is just a small string of broken promises and, indeed, of new and biting initiatives that hurt the ordinary person and of which no indication at all was given. As will be seen from the Hansard, when we take the gains and losses, for this year alone there has been a raid of $1,397m on the taxpayers of Australia.

As if that were not enough, as if that were not hitting hard enough, along came the Budget and in it a series of other miserable attacks upon the ordinary provident family. The whole thrust of what this Government is doing is to attack the ordinary family, the struggling family on a middle income which is seeking to save and seeking to educate its children. Wherever one goes one sees the hand of the socialists cutting away. Now people will be robbed because those in work will have to pay a 1 per cent tax by way of levy for Medicare. Of course there is no rebate for that at all and the conditions of that scheme do not give people access to their own doctors or to private accommodation in hospitals.

Something else that was never mentioned is the assets test to be applied to pensioners. What a mess, what an utter muddle it is. How can it be that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) can come in here, as he did again yesterday, and explain to us that if I as a pensioner were to give one of my family several years before I died say $30,000 or $40,000 of precious savings, that would be subject to the deprivation test. However, I could get the pension if I bought jewellery and antiques which I could will to my children. What kind of muddled mind is it that tries all these sorts of nonsenses? What kind of muddled mind is it that says it is against double dipping but is thoroughly willing to double dip on both the lump sum contributions and the assets test? If ever there were double dipping by governments, there it is.

So what do we see? We see a snide attempt to say to people: 'We are not going to encourage you to be provident; we are against that kind of situation. If you seek to be provident and to use your savings upon your retirement to pay off your home, to buy a car or to help one of your children to start in business, or , indeed, you seek to hold and to will those savings to your children, you will not be eligible for a pension'. The hand of socialism will come out. The Government will say: 'We will take our greedy share of it because we are opposed to providence, we are opposed to these kinds of situations'.The Government did not say one word before it was elected about what it proposed to do.

Look at the miserable situation we are in. The Government made a pretence to improve student assistance allowances. However, these allowances have been increased at a percentage below the inflation rate so students are losing in real terms.

What kind of humbug is it that protested for three years that there ought to be an indexing of personal income tax to stop people's incomes being eroded by inflation and does nothing about that situation upon gaining government? In fact , the Government does the reverse. On gaining office it indexed indirect taxes. So the Government is taking more and more without having to say so in a Budget. So we have seen a raid upon indirect taxes and excise. We have seen a raid upon beer, cigarettes and wine.

We have seen miserable kinds of things happen. We have seen the abolition of the tax concession on home insulation. Can there be anything more mean-minded than the Government's move against those young people of Australia who give their services voluntarily in the Army, Navy and Air Force reserves? These people were given one simple incentive by governments-that is, that the amount of money they earned was tax exempt. What is more mean than for the hand of socialism to reach in and say: 'No, we are not going to do it for you any more. We are not going to let you have it'.

These things then become the Budget, the Budget that has been represented as a Budget that is fair and that is moving towards recovery. Let us take stock of the Budget.
