It is an extraordinary situation that can project to the people of Australia in a public relations exercise a product which is the very reverse. It is an extraordinary situation that can project a Budget Speech as saying one thing when the documents supporting it say the other. Let me take the examples one by one. The Government is supposed to be a Government pledged to the re- employment of people. Its whole basis of coming to Government was that it could do something that the Fraser Government could not do, that it would in fact reduce unemployment and create more jobs. The Government had not had the flush of victory from its face a month when at the National Economic Summit Conference it confessed, although in small print, that in fact what it was planning was more unemployment, and more unemployment steadily, for the next three years. What an extraordinary situation that is! The Government had not been in office a few months before it raided the people in a mini-Budget, which has been incorporated in Hansard for all to read, and took from provident people the real margin of providence that they had-namely, their ability to save and their ability to acquire.

The Government had not been in office a bare five months before it brought down a Budget which went further than that and which moved into attacks on providence not only in regard to lump sum superannuation but also, of course, on assets tests. Each day people get up in this place and talk about the rich double dipping. Let me simply say that I see no rich in the municipal employees or Public Service unions objecting to the lump sum superannuation proposals. In fact, the great majority of the 1.8 million people who are being impacted by this new grab are ordinary small income earners who live on a margin. What about the waterside workers? Are they the rich? Are they the people whom the Government wants to hit too? Everybody ought to know that waterside workers retire early at the age of 60 because of redundancy problems in the industry. Special provisions are made for them in terms of lump sum superannuation to bridge the gap between the time they retire and the age at which they would qualify for a pension. Do we take notice of them or the municipal employees and the public servants? What about members of the ironworkers union? Where are the voices in this place for the ordinary people of Australia, for the ordinary families of Australia and for the pensioners who are going to be robbed by the nastiest and ugliest trick of arithmetic that one could have?

I repeat: How can people be anything but humbugs and hypocrites if they say: ' It is true that prices will not fall-indeed, prices are likely to rise specifically by Federal Government and State government actions-but by juggling the arithmetic of the consumer price index we are going to contrive that they appear to have fallen by 2.6 per cent. Therefore, we are going to take from the single pensioner $2.30 a week and from a married pensioner couple $3.90 a week'. Of course, the Government will take money from all wage earners. Yet it says that it is out to maintain real wages.

I said at the beginning of my speech that, on a quiet analysis of the Summit and, indeed, of the mini-Budget and the present Budget, it would be shown that what has happened to the people of Australia is a gross confidence trick, a hoax , a destruction of promises, a tissue of promises which have all been broken. Let the Hawke Government never again talk about broken promises of the past. This Government is now the professional expert on them. If ever Mr Hawke wants to be photographed against records-and he shows such a narcissistic tendency to latch on to other people's success because he cannot do it on his own--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is turning now, is it not?

—What I have said is perfectly true. He is latching on to others because like Narcissus he is so engrossed with his own reflection in the pool that he cannot hear the voices of the 600,000 or 700,000 unemployed Australians-the growing number of Australians who day by day are unemployed because this Budget not only does nothing to ease unemployment but also will create more unemployment. There can be nothing worse than a government which was elected on an issue that it would create employment and then set about on policies which it knew and in fact stated in small print would create more unemployment. I know nothing more deceptive, more humbug and hypocritical than that. I commend these remarks to the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sir John Carrick in his recitation said that he would have a quiet look at the Budget. The points that he tried to make in relation to broken promises seem to me to be very hollow indeed. He has been negative, hypocritical and hollow. I do not intend to go through word for word, clause by clause, what the honourable senator had to say about the Budget. But I do intend to say one or two things.
—It is a pity he has been accurate, though.

—If the honourable senator will wait a moment he will see. During the last election Howard went throughout the country making claims that there was going to be a $6 billion deficit. It was only after the Hawke Government came to office-and there is a great deal of silence on the other side at the moment-that we discovered that the deficit would have been $9.6 billion. When Senator Sir John Carrick talks about broken promises it is fairly realistic for the people of Australia to consider the first and major lie that was told by the discredited former Treasurer to the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us go a little further. Senator Sir John Carrick talked about the Government imposing a further burden of $13.3m-I think that was the figure he used-on the taxpayers of Australia through the changes we have made regarding taxation. Let us go back to what happened in this chamber after the Hawke Labor Government took over. Legislation was put before this chamber as well as the House of Representatives where, I might add, the Government has a majority of 25 seats. Because of the action of the previous Government the people of Australia judged very clearly that they were not going to have any more of that Government and elected a Hawke Labor government with that majority in the House of Representatives. The Government introduced the Dividend Recoupment Tax Bill in the House of Representatives. When the Bill came before the Senate members on the other side of the chamber, including Senator Sir John Carrick, voted against it. Therefore, the people of Australia were denied $500m in revenue that could have been gained from the cheats and the crooks-the people who had not paid tax in Australia. Senator Sir John Carrick and others on the other side of the chamber supported that denial.

Hypocritically Senator Sir John Carrick went through the Budget in a negative way and tried to destroy the things that the Hawke Labor Government is doing in an effort to gain some of the revenue necessary to meet some of the requirements of the people of Australia. Five hundred million dollars was denied the Government of Australia by this Opposition. The Opposition talks about hypocrites. It caused a situation in which the Government had to bring down a Budget and had to introduce new measures to obtain further income to enable it to meet the needs of the people of Australia.

Let me go back to the time of the election. Never let us forget that it was the people of Australia who threw out the Fraser Government and its broken promises. The people of Australia said: 'We do not want a Treasurer who said that we would have a $6 billion deficit and we finished up with a $9.6 billion deficit'. The Opposition did not react to the people of Australia. The Opposition voted against the Dividend Recoupment Tax Bill and, therefore, against the people of Australia. The Opposition allowed the tax avoiders and the tax evaders to get out of their responsibilities regarding taxation in Australia and forced the Hawke Labor Government to bring down a Budget which would put that $500m into the revenue. As I said before, I think that answers very clearly the points made by Senator Sir John Carrick regarding the Budget and his negative attitude to what is happening in Australia, particularly towards the unemployed.

I believe this Budget has laid the foundation for a sustained economic revival in Australia. Despite the points raised by Senator Sir John Carrick and despite the problems which we have, when I go through the figures in a moment it will be seen that there has been an improvement in employment in Australia, and we have been in government for only seven months. The first signs of recovery are already apparent after only seven months in office. I refer to falling interest rates, a jump in motor car registrations, an upsurge in the building and construction industry and increased employment. Business and consumer confidence is thriving. That confidence has been fuelled in no small way by a magnificent victory at Newport, Rhode Island and in the Davis Cup, by the participation of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the participation of the people of Australia-a feeling that Australia can do it, a feeling that we know that this Government will do it and the people of Australia will support it in allowing it to do it.

A recent report of the Melbourne University Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research stated that there was a continuing upward trend in consumer confidence that was almost unprecedented so soon after a Federal election. Just seven months after the Federal election we find that there is an upsurge in consumer confidence. Members of this chamber do not have to take my word for it; it is quite obvious. A report that was published in the Australian Financial Review a few days ago under the heading 'Survey shows consumer optimism on increase' stated:
The Hawke Government is defying the usual trend of post-election disillusionment , a regular Melbourne University survey showing continued increasing consumer optimism as the recession bottoms out.
The article continued:

The biggest improvement is in the increased proportion of the 1,088 interviewed consumers who consider that now is a good time to buy major household items, a good news results for home durables manufacturers that adds to the house building recovery.
The report further emphasised that confidence is now starting to show in the consumer groups throughout Australia. It stated:

The six-weekly surveys now have shown three successive increases for the first time since the third quarter of 1980, a trend which the Melbourne Institute and Morgan Research describe as ''an extremely positive sign.''

The Melbourne Institute and Morgan Research say that the overall improvement in consumer optimism since the March election is remarkable as the survey index markedly fell after each of the previous four federal elections, presumably as voters became disillusioned with the new government not fulfilling their high hopes.
The editorial in the Australian dated 17 September 1983 entitled 'New mood of optimism in consumer spending' stated:
There is nothing less certain than the future, or more fragile than predictions of it. Even so, for the economic recovery to continue, we need to have confidence about our future.

The marked improvement in consumer sentiment, measured by a joint survey of the Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research and the Roy Morgan Research Centre, conducted last month after the Budget, is therefore a most welcome sign that the worst of the recession is behind us and, indeed, that the economy is growing again. Spending by consumers is by far the largest component of this growth.

I believe those points show very clearly that the remarks passed by Senator Sir John Carrick are not indicative of what is happening in the community. There is an encouraging growth in the number of jobs being advertised in the newspapers. Reports by personnel agencies indicate that some employers are having difficulties in filling skilled positions. There is a consumer recovery and more jobs are starting to be advertised in newspapers throughout Australia. The Australian people are in a buying mood. A consumer led recovery would be the best possible trend for Australia because it would tend to stimulate employment immediately in the manufacturing and distribution sectors as well as directly in the retailing sector. By Christmas, this consumer confidence will translate into consumer spending and the reality of the economic recovery will become apparent, even to those who failed in the task over seven long, wasted years. If we look at what happened under the Fraser Government we will see that that sort of confidence and consumer spending was not taking place. I believe the Australian people took the correct action when they threw out the Fraser Government on 5 March.

By the end of this financial year the Australian economy will reach a growth rate of between 5 per cent and 6 per cent. I believe we could look at a number of examples of an increase in the growth rate. Although that statement in some ways does not refer to the growth rate in consumer spending, it certainly refers to the confidence that is showing in the market place. A spokesman for David Jones Pty Ltd was reported in the Australian of Tuesday, 4 October-that is not so long ago-as having said that trading was very good in all cities and suburban stores. He was actually talking about trading on a holiday. At this stage I will not argue the case for or against the extension of trading hours. The survey conducted by the Morgan Research Centre and the Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research showed quite clearly that there is an upsurge in consumer spending throughout Australia and there certainly is growth in the economy. The Budget tactics and Budget policies of the Government are starting to work. Consumer spending is increasing. It is very good to see the Deputy President nodding in agreement.

The Budget has placed considerable emphasis on the building and construction industries to get the economy moving in that area which normally leads in economic recovery. The Government expects to see strong growth in building as well as the area of building supplies. We expect to see large growth in the 26 allied trades that are tied to the building industry. We expect to see growth in land development, roads, kerb and channelling services, power and water. We expect to see increases for local authorities for the establishment of new homes and increases in their revenue from rates from the establishment of those homes.

The Hawke Government has also begun the process of restructuring two of this country's most distorted financial systems-those of taxation and social security . We heard remarks being passed earlier in regard to social security and the proposals put forward by this Government, particularly in relation to the asset test. I do not believe there is any Australian who would not believe or would not know that we have an aging population, and that we have a diminishing working population that will pay more and more income tax. Because of the large number of people who will retire, and because of the aging of the population, that working population will carry more of the burden to provide the social security and other benefits that the community must pay to the aging population in Australia.

It is reasonable to expect that there should be some type of asset test. It is reasonable to expect that we should give some relief to the people who are paying income tax and that we should not provide money for people who do not require that money. Money spent on social security for such people would be better spent providing finance for the people who need to be supported by the community and by the Government. I do not believe that any fair thinking Australian would deny that, given our aging population and the problems that will face us in the future. On a number of occasions in this chamber Senator Chaney has said that there should be some type of asset test. The only reason the previous Government did not bring one in was that it could not agree on the way in which the system should work.

Let us look at the housing situation in Australia. Senator Sir John Carrick made some comment about our cutting out the home deposit assistance scheme. We cut out that scheme because it contained a requirement until 30 September when it was revoked that a certain amount of money-I think $2,000-had to be saved over a two-year period in order to qualify. The difference now is that we have introduced the first home ownership assistance scheme which for the first time allows money to be paid from the Federal Government to help people meet the requirements of the deposit in order to purchase a spec home or to enter into a contact to have one built. We are starting to see an upsurge in activity in the home building industry, particularly throughout the State of Queensland. That upsurge has now started in Brisbane and it is as a result of assistance given by the Federal Government under the first home ownership assistance scheme.

Both the taxation and social security systems had been mutated into monsters that had indulged the wealthy at the expense of the most needy. Both systems have stalled after decades of amendments, bandages and abuses. We had band-aid attempts by the previous Government to do something about it, but with no real results. That Government did not have the guts to take on the problem of developing an asset test. Of course, this process is now changing. We now have Ministers and a Government who will accept their responsibility not only to the taxpayer but also to parts of the community, the aged and the invalid, who need some support from the Federal Government. With the Government doing something about social security benefits, I really believe that we have a government with a social conscience. We will have a more reasonable redistribution of the benefits that should go to every Australian.

This Budget is the first genuine attack on unemployment in this country. After seven stagnant years of coalition government, things are starting to improve. Senator Sir John Carrick said that we promised we would lower unemployment. We are keeping our promise. I will read out the figures for the first six months under our Government. Senator Walters is shaking her head but she can get the figures and read them. She will find that this is the case. The national unemployment figures-actual figures, not seasonally adjusted figures-at the end of August showed unemployment at 684,100 people or 9.9 per cent of the work force. At the end of February that figure was 747,300 or 10.7 per cent. This shows a drop of 0.8 per cent in unemployment since the Hawke Government took office.

We should look at what is happening with unemployment in Queensland. The figures there show very clearly that the Premier of Queensland and the people in charge of the Government in Queensland are certainly not addressing themselves to the problems that exist, either on a national or State basis. Queensland currently has 10.1 per cent of its work force unemployed. The number of unemployed youth in Queensland between the ages of 15 and 19 is 19,800 or 20 per cent. That is an increase of 7,000 in one year. There is 13.6 per cent unemployment amongst single females. Queensland has the highest adult male unemployment rate in Australia with 57,000 or 10.2 per cent. (Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jones, before I call you again I draw your attention to the fact that you should not assume, as you did in the course of your speech, that the nodding of the Presiding Officer's head necessarily indicates agreement with what has been said. There may be other explanations. In any case, whoever is in the chair is completely impartial and does not express agreement or disagreement with anything said by any honourable senator, as provided under Standing Orders.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I accept the reprimand from the Chair in relation to your nodding. Before the interruption, I was discussing unemployment in Queensland in the national context. The rate of growth of unemployment in Australia is currently 48 per cent but the rate of growth in Queensland was 74 per cent up to July 1983. Twelve months ago Queensland's unemployed totalled 67,000, or 6.5 per cent. The Queensland Premier claims that his Government created 49,000 jobs in 1982-83. But these figures are grossly and deliberately misleading; they were figures for the period 1980-81. Queensland experienced no employment creation in 1982-83. In fact, for every month over the past 12 months fewer jobs have been available compared with the corresponding month of the previous year. The Queensland Government claims that Queensland's unemployment rate is due to interstate and overseas migration to that State totalling 42,127 people during the calendar year 1982. But only one-quarter to one-third of those people were seeking to enter the work force. Only about 14, 000 of these people went to Queensland to work. The Queensland Government is still stalling on finalising details of the Commonwealth's community employment program although it has formally agreed to it. Its delay is probably linked to the fact that it has syphoned off job creation money into the short term money market to balance the Budget which otherwise would have shown a deficit of about $53m.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is worth noting also that the Government has made $15.9m available to the Queensland Government for job creation programs for the six months ended 30 June 1983 from money saved during the wages pause. I think that is worth mentioning. A moment ago Senator Sir John Carrick was very critical of the wage pause by the Australian Government. (Quorum formed) We sat on this side of the chamber while there were two Liberal senators on the other side and we listened to Senator Sir John Carrick go on with his hypocritical, negative debate in relation to this Budget. I find now that, when we start to produce figures to refute some of the comments made by him, the Leader of the Opposition continues to call for quorums. I have noticed that, on a number of occasions, he has not been very interested in whether there has been a quorum in this House. I am surprised to see him in here. I was saying that the unemployment problem in Queensland is worse than it is in the rest of Australia. It is one of the worst States in Australia. Yet, the Premier is going to the electorate on 22 October. I only hope, even with the interference by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, that people who are listening know of the problems that exist in relation to unemployment in Queensland.

Let me go a little further. Let me say something about what the Government is doing on a positive basis. Funding in the Budget for unemployment initiatives has, at least, been raised to realistic levels. We have to remember that they are being rasied to these levels even though Senator Chaney and the Opposition voted against the tax recoupment Bills and denied to the Government $500m which should have been revenue to come to the Government prior to the Budget. It denied the Government that revenue. This Government is still being positive in increasing the expenditure in relation to employment initiatives in this country . Trade training will be allocated $17.8m, up 23.5 per cent on the amount allocated by Senator Chaney's Government last year. Skills training has been allocated $23.5m, up 58.7 per cent on the amount allocated by Senator Chaney's Government last year. The amount allocated to youth training is up 20 per cent to $93.5m. Special training which covers special employment counselling and training through the Commonwealth Employment Service for job seekers disadvantaged because of mental or physical disability, different cultural or language background or through being unemployed for lengthy periods has been allocated $33.2m which is up 4.7 per cent. Employment services have been allocated $119.6m which is an increase of 19.4 per cent. Assistance to long term unemployed, up from a miserable $400,000 to $32.1m is an increase of 8,000 per cent. Yet this Opposition continually opposes what this Government is doing for the unemployed and employment in this country. More than $300m has been allocated for the community employment program which has already been launched.

Let us look at the attitude of this Government. We should go back to the speech made by Senator Sir John Carrick in which he continually criticised the Australian Labor Party and the Hawke Government. I remind this chamber and the people in the gallery of what this Government did when in Government and what it is now doing in Opposition. When it was in Government Mr Howard, the discredited Treasurer, went around this country saying that there would be a deficit of $6 billion when, in fact, we found the deficit would be $9.6 billion. That was the No. 1 lie perpetrated by the Government that was in power at that time. Secondly , the Opposition voted against tax recoupment Bills which were introduced into this House by a government that had a 25-seat majority in the House of Representatives. The Opposition, now led by Senator Chaney, has the audacity to continually call quorums so that people cannot finish the remarks which they want to make in relation to the Budget. He is a great believer in free and democratic speech in this country. This Opposition voted against the tax recoupment Bills and voted against--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President. It must be out of order for an honourable senator to reflect on the requirement that there be a quorum in this place. I think that the speaker should be required to withdraw that remark.
—There is no point of order.

—Finally, I repeat that members of this Opposition, led by Senator Chaney, voted against an attempt by the Government to regain the $500m lost in revenue through the tax recoupment Bills. They are responsible for the shortage of revenue available to this Government because they supported the tax avoiders, the tax evaders and the crooks in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —No one man has done more to tarnish the image of politicians than the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I take strong exception to the fact that one single dishonourable man can, indeed, tarnish to such a degree--

—I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. The honourable senator has referred to the leader of the Government in another place as a dishonourable man. I ask that she withdraw that remark; it must be unparliamentary.
—It is an unparliamentary expression, Senator Walters. I ask that you withdraw that remark.
—I will withdraw it if it is unparliamentary. No single man has tarnished to such a degree the reputation of us all. His blatant dishonesty, his contempt for the Australian people-

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Once again the honourable senator is referring to the Leader of the Government in another place as being blatantly dishonest. Once again that is a reflection on the character and integrity of the Prime Minister of Australia, and I seek your ruling as to whether it is unparliamentary. If so, I would seek to have those remarks withdrawn.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, we have just listened to a speech in which the word 'lies' was used, and all the rest. There seems to be a sudden concern on that side of the chamber which was not evident a few minutes ago. In any event, the language used by the honourable senator was not unparliamentary and Government members are simply trying to disrupt her speech.
—I rule that it is unparliamentary to refer to the Prime Minister of Australia as being blatantly dishonest, and I suggest that Senator Walters withdraw that remark.
—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. It seems to me that on this side of the House we cannot use any expressions against the Prime Minister--
—Order, Senator Walters! At the moment you are reflecting on the decision of the Chair, and that I will not have. I suggest that you withdraw the comments you have made.

—I withdraw the comments concerned. The Prime Minister had contempt for the Australian people. I hope that that expression will not be ruled as unparliamentary. He had such contempt for the Australian people that in his policy speech he made a list of promises which at that time he had no intention of keeping. I take exception to the fact that the people of Australia are now saying: 'We have to learn. We obviously have to become accustomed to politicians' words not being kept'. The Prime Minister made these promises, but obviously there was no thought in his mind of keeping them. We recall his promise to reduce taxation, and I will refer to it later. The present Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, in a speech to Labor economists said:

SPEECH.PARA: If Labor does not gain office next election then by 1983, when we could next hope to gain office, we would face a mammoth task in rebuilding the public sector-and maybe an equally mammoth task in convincing the electorate that it should pay a higher level of tax to enable us to do so.

Mr Willis acknowledged that a Labor Government would have to educate the Australian people to pay a higher level of tax to enable it to increase the Public Service. Yet in his policy speech the Prime Minister assured the Australian people that he would reduce taxes, and I will come to that a little later. Let us look at the promises of Mr Hawke, this new Prime Minister of Australia. He started making them before the election was called. He had challenged Mr Hayden's leadership, and when he failed, and failed quite miserably, he then made a promise to the Australian people that he would not challenge that leadership again until after an election. That was the first promise, as a pretender to the leadership, to be broken because prior to the election being announced he did in fact, along with his collegues, challenge that leadership. Indeed, much to their shame, his colleagues allowed him to break that promise and even encouraged him. So he started off breaking his promises well before the election. The Australian people should have been warned , but they did not believe anyone could be quite so compromising. He has dishonoured every promise he made in his policy speech, except the one that he would stop the dam in Tasmania. He said that jobs, jobs, jobs were his main priority.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not quite correct.

—As Senator Button says, that is not quite true. It certainly did not work out that way. He then refused to answer questions put to him in the House of Representatives, until he was forced to do so in front of the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies. He was the one, when questions were being asked in the House of Representatives about 'Who was the one who leaked?', who rang friends and told them not to go into partnership with Mr Combe and so save themselves a considerable amount of money. According to Mr Hawke, he did not tell them why but he did tell them not to go into partnership with Mr Combe, long before his Cabinet knew and long before the Australian public knew that Mr Combe was not to act as a lobbyist. Of course, the Australian people were still paying Mr Combe at this stage for work that Mr Hawke has said could not be carried out. He rang two of his buddies and said: ' Save yourselves some dough. Don't go into partnership with Combe'.
—He did not say that at all.

—That is exactly what happened. He was also paid for speeches that he made while he was still a shadow Minister in the Opposition. He was paid for those parliamentary political speeches under cover until Mr Combe brought out that information before the Royal Commission. Of course, his latest escapade is incredible. He had nearly $4,000 in cash in his briefcase-Australian and American dollars-which was stolen from him in a hotel. That is quite incredible. What sort of man carries cash of that magnitude, and in Australian and American dollars? We will just wait and see what sort of man does that. Now let us look at the broken promises.
—Other people get paid in cash.
—They did not like that.
—No, they did not like that. Prior to the election Mr Hawke said :

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the Australian people have had enough of election promises made to be broken. I offer no fistful of dollars to be snatched back after the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was dead right, wasn't he?

—Wasn't he just! He offered the Australian people cuts in taxation. He said there would be 500,000 new jobs in Labor's first term. Well, we will wait and see on that one. He said there would be 'immediate reductions in income tax for almost six million Australians'. As I have already indicated, he had no intention of keeping that promise because Mr Willis had said previously: 'We have to educate the Australian people to accept increases in taxation to support the enlarged Public Service'. Another one of the Prime Minister's broken promises was that he would not change tax on lump sum superannuation payments. How could anyone be quite so- I am stuck for a word. He told the people he would not impose tax on lump sum superannuation payments, and immediately did so in the first couple of months he was in office. He said he would maintain the home loan interest rebate, but he immediately grabbed that back. He said he would keep the health insurance rebate until the introduction of Medicare, but he grabbed back $550m from the Australian people in the rebates they should have had this year.

SPEECH.PARA: He said that he would not interfere at all with pensions. We now know that the means testing of the over-70s was introduced in a mini-Budget. He could not even wait for the main Budget to be brought down. He also, of course, introduced an assets test on pensions. Yet this man promised the Australian people he would not touch pensioners' cheques. He assured everyone, including the pensioners, that he would abolish the pharmaceutical declaration form. He did not abolish it ; he introduced a different form. He said that he would increase the spouse rebate and the sole parent rebate. Not only did he not increase those rebates, there were rumours rife that he would get rid of them altogether. Many families were concerned about these rumours.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who spread the rumours?

—They were spread by the Australian Labor Party because it was not going to keep its promise of increasing these rebates. It thought that if it spread a rumour that the spouse rebate would be decreased, people would not be so concerned when the promise was broken and it was maintained at its present rate. When we came to office in 1975 the dependent spouse rebate was $400. By 1982 it had gone up to $1,030, well above the inflation rate, because we believed that the spouse at home who is looking after children or elderly parents needs some recognition. The Labor Government has made no recognition at all of that group of women, a fact which appals me. We were also told that drought relief payments to help rural recovery would be maintained for some time . Again, that was another area that was immediately withdrawn.
—Don't you know the drought is over?

—Senator Ray has such little knowledge that he thinks that as soon as it rains the grass grows a couple of inches and stock are well catered for. The man does not have a clue what he is talking about. We were also told that there would be removal of the sales tax on retread tyres and that the price of petrol would be reduced by 3c a litre. What has happened? Not only has the price of petrol not been reduced, it has gone up. It will also be indexed twice- yearly. People will get used to their petrol prices going up because they will go up twice a year in line with the consumer price index. So much for the promise of a reduction in petrol prices.

SPEECH.PARA: We were told that there would be no more job losses in the steel industry. Senator Button knows to his shame that that promise also was not kept. We were told that there would be a maintaining of the real funding to local government. That was another promise broken. If Senator Button doubts that all he has to do is ask local governments. They will let him know just what they feel about it. We were told that the tax threshold would be lifted to $5,000 for general taxpayers or $5,893 for pensioners. Again, that promise was broken, As I say, every promise has been broken.

We have had the excuse from the Government that the reason for all these broken promises-Senator Jones also made this statement today-was that there was a $9.6 billion deficit. I am not quite sure whether Senator Jones, like Senator Cook, was also hoodwinked and swallowed the propaganda laid down by his Party. Indeed, Senator Cook had to come into this place and apologise because he had been hoodwinked by his Government. That $9.6 billion deficit figure was not accurate. It was a proposed deficit. There is no deficit until a Budget is brought down. Once the Budget is brought down there is then a deficit for the following year. The Budget deficit figure of $9.6 billion was made on quite a number of assumptions that were not accurate. Indeed, prior to the recent Budget those assumptions were all revised. So the $9.6 billion deficit figure was a lot of hot air.

There is nothing magical about a proposed deficit. Indeed, in 1976 the proposed deficit for the following year was $4.8 billion. When we brought down our Budget that deficit was cut to $2.7 billion, cut nearly in half. In 1978 the proposed Budget deficit was $6 billion. Again, when we brought down the Budget that deficit had dropped to nearly half of the proposed figure, to $3.4 billion. If Mr Hawke had wanted to, he could have halved the proposed deficit as we had done on previous occasions. There is nothing magical about that, yet this Government has told the Australian people that that was its excuse for all its broken promises. It did it so well and so often that its own members swallowed it. Senator Jones stood up here and said that the deficit was $9.6 billion. There was no deficit of that proportion. Senator Cook said similar things and had to come into this place and apologise for having misled the Senate on one occasion because he too had swallowed the Government's propaganda.

Let us look at what the deficit is now. It is $8.4 billion, double what the previous Government's deficit was in the previous year. It represents 4.7 per cent of gross domestic product, the largest deficit since the disastrous Whitlam years. Total public sector borrowing will be between 8 and 9 per cent of gross domestic product-at least $13 billion, the largest for more than a quarter of a century. What will that do to interest rates? All the economists are telling us loud and clear what it will do. It will send interest rates up. They estimate that the CPI will go up to between 11 and 12 per cent. The Government's interest rate payments will equal its payments for health and education together, two of our big spending areas. That money will be wasted on interest payments. No country can stand that sort of waste of money.

We have already considered the Labor Party's promises regarding pensioners. I would like to go back to that area because it is one about which I am particularly concerned. As I said, the Prime Minister promised that the pensioner cheque would not be touched, yet he introduced the means test for the over-70s. In other words, the aged people of our community who are, I suppose, at a time in life when they most rely on their relatives to look after their budgeting and are not as capable as they used to be of working out their own financial situation are to be penalised. People come to us and say: 'My son has worked out my budgeting for me. I cannot do without that extra money I was getting, un-means tested, that your Government was giving me because the amount of money I had coming in was paying my rent or my accommodation expenses in my unit. I shall now have to downgrade my accommodation. I am 80 years old and I shall have to move so that my budgeting can allow for the additional money that the Government is taking off me'. It is a situation in which the Government has been cruelest, attacking those who are not able to look after their own financial situation. To alter a person's financial situation at the age of 80 years is extremely cruel.

Then we come to the assets test that the Government has now applied to pensioners. This is pretty good if one works it properly. The assets test allows one to have a home at any cost, a car of any value, a yacht worth any amount, a caravan, jewellery of any value, works of art of any value, and as many antiques as one can fit into one's home. That is not bad for those who go into that area. The Government says that it does not like double dipping. But let us look at single pensioners who have perhaps a small home, no works of art, very little jewellery, no boat, no caravan and indeed, often, no car-or they might just have a car. But suppose they have been left a holiday home-they are called shacks in Tasmania-that has been in the family for many years. They will be disadvantaged by the Government if it sticks to its present system.

Of course, it is all under query because yesterday Senator Grimes went to the Town Hall in Sydney, where 2,000 pensioners told him just what they thought about the Government's scheme. They told him so forcibly what they thought about the scheme that he was then saying: 'Look, don't get so upset. We are thinking about it. We shall have another look at it. We are sort of realising that we did this all in a bit of a hurry. It was not thought through terribly well, and we realise now that there are, perhaps, a few faults in the scheme that we have brought in'. So Senator Grimes quickly got out of the Town Hall and is coming back to Canberra with his tail between his legs, saying to Cabinet: 'Let us have another look at this assets test, because really the pensioners are getting a bit upset with us, and we thought that the pensioners were friends of ours'.

Perhaps I may deal for just a few minutes with the only promise that was kept by the Government. That was the stopping of the dam. When the dam was stopped, the Prime Minister assured the Tasmanian people working in that area that no one would be disadvantaged. On Monday there was a comment in the Hobart Mercury by a Mr De Jong, an Ulverstone builder. As he said, he had then the contract to supply the Hydro-Electric Commission with prefabricated kitchens, and dining room and sleeping units for the working sites in the South West area. He had that contract. Because the Government decided to stop the dam, he had to sack 17 employees. That is really creating jobs, is it not? He hoped that he was on the short list to supply portable homes in the Crotties area. Actually, he expected a contract of $3m. What would that have done for jobs in the area? We have no idea. Mr De Jong said that it certainly would have been sizable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he have a contract or was he tendering?
—If Senator Tate had been in here, he would have heard, but he has only just come in and he is now asking questions on what I have already said .
—I heard.
—He had a contract earlier.
—He did not have a contract; he had a tender in.
—He had a contract for the kitchens. He said that he hoped to get the contract for the others. If the Senator looks in Hansard tomorrow, he will find what I said.
—You did not say that. You said that he had a contract.

—We shall debate that tomorrow, and I hope that I shall get an apology from the senator tomorrow when he has read Hansard. Mr De Jong is now saying: 'I am asking for help because the Prime Minister said that no one would be disadvantaged'. He has already sacked 17 of his employees, because the Prime Minister has not kept his promise to make sure that that man was able to keep his employees on.
—That is absolutely untruthful.

—So much for the Prime Minister's promise to Tasmania that no one would be disadvantaged. To sum up, in this Budget we have a list of broken promises, and nothing more. The Prime Minister ought to get out his policy speech and examine it. The Australian people ought to go to the various papers and re-read that policy speech made prior to the election, and just see for themselves what promises have been kept and what this man has done. The Australian people will never again be able to rely on the word of Mr Hawke unless he now brings forward some of those promises and decides that the Australian people should not be treated in the way in which he has treated them but that they should be treated fairly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we have been subjected once again to some very negative comments from the Opposition in relation to this year's Budget. Ever since the Hawke Government came to power, conservative senators in this place have knocked every single initiative of the Government, starting, of course, with the highly successful National Economic Summit Conference in April and now with the very responsible and well balanced Budget brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 23 August. This year's Budget is a very crucial and timely one for the people of Australia, in that it represents the end of seven years of the most miserable and destabilising economic policies that this country has ever seen. It is significant in that it represents the end of the Fraser-Howard formula which plunged thousands of Australian families into poverty and despair and which dumped hundreds of thousands of decent Australians on the dole queues. The former Ministers of the now discredited Fraser Government have the audacity to come into this chamber and criticise the Hawke Government over its alleged disregard for elderly people and the unemployed, when they presided over the biggest recession Australia has had and were guilty of neglecting the very people whom they now claim to support.

SPEECH.PARA: This year's Budget has been hailed by most sections of the media and by the business community as moderate and responsible. The conservative Australian Financial Review, which of course tends to be more highly regarded than most of the more sensationalist newspapers, in its coverage of economic issues said of the first Keating Budget:

The first Budget of the new Labor Government, brought down last night by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, is a Budget for recovery. It will provide a substantial stimulus to the economy, in the context of an expected stimulus for world economic recovery.
The Melbourne Age:
The Government has produced a neatly balanced Budget . . . The Budget has combined a reasonable degree of economic responsibility with a fair reordering of social priorities.

Even some of the more extreme right wing journals such as the Australian were at pains to find something wrong with the general approach and strategy behind the first Budget brought down by the new Labor Government. I think what irks the Opposition most of all is the overwhelming support the Budget has received from the business community. While the Opposition was no doubt hoping for unanimous rejection of the Budget by its traditional supporters, it woke up on Wednesday, 24 August, to find nothing but praise from the business sector for the responsible approach adopted by the Government. In an article headed 'Business praises Budget measures' which appeared in the Age on 25 August, David Uren wrote:

Representatives of the banking, life offices and accounting bodies yesterday described the Budget as responsible . . . The chief general manager of Westpac Banking Corporation, Mr Bob White, said the Budget was a generally responsible document. He welcomed the Government's commitment to the recovery of the private sector, by avoiding taxation imposts on companies and he commended the flexible attitude to monetary policy.
Further down in the article reference was made to the chief economist of the Australian Mutual Provident Society, Dr Harold Bell, who said:
. . . the Budget represented a significant expansionary push for the economy while being fiscally responsible.

Another indication of the massive acceptance by the business community of this year's Budget was the reaction on the stock markets. In the Australian Financial Review of 25 August, the headline 'share buyers give salute to Labor' heralded the massive upsurge in share prices immediately following the Budget. In the Age , under the headline 'Stocks soar in response to the Budget', the following appeared:
Investors on Australian stock markets gave the Federal Budget a euphoric reception yesterday, adding about 1,000 million dollars to the value of the market in a heavy buying spree.

Given the magnificent reception the Budget has received from the business community, it is no wonder that the Opposition is becoming frustrated and disillusioned. Given the situation it left the economy in, with an impending Budget deficit of $10.4 billion, the Opposition attacks on the Budget are hollow and unconstructive. Because of the previous Government's almost criminal neglect of the needy and less affluent groups in the community, what we have set about achieving in our first Budget represents, as the Treasurer said, a substantial reordering of priorities. We have aimed to provide the proper setting for sustained economic recovery while at the same time giving special assistance to those people who have been hardest hit by the recession. In this way we have launched an all out attack on the tax evasion industry which has robbed the ordinary working people of this country of thousands of millions of dollars and we have attempted to put an end once and for all to middle class welfare, to ensure that the limited funds that are available go to those in most need. In this regard, the reintroduction of the assets test on pensioners is a genuine attempt to stop the very wealthy in the community from ripping off the system.
Debate interrrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney-General: Is the proposal for a national crimes authority, which the Caucus declined to approve in principle yesterday, along the lines of the Victorian Government's submission to the National Crimes Commission seminar? Does the Attorney-General agree that this is already a much watered down version of the former Government's National Crimes Commission Act? Does the decision yesterday mean that Caucus wants to weaken the proposal even further?

—If Senator Durack can curb his impatience all will be revealed, I hope in another week or two. The Caucus decision yesterday, despite some reports to the contrary, endorsed the basic thrust of the submission that was presented to it. It simply wanted an opportunity to review some aspects of the detail of the proposal. That will occur within the next week or so and I hope that it will be possible, accordingly, to make an announcement which will make very clear what the nature and extent of the Government's proposal is and how useful, valuable and justified it is.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has there been an improvement in the national level of new dwelling commencements in the June quarter this year compared with the corresponding period of 1982? Has the change in the level of housing commencement been uniform among the States? How does the current level of new dwelling commencements in South Australia compare with the position in that State last year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a substantial improvement in the June quarter 1983 over the June quarter 1982 in both commencements and approvals for new dwelling constructions. New dwelling commencements nationally have increased by 3 per cent over that 12 month period. Dwelling approvals have increased by 5 per cent over that period. Senator Maguire also asked whether the increase had been uniform throughout the States. The answer is no, there is a very wide disparity between the level of improvement in some States and the level of improvement in others. In Senator Maguire's State, for example, over the 12 month period to the June quarter 1983 the level of commencements increased by no less than 25 per cent. I think that is the highest of all the States. The level of approvals, likewise, which indicates the commencements at a later time, also increased by 25 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: At the other end of that scale, in Queensland new dwelling commencements in the June quarter 1983 as against the June quarter 1982 actually fell by 13 per cent against the national trend where there is an increase of 3 per cent. New dwelling approvals in Queensland fell in the June quarter relative to the previous June quarter by 12 per cent. It is quite clear that Queensland is retarding the national economic recovery. Queensland has long had the lowest per capita income of any of the States. It has also accumulated over the last decade or so the highest per capita level of debt of all the States. In short, the answer to Senator Maguire's question is that the building industry has shown substantial improvement nationally; it has shown a quite remarkable improvement in South Australia; but in Queensland it remains retarded. In the building industry as in economic activity in general Queensland is retarding the national economic recovery. That is a situation which, given an appropriate verdict on 22 October, should start to turn around some time in 1984.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Attorney-General. I remind him of the clear undertaking given by the Prime Minister in the House of Representatives on 19 May when he answered a question from Mr Anthony. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . at the beginning of 1984, we will be in place, with the proclamation of the Act, for the National Crimes Commission to take over, in the most effective way, the work of the royal commission.

He was referring to the Costigan Royal Commission. Can the Attorney-General say whether the decision of Caucus yesterday on the national crimes authority will jeopardise the firm undertaking given by the Prime Minister in May?

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike the Liberal Party, the Australian Labor Party does not work on the fuhrer principle, where all directions from the top flow down into immediate implementation. There is a process of internal party democracy to go through which has made the Labor Party the great and splendid institution it is today, even if some Ministers may be embarrassed along the way by the said democratic processes. I am sure that those democratic processes when they have fully played themselves out-as I indicated in answer to Senator Durack, they are expected to do so within the next week or so-will prove that the Prime Minister' s statement in May was made with his usual foresight and that early in 1984, if not necessarily on 1 January, an appropriate mechanism will be in place to maintain the continued vigilance over organised and sophisticated crime in this country. Beyond that, I do not propose to indicate any more detail.

—Has the Acting Minister for Health seen recent reports of a survey conducted by the Australian Medical Association from which that organisation draws the questionable conclusion that few doctors will be prepared to bulk bill the Government directly for services rendered after the introduction of Medicare on 1 February 1984? Has the Government been able to make any assessment about the degree to which doctors will be prepared to co- operate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noticed the AMA's survey of doctors' billing intentions under Medicare. I have also noted Dr Thompson's comments on the matter. I must say that I do not regard the results as in any way conclusive or providing any real indication of what will happen after the introduction of Medicare. The AMA, in particular, is very fond of conducting surveys like this and using statistical methods which, if they were used in articles in the Australian Medical Journal for instance, would immediately provoke howls of protest from its own members. This survey was a voluntary one. Given the AMA's well-known antipathy to bulk billing, I am sure, as has happened in the past, that doctors who were inclined to reply were in fact those who feel very strongly against bulk billing. I am sure that the approximately 3,050 respondents out of the 5, 108 or 5,109 who were questioned would be a sample biased against direct billing , not intentionally but because of the nature of the survey and the way it was conducted. In any case, they represent only about 10 per cent of practising doctors in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: There are also contradictions in the results of the survey which cast doubts on its value. It claimed that 76 per cent of doctors favour direct billing for pensioners and other social security beneficiaries. I believe that demonstrates even more the inbuilt bias against direct billing because currently 90 per cent of services for those people are direct billed. The AMA's president, Dr Thompson , says that the average level of bad debts reported was 4.8 per cent. I must say that I wonder whether a survey of tax returns might indicate a higher figure than that being claimed. Still, it is unarguable that direct billing will remove all bad debts. Despite this, by some jump of logic 80 per cent of doctors claimed that direct billing of all patients either would make no difference to bad debts or would increase administrative and overhead costs. I find that an extraordinary result, a result which would not be understood by anyone who has any knowledge of the subject. Looking at those results, I do not think the survey can be said to have proved anything. We as politicians are fond of saying that there is only one poll that counts, and we will see the result of that six or 12 months after the introduction of Medicare, when I am sure, as I know the honourable senator is, that the percentage who bulk bill will be considerably higher than the AMA survey shows.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I quote the statement, which he quite properly quotes back to me when I ask about nuclear deterrence, by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, of 15 September, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the contribution made by the joint defence facilities to the deterrence of nuclear war fully justifies any risk . . . from our having those facilities in Australia.

It is about that risk that I want to ask the Minister, and I ask in the context of the possibility of a Soviet pre-emptive nuclear strike on the United States: Is it this Government's assessment that United States submarines carry up to 5, 000 nuclear warheads ready for immediate dispatch to all parts of the Soviet Union as a response to a Soviet pre-emptive strike? Is not the United States communications base at North West Cape crucial to the accurate deployment of those submarines and their missiles? Is the Government's official view, therefore, that in the case of a Soviet pre-emptive strike North West Cape would first have to be destroyed? Is North West Cape the only risk, in the Government' s view, to which Mr Hayden referred in the 'justifies any risk' phrase of his ANZUS statement of 15 September 1983? If not, what other places, in the Government's view, are at risk?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Chipp for keeping alive, at an appropriate level of seriousness, an exchange between us that was in danger of disintegrating with Senator Mason's question yesterday. In answer to the specific question raised by Senator Chipp, on the information available to me from the Minister for Foreign Affairs I am able to say that, in the Government's assessment, by itself North West Cape is not crucial to the accurate deployment of the submarines and missiles to which he referred. The station is an important element in the United States Navy's communications network. That network is crucial, in turn, to the operation of United States submarines. However, the network includes a high degree of redundancy in order to ensure that United States military communications can continue to operate in time of war. North West Cape thus assists the United States to ensure the survivability of communications to its submarines.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government does not agree that, in the event of a pre-emptive Soviet nuclear strike on the United States, North West Cape would first have to be destroyed. In such a situation the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics would presumably weigh the strategic value of a range of possible targets, including the United States intercontinental ballistic missile force and key command and control centres in the United States and other strategic forces that could be used against it. We cannot know what choices the Soviet Union might make in the highly improbable situation which this question postulates. I remind the honourable senator, however, that North West Cape is only a relay station; it is not a command and control centre.

I am afraid I am not prepared to comment further on the roles of the classified facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar. As such, it becomes more difficult to answer the question as to the risk factor associated with those in the terms in which Senator Chipp has pressed me. As I informed Senator Mason yesterday, the Government doubts that definitive predictions can be made about the targeting practices of the super-powers in the kind of hypothetical circumstances we are talking about in relation to any of these sites. I do not really see that, apart from that further contribution to the debate, much more can be said about the matter from the Government's point of view.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware of serious delays in implementing the community employment program brought about by the Queensland Government's failure to finalise minor details which have already been resolved in other States? Furthermore, is the Minister able to explain, firstly, why the community employment program apparently will operate from either the Premier's Department or Treasury in that State rather than from the Department of Employment and Labour Relations; and secondly, why Queensland projects have not yet been announced as has been the case elsewhere, with the South Australian projects being announced yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware why the program will operate from the Premier's office. I do not know what other choice I was given, but I understood that everything in Queensland operated from the Premier's office, and that may well be the reason. The point of the question was about delays, essentially, in the implementation of the community employment program. I am informed that the Queensland Government agreed to the guidelines and administrative arrangements in respect of the program on 9 August 1983. It was the last State so to agree. South Australia, for example, has approved the first projects under the scheme- 13 projects to cost $1.43m-and Queensland is the last cab off the rank in organising projects under the program. In relation to the State of Queensland, there have been 130 applications to date from potential sponsors of projects and over 1,200 inquiries.

ANSWER.PARA: The Federal Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, advised the State of Queensland on 11 July 1983 of the proposed structure of the consultative committee which is to make recommendations on project approvals. This structure was endorsed in the Commonwealth-State agreement on 9 August 1983 . It is true that on 23 September 1983 the Queensland Premier made nominations to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations for the membership of the consultative committee, but these nominations by the Queensland Premier are not in accordance with the committee structure which was previously agreed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you make a statement at the proper time?

—For example, for Senator Lewis's benefit, the Queensland Premier sought two State Government nominees in lieu of one. He refused to nominate a member of the National Aboriginal Conference as a representative of Aboriginals, and he declined to nominate a youth representative from the Youth Affairs Council of Queensland. That situation has not arisen in any other State. Until a committee is formed in accordance with the agreement it is just not possible to approve projects. I should add that the agreement also made provision for a joint Commonwealth-State secretariat, and the Queensland Government in respect of that matter has proposed arrangements and staffing levels which would not permit the secretariat to function effectively and the program to get off the ground in Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: In the absence of that sort of suitable administrative structure, officers of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations are now undertaking whatever preliminary activities they can with respect to the applications which have already been lodged. I summarise by simply saying that, having originally agreed to the structure, the Queensland Government, for reasons which I suppose can be interpreted only by the people of Queensland, has gone back on the original agreement in relation to that structure and has been responsible for a lot of delays in the implementation of a very worthwhile and important Commonwealth program.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and follows on from the question he has just answered. I ask: Is it a fact that the administration of the community employment program by the State of New South Wales in some respects is outside the guidelines which have been agreed and that this has been a matter of complaint by members of parliament from that State? If that is a fact, has the Commonwealth placed any restriction on the expenditure of moneys by that State or does it merely hold up the supply of moneys to non-Labor States ?

—First of all, with regard to the last part of the question, there is no question of holding up moneys to non-Labor States. If Senator Chaney had listened to the last answer before asking a question which followed on, he might have understood why I dispute the suggestion made in the latter part of his question. Insofar as New South Wales is concerned, there have been some delays as there have in every other State but not of the order--
—Why didn't you tell us about that when referring to Queensland?
—Order! The honourable senator is answering one question.

—Well, I am grateful for the interjection, Mr President. There seems to be a collective view on the other side for once and that is a very healthy sign. Of course, any such program cannot be implemented without differences of opinion and difficulties. All I am saying is that Queensland has not even agreed on the structure at the moment. The Opposition may approve of not agreeing on the structure; the Government does not. Insofar as New South Wales is concerned, of course there have been queries and disagreements amongst members of parliament about the nature of projects which should be funded and so on under the scheme. But if the honourable senator requires any more specific details, I will obtain them from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact, as reported in the Press recently, that abuse of the welfare system is costing Australian taxpayers many millions of dollars a year? Does the Government believe that stringent action needs to be taken and adequate resources need to be provided to catch those cheating on the system? Does he agree--
—Why do you continue to ask such dorothy dix questions?

—It is not a dorothy dixer; it is in my own writing. Does the Minister agree that general support for the welfare payment system in the community generally, and amongst taxpayers in particular, depends on confidence that those receiving benefits truly require them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that the one or two questions that are not dorothy dixers always are accused of being dorothy dixers. Yes, in a social security system which involves the payment of some $13 billion and some 80 million cheques per year there are always some people who will abuse the system just as there are doctors amongst the 25,000-odd doctors, just as there are lawyers and teachers or anyone else who will abuse the system. Of course, if there is an expenditure of up to $14 billion, the cost in terms of abuse may reach some millions of dollars. There is no denying that, nor does that mean that I applaud or agree with that situation.

ANSWER.PARA: The article in the Melbourne Age, to which I believe Senator Tate referred, implied that the Government was indulging in a crackdown or a blitz on such welfare abuse because it intends to increase considerably the penalties for fraud and abuse not only by welfare recipients but also, for instance, by public servants who abuse the privacy provisions of the legislation. However, those penalties will be increased simply because in some cases they have not been increased since 1974 or 1977 and in other cases even since 1947. There was a need to upgrade those penalties in line with changes in money values and in accordance with the nature of offences.

The second part of Senator Tate's question is an important one. If we were to reach a stage where the system was so effective that there was no abuse, that there was no possibility of anyone getting at the system, in fact large numbers of people would be disadvantaged because in such a system large numbers of innocent people would be affected and large numbers of people who are entitled to benefits would not get them. This was demonstrated by the previous Government 's approach of having occasional blitzes in the unemployment beneficiary area and other areas. The result of those blitzes was that large numbers of innocent people were picked up and in some cases some 80 to 90 per cent of people who lost benefits as a result of such episodes were put back on those benefits following an appeal.

What we need is a system which is simple enough to be understood by the clients , which is simple enough that its fairness is understood by the taxpayers who pay for the system and which is simple enough to be administered effectively. There is a great myth that by making a system more complicated, by making it administratively difficult, it is easier for public servants to overcome fraud. The opposite is in fact the case. Those people-those smarties, if you like-who are able to manipulate the system are happier and can operate without detection much more easily in a complicated, administratively difficult system. It is for that reason that we will seek to strike a balance between ensuring that there is the minimum amount of fraud and misappropriation in the system but at the same time ensuring that those people who seek and need assistance, get assistance. We will continue to cast our policies in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Attorney-General, concerns what he spoke of previously as Labor's in-house democracy at work. Is it true, as widely reported in this morning's Press, that one of the main reasons for the Attorney-General's failure to get Caucus approval for the national crimes authority Bill was the opposition of the former Special Minister of State, Mr Young, who, when he was Minister, had joint responsibility with the Attorney-General for this matter? Does he think that Mr Young's reported reason for now opposing such authority, namely 'certain recent events' provides sufficient grounds for the Government as a whole to have second thoughts about the proposal?

—The Australian Labor Party's and my passion for internal party democracy does not extend to sharing the fruits of that passion with members of the National Party or any other party. It is not appropriate that matters of internal discussion and debate of this kind within the Party be canvassed in this forum or any other. I do not propose to answer the question put to me.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs aware that some visitors to Australia, particularly those who are elderly and/or speak little English, fail to understand the full implications of overstaying the term of visitors' visas? Can further measures be taken to improve communication in such cases and thus prevent unnecessary distress for visitors and their families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs that certainly at times some elderly people, like others, do overstay the term of their visitors' visas. I think it is worth while pointing out that all visitors to Australia, including the elderly, sign undertakings overseas printed in their own languages-in languages other than English where appropriate-that they will not seek to remain in Australia beyond the period of the stay authorised on their visa. However, it is obvious that some elderly uneducated visitors may not always understand the significance of what they have signed and , of course, the circumstances of some people change when they are in Australia. If they overstay wittingly or unwittingly in Australia, under the law they become prohibited immigrants.

ANSWER.PARA: Allowance is made to the fullest extent possible for the aged and the circumstances of elderly overstayers located by the Department is taken into account. Elderly people, for instance, are certainly not normally placed in custody but they may be required to report to the Department while their status and situation in Australia are examined. When elderly overstayers come to notice , account is taken of their individual circumstances, whether under normal policy they have any eligibility or claim for further stay or change of status. If they are not eligible to remain or if their status remains unchanged, the person concerned still has the option of leaving the country voluntarily. Certainly, the question of enforced departure of such people would be considered very much as a last resort.

Presumably, when elderly visitors come here to stay with relatives, those relatives should be interested to ensure that the visitors' immigration status remains lawful during the visit. There are provisions whereby people in such circumstances can have their eligibility extended. I believe it is not up to just the elderly visitors, who are often in the sorts of difficulties which Sentor Zakharov implied, but also their relatives in this country to assist by ensuring that the law is obeyed as far as possible in these circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Whilst I agree with the Attorney that he has a right to an opinion that it may not be appropriate to canvass internal party discussions, will he not agree that it is appropriate that he indicate to the public his intention in relation to such important legislation as that for the national crimes authority? Will he give an undertaking that in an attempt to salvage his reputation as a 'professional civil libertarian' he will not agree to changes which will further water down the national crimes authority legislation?

—I have already given an indication of the direction in which the Government is heading insofar as this crimes commission or, as it is to be redesignated, national crimes authority, is concerned. Whether my reputation at the end of the process is greater as a civil libertarian or as an authoritarian will remain a matter for the judgment of Senator Martin and other honourable senators in this chamber.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. On a recent trip to Peterborough, which is in South Australia and not in Queensland, I was reminded of the difficulties facing that town, partly as a consequence of the changes in rail provisions by the Australian National Railways Commission. Some of the changes include reduced services for the supply of food and provisions each week. Other changes are due to the changeover to standard line. As well as the economic criteria for assessment and reassessment of rail services, the Government promised a community impact study, examining the impact on towns of proposed changes, because in the long run the social cost to towns of a major rundown is greater than the more immediate loss of dollars to ANR. Can the Minister say what stage the implementation of such a community impact study has reached and/or whether any such study has been done?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crowley was kind enough to indicate to me that she wished to ask a question with respect to Peterborough in South Australia. I sought some assistance from the Minister for Transport, whom I represent in this place. I am advised that following completion of the Adelaide-Crystal Brook standard gauge link there have been some rearrangements of rail operations, which have resulted in some reduction in the number of staff required at Peterborough. As a result, some positions have been transferred to Adelaide. I understand that freight services to Peterborough are essentially the same as they were before the commencement of the standard gauge services via Port Pirie. Australian National is currently preparing proposals regarding passenger services and the Government will consider those proposals when they are available. Senator Crowley asked me whether there will be a community based impact statement. I give an assurance that that will be done by the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian National Railways Commission is in the process of identifying possible community service obligations from among its total operations. The Government will examine Australian National's proposals when they have been fully developed. I remind the Senate that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, in its report which was published in 1982, recommended that community service obligations be identified and community service impact statements be prepared and that they be funded via separate revenue support. That is consistent with the Government's view and will be taken into consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Attorney-General recommended the early release of any Federal offenders in New South Wales in conjunction with the scheme which was, until recently, operating in that State? If so, which Minister or Ministers of the New South Wales Government sought such action and what were the names and dates of release of the prisoner or prisoners concerned?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.
