TALK.START.PARA: —The only prisoners in New South Wales over whom I have any jurisdiction are, of course, those who are imprisoned in New South Wales as a result of being convicted for Federal offences. The mechanism by which such persons come up for release, whether on parole or after the expiry of their non- parole period, is on the basis of representations made directly to me by the prisoners concerned. They are not in any way filtered through, as far as I am aware, the New South Wales gaol authorities. They are certainly not filtered through the New South Wales Government. I have authorised the release of a number of Federal prisoners on one ground or another but, in the absence of any early release on licence scheme operating at the Commonwealth level, in each case that release has been only within parameters, on the basis of criteria and according to rules which have been laid down and observed by a succession of governments.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the difficult policy questions with which I was grappling until the demise of the New South Wales scheme was whether there ought to be at the Commonwealth level a similar early release scheme in order to ensure comparability of treatment between Commonwealth prisoners in New South Wales gaols and New South Wales prisoners. It was not, I hasten to add, because I wanted a piece of the alleged action; it was only in order to ensure that there was no discrimination in terms of the way in which people in the same practical situation were regarded. If Senator Boswell wants to pursue the matter further in respect of the matters of detail he canvassed in his question, in the light of what I have said, I ask that he put a question on notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Special Minister of State aware that Queensland has the highest disparity between the number of electors enrolled and the number entitled to be enrolled? Is it also a fact that the Queensland State electoral roll has even fewer electors than has the Federal roll for Queensland? To what extent is this situation caused by the lack of a joint roll arrangement? Finally, will the Commonwealth Government again approach the Queensland Government with a view to establishing a joint roll?

—I was not aware of the suggested fact which Senator Ray has brought to my attention about the disparity between enrolments and those entitled to be enrolled, but I am surprised about nothing when it comes to the quality of democracy in the State of Queensland. I know there has been a history of endeavours to create a more effective joint roll system in that State. I certainly indicate on behalf of the Special Minister of State that further approaches will be made to the Queensland Government in this respect, although one could hardly expect them to bear fruit until after the election on 22 October.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FORMER SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE: RELEASE OF CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Did the Government direct counsel for the Commonwealth to submit in his closing address to the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies on 26 September that the former Special Minister of State improperly released confidential information?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a matter of discussion and instruction from the Commonwealth Government to counsel as to the way in which that matter was presented to the Commission, along with all the other basic responses, but I do not believe the newspaper reports of those submissions this morning in any way accurately reflected the character and tenor of the submission that was made; certainly the headlines did not. The submission, in essence, was that any release of information from a Cabinet discussion of the kind that was involved with the meeting of the Committee on National and International Security was almost by definition improper to the extent that it was unauthorised and so much was stating almost a truism. The real substance of the submission of counsel for the Commonwealth-the honourable senator might read the transcript; it is now publicly available-was to say that it was wholly a matter for the Commissioner, Mr Justice Hope, as to the degree of impropriety that he ascribed to the release of the information in question.

ANSWER.PARA: Clearly, there is a very long continuum that one can draw in cases such as this between matters of technical impropriety but comparative triviality and matters of very great impropriety indeed, bordering on criminality. Where the line should be struck on that particular continuum was something that Commonwealth counsel made very clear was a matter for Mr Justice Hope. Indeed, Commonwealth counsel drew His Honour Mr Justice Hope's attention to a number of matters that ought properly to be taken into account in mitigation of the circumstances, at least of the Friday conversation involving Mr Young. I do not retreat in any way from the proposition that this submission was made on the basis of discussion with and formal instructions from the Commonwealth. But the context in which those instructions were given and the character of the way in which they were carried out is a very much more complicated story than the impression the honourable senator has clearly received from this morning's newspaper report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Is the Attorney-General saying that in this, one of the central issues of the Commission's inquiry, counsel was in all respects acting on the Government's instructions?
—The Attorney-General is saying what he has said and no more.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General and concerns the 'adults only' classification given to the film clip of the song Street Kids which effectively prevents its being televised before 8.30 p.m. Is the Attorney aware of claims by the singer and producer that the main purpose of the song is to educate young people about the futility of taking drugs and that all proceeds from the record will go to the Melbourne based Open Family Foundation? What action can the Government take to reverse this rather stupid decision of the Film Censorship Board?

—It has not been my privilege to see or listen to the tape of the song Street Kids so I cannot form any personal judgment as to the merit or otherwise of the action that has been taken in respect of it. What I can say is that the Film Censorship Board is an independent statutory body. It classifies film for broadcast on Australian television, other than that produced under the auspices of a local Australian television station, on behalf of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and in accordance with the Tribunal's program standards. Those standards set out the criteria for classification and the times at which items which have attracted various classifications may be screened. I have no reason to doubt the accuracy of the information which Senator Foreman has given to me about the banning, as it were, before 8.30 p.m. of that particular item. As to what might be able to be done about it, it is not a matter for direct government intervention, given the independent statutory character of the Board and its functions in this area. But it is always open to applicants who are dissatisfied with the classification that they have received to appeal to the Tribunal for a review of the Board's decision. I understand that to date no appeal relating to the clip Street Kids has been lodged with the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, but that course of action is certainly open to the complainants in this matter should they feel that they have a case that can effectively be made out.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON AUSTRALIA'S SECURITY AND INTELLIGENCE AGENCIES

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Since the Hawke Government, through its counsel and after hearing all evidence, has informed the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies that it regards Mr Young's conduct as improper and has invited the Royal Commissioner to form a similar opinion, why has the Government not acted already on its judgment of impropriety and filled Mr Young's former portfolio? Secondly, since a judgment of impropriety on a Minister must in the final analysis be an executive and not a judicial one, does the Government in respect of future incidents intend to make its own decisions or does it intend to set up judicial inquiries into such incidents?

—There is very little I can add to my previous answer. That was the submission, as I indicated, in bald terms, that was made to the Commission. But there are manifestly many shades and degrees of impropriety and I suggest that the particular inferences that Senator Sir John Carrick wishes to draw from this state of affairs depend very much on where along the spectrum or continuum of impropriety the particular conduct in question rests. The Government takes the view that, rather than make any unilateral judgment about that matter, it ought properly, in the interest of fairness, and not least to Mr Young, to await the outcome of the Commission's findings, which will no doubt be directed among other things to that matter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Since the Government was willing to assert before the Commission that it believed that Mr Young's conduct was improper, what was the Government's view of the degree of impropriety? As I understand the situation from the Attorney, it is willing to say that the conduct was improper and willing to say that there are degrees of impropriety but not willing to indicate what in its judgment was the degree of impropriety. I invite him to tell the Senate what is the Government's judgment as to the degree of impropriety.

—As was made clear in my formal opinion given to the Hope Royal Commission on this matter, a number of factors have to be taken into account in determining impropriety. But the most obvious of them in this particular case is the precise factual situation in terms of what actually was communicated on the evening in question about which there is considerable conflict of testimony before the Commission. The Government's view is simply that it, not being armed with almighty powers in these matters, despite some appearances to the contrary, is unable, not to mention unwilling, to make any such judgment on contested or controversial matters of fact. We would prefer- indeed we regard this as the only appropriate course of action to take-to leave those matters of judgment to the Royal Commission.
—My question is also to the Attorney-General.
—Are you asking about Mr Young, too?

—It is good to see that the level of inanity from Senator Walters continues. Has the Attorney-General seen the policy proposal adopted by one of Australia's minority political parties which proposes a constitutional amendment to prevent international agreements affecting any Australian States without the particular State's approval? Can the Attorney-General say what effect such a requirement would have on Australia's standing in the international arena?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports recently that a party that still has the hide to call itself the Liberal Party of Australia has in fact adopted a policy endorsing the proposal that any treaty implementation exercise be the subject in effect of a veto power so far as the States are concerned. This is absolute nonsense for a variety of reasons which I will now endeavour to spell out. Very few treaties allow a country or nation which is a party to them to have the right to apply them only to some parts of its territory. The great majority of treaties require a participating country to accept obligations with respect to the whole of its territory. Therefore, there is no scope for individual Australian States not to accept a great many, perhaps the majority, of existing treaties as a matter of international law. Various proposals have been mentioned which would have the effect of preventing Australia from becoming a party to treaties in the first place unless the States, or a majority of them, gave their consent. This kind of thinking reveals quite basic misconceptions about the nature of international law and about the role of a national government.

ANSWER.PARA: In the first place, to the extent that these proposals seek to limit the Commonwealth's external affairs power, they are quite misconceived. The Commonwealth has power already in respect of a great many subjects, such as defence, international trade and commerce, taxation and immigration, that would enable a great many treaty subjects to be covered by legislation without any reference to the external affairs power. Therefore, it is absolutely nonsensical to talk about preserving the Commmonwealth's power with regard to defence, for example, in that context.

Secondly, talk of so-called traditional State areas is again misconceived. For example, some people might regard education as a traditional State area, but a State law prohibiting, say, Aborigines from attending a university would clearly have a quite profound effect on Australia's international relations. As the Chief Justice of the High Court-the Chief Justice; not just one of the puisne judges down the line-has said, any subject matter may become an external affair if it is treated in a way that involves a relationship with other countries or with persons or things outside Australia.

Thirdly, some people, again in the Opposition parties, seem to have the view that Australia should turn its back on treaties that have been widely accepted elsewhere if giving effect to them would cause inconvenience or difficulty for some States. I suggest that this amounts to, as Senator Bolkus indicated, a policy of isolationism from a world that is becoming increasingly and quite properly concerned about recognising universal values. It would be an extreme form of hypocrisy for Australia to express its support for those universal values while refusing to give effect to them in its own territory.

Finally, if Australia is to accept international treaties there can be no question that the ultimate responsibility for complying with them rests with the Commonwealth. The States are not recognised as having any responsibility as a matter of international law. Only the national Government bears this responsibility and can be called to account by the international community. There is nothing to prevent a State, of course, expressing support for an international principle one year and then denouncing that same principle the next year, perhaps as a result of a change of government. That is exactly what happened in the Tasmanian dam case. It is just not conceivable that any Commonwealth government would be prepared to prejudice its standing in the international community by allowing itself to be subjected to whims and fancies of this kind at the State level. It is a nonsensical policy proposal from a whole variety of viewpoints. I hope that point is well and truly appreciated by people who might otherwise be minded to take this once great Party seriously.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Resources and Energy aware of the numerous reports on the strengthening of the world uranium market? Has he seen the article entitled 'Australia: Uranium Giant Limps on Export Front' in the latest issue of the Bulletin where it is stated that the uranium spot price has risen strongly in the past 12 months, that the long term contract price is believed to average about $US35 per pound and that, for the first time in many years, world demand for uranium will exceed production, indicating that prices will rise higher? Does the Minister still stand by his comments made in March this year that it is economics, not politics, that will prevent uranium development and export for at least the life of the present Parliament and 'the chances of contracts being signed for the minimum export price established by the previous Government-$US35 per pound-are nil at the moment'? Will the Minister now state categorically that if new contracts can be signed above the floor price of $US35 per pound they will be approved by the Government? Finally, will the Government, together with the South Australian Government, reconsider the decision made on what is now proved to be bogus economic grounds to prevent the development of the Honeymoon and Beverley mines in South Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article in glancing through the headlines in today 's Bulletin. I have not read it and I do not know, therefore, what sort of speculation it contains about what whoever wrote that article-I think it was David Haselhurst-believes the potential long term contract price for uranium is or where David Haselhurst obtained that information. I believe the spot price last week was $US24 per pound which, while it is correct that it is up somewhat on the price that prevailed towards the end of last year, is still very much below the general benchmark looked for by the previous Government of just above $US30 per pound. I might add that it was considerably further below the average price presently being obtained by Australian exporters of uranium.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chaney also asked me whether I still maintain that it is economics and not politics which is preventing the expansion of the Australian uranium mining industry. Yes, I believe that that is still the case. The degree of time for which that continues to be correct is a matter of judgment, but I believe it is unquestionably still correct at this time. That view has been confirmed by Total Australia Ltd in a letter to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment written, I think, in April this year. It was, of course, also endorsed by a letter from Queensland Mines Ltd to the Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union of Australia in February this year, although I would not like to be held precisely to those dates.

Senator Chaney asked me also to state whether a contract could be written for supply at some time into the distant future-obviously, if it was from anyone other than an existing producer it would have to be some time into the reasonably distant future-and would I state categorically that that would be approved. The answer is: No, I will not give such a categorical statement because, as Senator Chaney has been told many times here, and I am sure he has also heard it elsewhere, this whole question is the subject for Cabinet consideration scheduled for, I believe, a fortnight hence. In relation to his final comment regarding the Beverley prospect in South Australia, let me say this: If every tin pot uranium deposit in Australia such as Beverley, Honeymoon, Lake Way and a number of others were to be developed, one of the economic consequences of such development would be that the future of Roxby Downs would be threatened, at the very least, and, in all probability, its economic viability throughout the 1990s would be destroyed. Roxby Downs, as I said last week, may be the largest ore body in the world of a number of minerals. That, of itself, does not make it a viable mining proposition. That is a fact which is obviously appreciated by Western Mining Corporation Ltd, which is still conducting its economic feasibility study of the project which is to continue until the end of 1984. I do not want to pass judgment on the economic viability, or otherwise, of Roxby Downs other than to say that it is by no means assured. Given that fact, if the potential to supply uranium which Roxby Downs has was to be pre-empted by the development of every other tin pot uranium prospect in Australia, then the economic viability of Roxby Downs might well be destroyed. If Senator Chaney, the Opposition, the Liberal Party and honourable senators from South Australia like Senator Messner want to destroy the economic viability of Roxby Downs, then let them go ahead and do it. This Government will not do it .

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In light of the last third of the Minister's answer relating to Roxby Downs, is he saying that it is the Government's role to ensure that those projects approved by the Government do succeed economically and that to do that he will exclude competitors from the field?

—The Fox report on the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry recommended sequential development of the Australian uranium mining industry. I am not sure what the response of the then Government to those recommendations was or indeed whether it had a coherent and unified policy at all. As with most other matters, the Liberal Party members squabble among themselves about specific policy matters. Then there is the bigger squabble between the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia on a number of other policy matters with the Liberal Party almost invariably caving in to the flea that infests it. Governments, including the former Government of which Senator Chaney was a member, have made political decisions and arbitrary decisions, call them what you like, to close down certain mining operations. I remember Fraser Island, for example, where the Fraser Government closed down a mining operation that was actually producing and had been for some time. Governments make these decisions from time to time. The previous Government gave permission for the two existing uranium mines to enter into production. It did not approve the establishment of any other mines. Whether governments ought to make those sorts of decisions is ultimately, I believe, a moral or philosophical question. It is not without precedent in Australia for governments of Liberal persuasion, certainly-and probably, although I cannot think off the top of my head, governments of Labor persuasion-to do so.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister representing the Minister for Territories and Local Government. Is the Minister aware that there is considerable and increasing demand from community groups for accommodation and that even now much of this demand cannot be met? Will the Government's community employment program, whilst providing desperately needed jobs to relieve the shocking level of unemployment which the Hawke Government inherited on taking office, be likely to increase the demand for space by community groups benefiting from the program? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether his Department, and also the Department of Territories and Local Government, whose Minister he represents, have taken any action to meet this demand for accommodation by community groups and, if so, what action has been taken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has a clear commitment to the principle of working in conjunction with community-based organisations. There are a considerable number of Commonwealth-owned buildings which have become surplus for a variety of reasons and the Government is of the view that those buildings, properties and assets should be used by approved community organisations. The Commonwealth is firmly of the view that, where such buildings are available or surplus to immediate requirements, they should not be allowed to lie empty but rather should be made available to meet an increasing demand by community-based organisations.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that the Department of Territories and Local Government has to date provided 143 community groups with accommodation in 104 separate Commonwealth-owned locations which were previously either temporarily or permanently unused. A number of other locations are being examined by the Minister and by the Department to determine whether they too may be made available for such purposes. Those currently include the Griffin Centre and the Hackett Primary School. I understand further that the Mort Street vehicle testing station has recently been allocated to a community arts group.

Senator Colston also asked me a question in relation to my own Department. I recently took the initiative, in consultation with the State Government, to make available to a community-based high school two empty buildings which were no longer needed by the Department within the grounds of the Rozelle Hospital, which is a State Government instrumentality. This school, which is providing facilities for certain disadvantaged children who are not provided for in the State public schools system, conducts classes on the basis of genuine progressive educational policies, although it has not yet been accepted as part of the State education system. That school, known as Wawina, has taken possession of those premises.

I think a principle that ought to be followed by all governments is that public assets and facilities should be available to community-based organisations if they are surplus to the requirements of the State or the Commonwealth. I assure the honourable senator that the Government will continue to monitor all Commonwealth buildings to ensure that space is fully utilised, and that, when it is not being utilised by the Government, it is made available to community-based organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday at Question Time Senator Colston asked me a question relating to Commonwealth public servants who are members of the armed services and whether they are granted leave to attend full time training. I am now in a position to provide Senator Colston with an answer to that question. Commonwealth public servants who are members of the Navy, Air Force or Army Reserve are granted leave to attend periods of compulsory full time training. Maximum periods of paid leave which may be granted in a year are as follows, and it is noted that these periods include weekends: Navy, 28 days; Air Force, 32 days; and Army, 34 days. The effect will be that for certain periods of compulsory training Commonwealth public servants would collect pay for their reserve training and would not have their normal salary reduced.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 31 May I responded to a question from Senator Missen concerning the Australian Government's responsibility to its citizens abroad and in particular to those Australians who come into conflict with the laws of another country. Senator Missen's interest in this matter is well known as he has been consistent in seeking clarification about the Government's position in these matters. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has communicated to me that he is a little concerned that from our exchange the impression may have been left that Senator Missen's previous inquiries on these matters have gone unanswered. That is not the case.

QUESTION.PARA: A letter dated 20 April 1982 was sent to the then Foreign Minister by Mr G. Harris, the secretary to the Government members law and government committee, of which Senator Missen was a member. A response was provided by the previous Government in September 1982. I take the opportunity now to table these documents. As I explained in my reply on 31 May, Australian consular officers do their utmost to ensure that their fellow Australians are not discriminated against in their dealings with the laws and judicial processes of another country, but there are limitations to such assistance set both by international law and practice and by the need to be cautious about interfering in the legal processes of another sovereign state. Such interference could result in the opposite effect to that sought.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Sentor RYAN-Yesterday Senator Missen asked a question in several parts concerning the Government's intention with regard to the declaration of the marine park region of the Great Barrier Reef. As the reply I have secured for him is a lengthy one I seek leave of the Senate to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

I draw the Minister's attention to a commitment made by the A.L.P. during the recent Federal election campaign that ''if it attained office, it would immediately declare the entire Great Barrier Reef region as marine park below water mark in the Queensland coast''. In the light of this firm commitment, I ask the Minister:

Firstly-Why has the Government not taken the necessary steps to declare a marine park over the entire area if it has legal control, i.e. from low water mark along the coastline to the outer edge of the region?

Response-When the Government took office in March only 14 per cent of the Great Barrier Reef region was included in the marine park. On 31 August 1983 the proclamation of three further sections of the marine park increased this to 80 per cent or approximately 280,000 sq kms of the region in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. This was achieved through the inclusion of the far nothern area and offshore parts of the central and southern areas of the region in the marine park to add to the previously declared Capricornia, Cairns and Cormorant Pass sections.

In May this year the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment took the necesssary action to declare the balance of the region this year by directing the authority to provide him with reports covering the area of the Great Barrier Reef region south of the Cairns section which was not already the subject of a report. He has received these reports and I understand consideration of these reports will be a major priority on his return from overseas.
Secondly-What negotiations have taken place between the Federal Government and the Queensland Government on the important matter of park boundaries?

Response-At the Great Barrier Reef ministerial council meeting on 3 June attended by the Queensland Premier and the Queensland Minister for Tourism, National Parks, Sport and the Arts, the Council endorsed the reports of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority in respect of the far north, offshore central and offshore southern section of the marine park.
Furthermore, one of the two part-time members of the authority is a Queensland nominee.

Thirdly-When will action be taken by the Government to declare the marine park over the entire Great Barrier Reef region right to the low water mark so as to ensure that the world's largest system of coral reefs is afforded every protection at an early date.

Response-It is the Government's intention to have the entire Great Barrier Reef included in the marine park within a very short time. It is also the Government' s policy that the marine park should extend to the western boundary of the Great Barrier Reef region on the Queensland mainland coast where necessary to protect areas of ecological significance. Accordingly it is likely that almost 99 per cent of the region will be included in the marine park.

Clearly the use of the low water mark as a boundary for the entire length of the Queensland mainland would place unnecessary restrictions on Queensland local authorities and would also unnecessarily involve a Commonwealth agency-the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority-in minor administrative matters which would divert the Authority from its principal task of the care and development of the marine park. It is not our intention that the Authority should become involved in minor administrative activities including supervision of coastal structures, such as jetties and minor waste discharges, which are appropriately at present the responsibility of State and local government authorities, and which are not likely to be of direct or significant relevance to conservation of the Great Barrier Reef.

There are other activities, such as the extraction of sand or gravel from below low water mark close to the shore. The total prohibition of which may not be warranted on ecological grounds. Common sense dictates that this would be an excessive Commonwealth Government restriction on normal State activities.

This Government is seeking to avoid unnecessarily interfering in the responsiblities of the State and local government authorities. However, to dispel any fears that oil drilling could occur in those parts of the region not yet included in the marine park, regulations were made to take effect from 1 September 1983 prohibiting oil drilling in those areas. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act prohibits oil drilling in the marine park.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-On 12 September this year, in an interview for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's AM program to be broadcast the following morning, I drew attention to the massive advertising and lobbying campaign which the tobacco industry was conducting in Western Australia to endeavour to persuade parliamentarians to vote against the Bill to prevent tobacco advertising in that State. During the interview I referred to the fact that there was no provision in Western Australian law for the sources of political party funds to be revealed and that it was very likely that money would find its way from the tobacco industry into political party campaign funds , either with or without the knowledge of the parliamentarians. Throughout the interview I stressed that no illegal act was implied as there is no law in that State to stop contributions to party funds by organisations or individuals who may benefit from subsequent actions in the Parliament by members of that party.

SPEECH.PARA: Three days later, on 15 September, I read an article in the West Australian newspaper indicating that certain members of the Legislative Council of the Western Australian Parliament had censured me for my comments on the ABC's program because I had suggested that MLCs would be subjected to pressure or undue influence to oppose the Bill. The article went on to say that 'there had been an inference that big financial contributions might be made to campaign funds'. According to the report, the Leader of the Opposition in the Council, Mr Medcalf, then said that 'Senator Evans had cast a slanderous slur on the name and reputation of all MLCs'. The same newspaper, several days later, reported that 'the West Australian Opposition was in uproar yesterday over a Liberal politician's reported suspicion that the tobacco industry had used inducements to persuade MPs to oppose the Government's anti-tobacco advertising Bill. Dr Tom Dadour shocked fellow MPs when he told Parliament he wondered about overseas trips, jewellery and money for campaign funds'. He named a former MP-whom I will not name, but it is in the quotation-and said 'you can't tell me he wasn't in the hands of receivers'. That quotation was from a Liberal member of parliament, the same party as the Leader who impugned me.

I wish to make it clear that I did not cast aspersions on individual members of the Western Australian Parliament. The purpose of my original comments was to draw attention to the odium which surrounds all politicians when there is no law to ensure that the public is informed of donations to political parties made by vested interests at the time when legislation concerning those interests is being debated and voted upon by the Parliament. I reject outright the suggestion that I have cast a slur on the Western Australian Parliament or either of its Houses or its individual members. I have a very high personal esteem for most of them and a respect for their integrity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support this motion, Mr President. You will notice that it applies to only two Fridays, those of 7 October and 21 October. I think the Democrats can claim the credit for suggesting this proposition to the Government and to the Opposition. Given the incredibly long schedule of legislation that the Government wants to get through before Christmas, there is no way in the world we could have got through it had we sat only on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays. We suggested that we would have been prepared to sit every Friday on the condition that there be half an hour for Question Time, no matters of public importance or urgency motions or anything other than Government Business.

SPEECH.PARA: The last thing that the Democrats-and I am sure all honourable senators-want is legislation by exhaustion in the last couple of weeks. In particular, we want to avoid what happened in May when the House of Representatives got up two weeks before the Senate when all honourable senators, on this side of the chamber anyway-Liberal and National Party senators, Democrat senators and Senator Harradine-were faced with the prospect: 'If you amend this legislation you will be responsible for bringing back the House of Representatives'. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not proposed to speak to the motion because most of the issues have been canvassed before in the Senate. We are sitting extra hours and we do not particularly want to waste the hours now or on Friday, but there are two points I wish to make. First, I am glad that Senator Chipp has taken the credit-I would say the blame- for the extra days of sitting. But the Opposition is dissatisfied with the general sitting arrangements. These changes are taking place in the context of an examination of possible sitting hours and sitting patterns for next year which we hope might produce something which will be more effective and efficient for the Government and, indeed, for the Opposition. That hope has been expressed often before and has usually been disappointed. I think that we should be trying to get a sitting pattern that is more suitable and sitting hours that are more civilised.

SPEECH.PARA: The other key matter and the point of disagreement between the Opposition and the Australian Democrats is the possibility that the Government should have periods of the parliamentary sitting which are immune or free from private members' normal rights and entitlements. The idea that we should have days of sitting without the opportunity for questioning the Executive Government, the idea that we should have days of sitting on which private members do not have the opportunity to bring forward matters of public importance or motions of urgency is anathema to the Opposition. We believe that the parliamentary institution is not simply the property of the Government. It is the property of the members who are elected to it. We would be very strongly opposed to getting into a practice of having sittings in which the rights of the Opposition and private members as enshrined in the Standing Orders were not available to us. That is what we were elected to do and that is what we are paid to do.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRY BANK OF AUSTRALIA LTD

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1982-83

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In 1977 when primary industry was having many problems, seasonal, price-wise and otherwise, the then Government decided in its wisdom to try to make available money at long terms for people involved in primary industry. Unfortunately at the time-I suppose even now-people seemed to think that there should be cheap money around and that it should be made available to them because of their problems. Unfortunately, as most of us know, there is no such thing as cheap money. But the Primary Industry Bank of Australia Ltd, or PIBA as it has become known, was formed to help the man on the land and those involved in the fishing industry to obtain money with long terms attached to it so that they would be able to service that loan and make their living on the land.

At the time the Bank was set up there was a lot of criticism by spokesmen for primary industry as well as a lot of other people, but I think that the success of PIBA since then is in itself an answer to such criticism. It has been used in spite of that criticism by primary industry leaders and producers. I note that the amount of money lent has increased by $130m in the previous year to approximately $560m this year. That is indicative not only of the fact that it has been successful in the past, but also of the fact that the people involved in primary industry-as I say, that includes the fishing industry, although I would like to see it able to use it more than it is currently-are using it; it is indicative of its success and the fact that it is helping the people involved in primary industry pursuits to stay on the land.

I think that one thing should be noted. When PIBA was formed some of the money that went into its formation and helped fund the initial loans came from income equalisation deposits which were introduced by the then Government. These had a two fold purpose-that of helping the primary producer balance out the peaks and troughs in his income and that of helping thus with his taxation problems. Putting it another way, the primary producer who was having a good season was, in a roundabout way, helping those who were having bad seasons and needed money. It should be noted that, since those days, the present Government, while not quite abandoning income equalisation deposits, has effectively emasculated them and they are no longer serving the purpose for which they were originally brought in. They are basically, more or less, a savings bank institution. They do not help the farmer with his taxation problems in equalling out his income and thus the money that would be available from that source will be less and less over a period.

I congratulate the PIBA Board on its report and on bringing to our notice, in the way in which it has done, the various inventions by notable Australians that have helped primary producers not only in Australia but right around the world. They are indicative of the fact that the primary producer has contributed towards world food supplies in many ways, not only in their basic production but also in the means of production or harvesting. I congratulate them on that little innovation which, I understand, was introduced last year and has continued this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this paper which is without doubt of great interest to the primary producing sectors of the Australian community, but I rise with one particular matter in mind; that is, to draw to the Government's attention the demands that will be made upon this banking institution by grape growers in the years ahead as a result of the introduction of the wine excise in the recent Budget. Last year there was introduced in this place the Auditor-General's efficiency audit in respect of the collection of excise duties and deferred customs duties by the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs. I quote from the Treasurer's statement of 21 September:

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the re-introduction of the excise was to lessen (excise) avoidance possibilities, simplify administration and yield revenue.

I cannot think of any more complicated means of administration, which will certainly lead to less revenue, than this excise brought in by the Government. That argument has not only been proposed by the Treasurer but has also been carried forward by the Australian Financial Review. But there are a number of points that also need to be made. The report's allegations are unsubstantiated by any facts. In fact, they are based on the Auditor-General's assumptions about what might or could happen. There have been no allegations--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I must question the relevance of the matter being raised by Senator Messner to the annual report of the Primary Industry Bank of Australia, which is ostensibly the subject under discussion.
—I think, Senator Messner, that you should explain how your remarks are relevant. You may proceed.

—Yes, Mr Deputy President, I shall make that point very clear. Indeed, extra funds will be required by primary producers in the wine growing industry to pay the extra tax, and they will therefore be calling upon funds available from the Primary Industry Bank.

—There is no doubt about that. They will have significant cash flow problems. There has been no specific investigation by the Auditor-General of allegations. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that I must reply briefly to Senator Messner's remarks. I note with considerable interest that Senator Messner is advocating a sales tax on wine. It is a proposition that I shall pass on to the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I wanted to make a couple of brief comments, too, about Senator Collard's remarks and the financial link between the Primary Industry Bank of Australia, which is ostensibly the subject of this discussion, and income equalisation deposits. He referred to the purpose of those deposits. The purpose, as envisaged by and recommended by the Industries Assistance Commission back in 1975, was to provide a mechanism so that farmers could stabilise their taxable incomes by depositing money in a trust account in years of high income, and withdrawing that money in years of low income. As such, it was a commendable and worthwhile proposition. But within a year that purpose had been subverted-indeed, turned on its head-by subsequent amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act, as a result of which those farmers who stabilised their income by paying into the trust account in years of high income and securing a deduction from taxable income for those payments, and withdrawing in years of low income, as it was envisaged they would do when the proposal was first raised by the IAC and first enacted by the previous Government, found that after the 1978 Budget those who used IEDs in that way paid more tax than they would have paid had they not used IEDs at all. The IEDs, as they existed under the previous Government for four and a half years, imposed a tax penalty on farmers who used them to stabilise their taxable income and provided an incentive to farmers who destabilised their taxable incomes through the use of income equalisation deposits. That incredible anomaly continued until the Liberal Government was finally removed from office. It was corrected within, I think, three months by the present Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —After discussion with Senator Chaney it was agreed that prior to the debate on this report resuming I should make a statement on behalf of the Government which I now do. The Government considers that the prescribed payments system is a fundamentally sound system. However, it accepts that, in the light of experience , there is a need to refine certain of its administrative aspects so as to reduce paper work burdens on some taxpayers and to facilitate taxpayer compliance with its requirements. To this end, the Government has decided to introduce legislation to amend the income tax law along the lines proposed in the report tabled in the Senate yesterday by the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. In reaching this decision, the Government was satisfied that the changes proposed would not put at risk the anti-evasion objectives of the system.

SPEECH.PARA: Taxpayers who, as payees, have been granted exemption from source deductions on the grounds of a good compliance record are to be taken out of the system in relation to prescribed payments they receive, provided that an appropriate declaration as to the holding of an exemption certificate is lodged with each payer once a year. For such payees with large numbers of different payers, it is proposed that the Commissioner of Taxation will, on application from a payee, be able to approve special arrangements under which quotation of an exemption certificate number on an invoice or statement would be acceptable as an alternative to the declaration. These changes will result in a very significant reduction in the paper work burdens on the exempt payees concerned and also on the payers with whom they deal.

Modifications are to be made to the provisions under which a payee may submit his duly completed part of the monthly deduction form no earlier than seven days before the commencement of the month in which a payment is due. Specifically, the changes to be made in this area are as follows:
The seven-day requirement is to be extended so that a payee may lodge a deduction form at any time in the month preceding the month of payment;

where a deduction form is properly lodged by a payee, it will remain valid until the month in which payment, or a first instalment of it, is made and where a part payment is made, the payer will be required to generate deduction forms in respect of subsequent instalments; and

where a payer gives a payee notice in writing that the payer will produce fully completed deduction forms on a monthly basis, the present requirement that the payee partially complete the form will be deemed to be met if the payee lodges with the payer one completed form to cover all prescribed payments from that payer in a year of income, unless the payee's circumstances change before the end of the particular year in which case a further form will be required to cover payments for the remainder of the year.

These modifications will ensure that affected taxpayers can more readily accommodate the requirements of the system into their business operations. The changes to allow payers, at their convenience, to complete both parts of deduction forms will certainly be welcomed by those payers who operate computer based business systems.

In addition to the above changes which were recommended by the Senate Committee , a minor amendment will be made to the provisional tax self-assessment provisions to simplify the calculations which a taxpayer who wishes to vary a provisional tax liability on account of prescribed payment income is required to make. The present requirement to identify estimated taxable, that is net, income , being prescribed payments, including such payments from which deductions have been, or will be, made, is to be altered to require the taxpayer to identify gross prescribed payment income from which deductions have been, or will be, made. These amendments clearly evidence the Government's willingness to refine the system to meet valid concerns about its operation. Amending legislation to give effect to these proposals will be introduced as soon as possible. The amendments will have effect from the date the legislation receives royal assent. The requirements of the law as presently enacted will remain in force until that time.

I take this opportunity to thank the Senate Committee for its valuable work in preparing the report. The Committee's recommendations are sound and workable. I am particularly pleased that this Committee, comprising representatives of the Liberal Party, the Australian Democrats and the Government, unanimously recommends the regulations for the system be not disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. A number of things ought to be observed about it. Firstly, I think the Government needs to be thanked for such a ready response to the Committee's recommendations. After all, the report was put down only yesterday. The Government has responded to it today and has not only picked up the recommendations of the Committee but also added to them. I think that ought to go, if not into the Guinness Book of Records, into the next edition of Odgers if and when it is ever printed. That aside, I make a number of brief observations. Firstly, it needs to be remembered by everybody that these amendments most probably would not have come about if the Opposition had not, some weeks back, first contemplated disallowing the regulations and then moved to have them looked at by the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. The Senate ought to be thanked also for allowing the Committee to meet on sitting days. Under the chairmanship of Senator Coates the Committee worked well and fast.

SPEECH.PARA: What came out very quickly was the problems we have with all tax laws in Australia. The Australian Taxation Office generally has a game law mentality and always goes for the overkill. It is quite obvious that all taxation laws in Australia are totally designed for the convenience of the Taxation Office and nobody gives a damn about the individual taxpayer who must put up with the administration of the Taxation Office. The whole system was designed to suit the convenience of the Taxation Office. Nobody cared overmuch about the convenience of the taxpayer. That is an unfortunate attitude that has crept into this Parliament, in all parties, for far too long. We tend to forget that our constituents basically are the taxpayers of Australia. When we look at tax legislation in the future I trust that Parliament will cast a harsher eye over whether it is merely for the convenience of the Taxation Office to collect what has become almost sacred revenue and consider how much we will inconvenience our constituents who are the taxpayers. It became very evident within the inquiry that taxpayers were being unduly inconvenienced with paperwork. One could perhaps be slightly cynical and say that one of the reasons for such an immediate response to our report was that the Government is sensitive about the fact that this particular tax has an enormous capacity to enrage taxpayers who will take out their rage and anger through the ballot box at the next election.

There are some other matters within the report to which I allude. One, of course, is the rulings of the Commissioner of Taxation. I realise that those rulings are but internal administrative arrangements which have now been exposed to vulgar public gaze due to the Freedom of Information Act but I am still somewhat surprised that the Commissioner believes he can interpret the law contrary to most legal opinion in Australia. I think it is a dangerous trend amongst administrators of the law that they believe they can put interpretations on an Act of Parliament which suit the administration of the law rather than make certain that the law is properly and thoroughly complied with. I think it is a dangerous trait in administrators and it ought to be stamped out by Parliament.

The Income Tax Assessment Amendment Act, as the Committee's work has discovered , is a very interesting illustration of the fact that whilst people may occasionally fulminate about legislation in this place, very little true scrutiny is given to its contents. Those honourable senators who for years have put forward the proposition that all legislation ought to be referred automatically to Senate standing committees for thorough investigation and report before passing the Committee stage will take comfort from the fact that the Act slipped through Parliament with none of these things being discovered by the legislators. This Act stands as a monument to the indifference which allows legislation to slip through Parliament. While we are arguing about all sorts of other things we do not bend our minds to what we are properly elected to the Senate to do in the first place.

The last thing I should like to say is that I now regret, as a result of some of the things said this afternoon, that we did not keep the Committee going and press to see how much the present mail strike in Canberra has delayed the receipt of all these payments. One wonders how many people have applied for tax file numbers and have not been able to get them in Canberra due to the fact that they cannot get them through the mail. One wonders how much the mail strike is affecting the Commissioner of Taxation's revenue collections. One wonders whether there is bogged down in the mail house some hundreds of millions of dollars and whether or not the postal union involved should not have to pay interest on it because the Commissioner has not been able to receive that sacred revenue into his coffers. It is just as bad, I suggest, as people indulging in evasion and avoidance schemes to deprive the Commissioner of revenue. We all believe that is wrong, but there seems to be nothing wrong with industrial disputes holding up the gathering and collection of that revenue. Maybe it is high time the taxation legislation was amended to provide that, where the Commissioner is deprived of his revenue arriving on the proper date due to industrial action, then he ought to be able to assess on all the members of that industrial group a penalty equivalent to 10 per cent of the taxation he has not received. I think this would be a very interesting way of curing a lot of industrial disputes.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would include the employers as well; both sides?

—Yes, whoever causes the industrial dispute. They ought to be paying the tax. I do not see why the taxpayers should be hammered for not paying their tax on time when on occasions through industrial disputation the Commissioner does not get his tax on time.

SPEECH.PARA: I know a number of members of the Committee wish to speak on this, so I will conclude my remarks by saying again that we ought to be far more careful in this place about passing legislation which turns out to be an administrative nightmare for our constituent taxpayers. It is a very good lesson for us all. I think the operation of this Committee was a very good example of how a committee can operate under some pressure and get back to report to the Senate in quick time. I must congratulate the Government on acceding to the recommendations of the Committee. We look forward to the legislation coming at the earliest possible time, but I still ask those taxpayers outside, those 350,000 people ranging from Croatian bricklayers to ethnic truck drivers and all the rest of them, each time they fill in one of these forms to remember that it was Prime Minister Hawke who brought in this legislation. Every time they fill in a form, they should remember to keep him in mind when next they go to vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is obvious that Senator Withers has linked this taxation report by the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations with the mail strike because he has not yet got his tax refund cheque and is somewhat needled by that. I also suggest, in relation to his plea to the 350,000 people, that they can be equally assured that the Liberal Government would have introduced similar legislation with similar provisions.
—What rubbish!

—It had already announced it in Press releases, if the honourable senator would care to go back and have a look at it. I do agree with Senator Withers that the inquiry was a valuable exercise. It is surprising that a Senate committee can have a matter referred to it for the most crass and politically opportunistic reasons and yet eventually come out at the other end with a fairly objective report, a well balanced report, and a report that actually goes to the issues rather than the rhetoric. That is what this report has done, thanks to the co-operation of all members of the Committee. It addresses the problems rather than trying to capitalise politically on one point or another.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that the information the Committee obtained from the Australian Taxation Office went a long way to relieving the anxieties of the various industry groups. Much of the information that came out at the Committee hearings was new and went a long way to saying to those industry groups that some of the problems they imagine they have are just non-existent. In general, submissions made to the Committee by industry were made not on the basis that they opposed the withholding tax, or the deduction at source tax, but on the basis that they believed there were administrative problems. It was always hard to work out whether they were using the Trojan horse method and using the administrative difficulties to express their objection to the tax. On the whole, for the record and under oath, the industry groups said that they supported this tax.

As indicated earlier, overall the prescribed payments at source taxation will affect some 350,000 people in Australia. I think we should go back to look at why it was necessary to introduce it in the first place. One has to put that in the context of some of the problems that have occurred. The reason, as stated by the Australian Taxation Office, relates to the compliance rate. The compliance rate, in dollar terms, is such that only $55 out of every $100 that should be paid in tax is being paid. It is estimated that, with this new withholding tax coming into operation, compliance will go into the high eighties. We will never get all of it but at least we will move from $55 into the high eighties. I do not think any government, Liberal or Labor, could have just stood aside and allowed the existing system to continue.

There are already indications that this system is working. We need go no further for evidence of that than the number of people who have applied for a tax file number, notwithstanding postal strikes or anything else. Normally 10 per cent is deducted, but if a person does not have a tax file number 25 per cent is deducted, a fairly large whack. In the period for which we have evidence , September 1 to 19, in Sydney alone there were 4,681 applications for new file numbers, and Australia-wide the figure was 16,355. Of those, at least 25 per cent have not lodged income tax returns. I think it has been a fairly effective way of forcing people into paying the tax that they owe, and no doubt the Government will derive quite a good deal of back tax from it. It is also surprising that a large percentage of people who have applied for a file number have just recently arrived in the country. We can conclude from that only that Air New Zealand had an absolutely bumper month in August, with the number of people who arrived on flight 2 and suddenly had to apply for a file number.

We must acknowledge, though, that initially there were administrative problems with the scheme and that many of the letters we received, exhibiting all sorts of frustration, were justified. For a start, insufficient information was available or known by people affected. In spite of the fact that industry groups and the Taxation Office had participated in seminars, and in spite of all their best efforts to disseminate information, only a small percentage of the 350,000- odd people to whom the information should have gone actually understood the scheme. Initially there was some problem, but only very briefly, about the availability of forms. There has always been the problem of administrative costs , but I suggest, respectfully, that the industry should not complain about administrative costs when the compliance rate for paying taxation is so low. It is just part of the burden they carry because of the fact that their industry is not paying its fair share of tax. We also had problems with the compatibility of computer systems. Nearly all those problems were in the process of being ironed out before the Senate Committee was set up. The Taxation Office is not totally insensitive to requests from different industry groups. It may well have been that the pressure of Government and the possibility of a Senate committee did advance its co-operation in terms of implementing this scheme.

I think we also have to look now at just how well the Taxation Office has done on this issue. The Committee was set up prior to 1 September, when the scheme was to be implemented, and all sorts of accusations were going around. One accusation was: 'Look, no one will be able to get an exemption certificate or only a few hundred will be able to get them and applications for variation of payment will be just impossible to be made'. But I think we should look at the figures. In the period 12 August to 26 September the Tax Office received 21,598 applications for exemption certificates of which it processed 21,032. It granted certificates to 92.37 per cent of applicants and refused some 7 per cent. As at 26 September, only 129 applications were awaiting further information and a further 566 had not been processed. It is not a bad effort in six weeks to process over 21,000 applications for exemption.

The figures for variation certificates are even larger. The Tax Office received 64,001 applications for this purpose in the period 12 August to 26 September. It processed 62,988 applications, 97.48 per cent of which were granted and only 1.9 per cent of which were refused. Only 372 applications are awaiting further information and only 1,013 have not been processed. So in all, some 1,385 applications out of 64,001 have not been dealt with to a point of conclusion. I think that Senator Withers was in some ways critical of the Tax Office and its methods. But one has to acknowledge that the Tax Office has made a magnificent effort to process that many applications in that period.

I would like to refer to the conclusions and the recommendations of the report. There is no doubt that the system set up by the Tax Office is administratively too complex and requires too much paper work. I, like Senator Withers, was very pleased to hear the Government respond that it would amend the Act to make it administratively much easier to process applications and to reduce the amount of paper work. I am sure that that will have the required effect. I am sure that this method of collecting tax will add to the general amount of money being collected by governments and lessen the burden on other sections of society. There is no excuse for some industries to have a compliance rate of $55 in every $100 when the pay as you earn taxpayer has a compliance rate of $100 out of $100 .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to share in passing around the compliments this afternoon. First of all I think that a compliment is due to Her Majesty's Opposition. I think that the Liberal Party of Australia deserves credit for recognising that by having this matter referrred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, the legislation could be improved and ameliorated and some of the effects on a lot of industries that were caught up in a sudden blitzkrieg of attacks could be lessened. I also pass on my compliments and congratulations to the Government for literally adopting the report of the Committee and ensuring that the recommendations will be put into legislation in the very near future because the Committee did discover that there were some problems associated with the way in which the new tax was introduced, the way in which it was implemented and the way in which it was being administered.

SPEECH.PARA: I also would like to express my personal appreciation to the members of the Committee, to Senator Coates, the Chairman of the Committee and to Senator Robert Ray, the Deputy Chairman during the short absence of Senator Coates, for the way in which the inquiry was conducted. The inquiry may not have been unique , but I have not heard of an inquiry at which a Commissioner of Taxation has been given the opportunity to have dialogue with those who were most concerned and most upset with the situation which had developed as a result of the introduction of a tax. I think that the almost direct dialogue that took place during the inquiry, the give and take and a little of the parry and thrust which we witnessed were good in that some of the concern was lessened when assurances were given by the Comissioner and his senior officers. This approach also cleared the lines and enlightened many representatives of industry groups who had misconceptions about the Income Tax Regulations (Amendment) Bill 1983 and its likely impact on their industries. Of course, much of that concern was brought about by rather poor communications I suspect on the part of the Government but in the main on the part of those people who were out to make mischief by misrepresenting both the intent and the effects of the Bill.

The Australian Democrats support the thrust of this report. We believe that the Government's attitude in adopting interim measures while the Commitee was sitting was a helpful approach to a lot of people who were in potential difficulties. For instance, it was not known whether a proposal put by the Australian Democrats, and I am sure by others, for provisional exemptions would bring relief to a few, a few hundred or a few thousand taxpayers. But in the event, 24,500 potential taxpayers took relief from those provisional exemption arrangements. I am sure that this took a lot of steam out of the matter as far as the administration in the Australian Taxation Office was concerned because it allowed this legislation to settle down a little more easily and a little more smoothly.

I must confess that I still have some reservations and I do not in any way deviate from my 100 per cent support of the report itself. My reservations relate to the potential, prospective difficulties which have not yet been taken on board. I think that the Taxation Commissioner has lessened the impact on some companies by arranging for some assistance to make the system more computer compatible. But I believe that a tremendous amount of additional work needs to be done in this area. Hopefully this work will be carried out before the next review of this tax is undertaken by the Finance and Government Operations Committee. I am pleased that there is to be a further review because I sense that even now and even following the Government's agreement to make alterations to the legislation there will be difficulties. Those difficulties have been brought to my attention not so much by industry group representatives but by individual companies with individual problems which are not large enough to be taken up by industry groups but which are important to each of those companies. I hope that a great deal of compassion will be shown by the Commissioner of Taxation in helping to resolve and lessen those problems. Certainly, the Government's attitude seems to be that it wants to help those who have had quite serious impositions made on their time, on the cost of running their businesses and in some cases on the viability of their businesses.

In my final comment, I would like to put this proposal to the Government: I believe that as the Government makes its decision to expand this tax into other industries, it needs to do more work and needs to ensure that the Taxation Office does more work out in the market-place. I think that the biggest shock I received during the hearings of the Committee was the response from the Taxation Office that although it had conducted a pretty thorough research into its capability to administer this legislation if had done absolutely nothing in terms of the effect that this legislaion would have out in the market-place. I put it to the Government that before it expands this legislation to include other industries-the Government might like to take the suggestion on board for other areas of tax; I will refer later to the sales tax area-and creates havoc in the market-place it should in effect introduce an environmental impact statement. I distinguish between the environment as we nearly always refer to it -that which is out there in the wilderness-and, in this case, the environment which is the market-place, the businesses in this country. That environment was very seriously upset and violated as a result of this legislation.

I think that an environmental impact statement of that kind would be beneficial not just to the businesses concerned but to the Government itself and to the confidence of the people in this Government. I ask that such a statement be prepared before the Government goes ahead and bulldozes legislation of this type out into the world at large, without having any idea of its potential impact. With those few words of, I hope, helpful advice I close by again complimenting the Government on its rapid response. I hope that it is able, as a result of the new legislation, to overcome the difficulties that were inherent in the original legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add a few brief comments to those of the other members of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations who have spoken this afternoon. I was interested to see the Government's response to the recommendations in the Committee's report. I think it will be agreed that their implementation will improve what is a complex administrative procedure. I hope that the amending legislation will come forward quickly from the Government so that it may have an early passage and improve the existing legislation as soon as possible. I noted further that the Government had accepted an amendment with regard to provisional tax self-assessment. Again, I think this will be an improvement for those who are affected by the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: It was of interest to hear the figures cited by Senator Robert Ray with regard to the number of exemptions that have been granted and the number of variation certificates that have been approved. I felt at the time of the Committee's hearing that the exemption certificates were made more difficult to obtain by the form that is required to be completed before a person can be considered for an exemption. It seems to me that the compliance that is required by the Commissioner of Taxation under the legislation in providing information on the sources and application of funds has deterred some people from applying for an exemption certificate. It may be that, after experiencing the system, they will be led to provide the additional information which the Commissioner requires. It is of some interest to me that the information that is required by the Commissioner to grant an exemption certificate is information that goes beyond what is required to be provided by a taxpayer when lodging his income tax return . I think that the degree of information that is required and the manner sometimes of collecting that information in time to apply for an exemption certificate have been somewhat of a deterrent, to the extent that some 21,000 exemption certificates only have been approved and, in addition, 64,000-odd variation certificates have been dealt with. Something over 300,000 people are to be affected by this legislation. That figure perhaps puts into perspective the number of people who are still dealing in absolute terms with the provisions and with the administration that is required within their own organisations and by the Australian Taxation Office to collect this withholding tax.

The Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in his letter of 15 September made suggestions that were of considerable interest to the Committee. The Committee was interested to read and to hear from him that he believed, as an administrator, that the system was basically sound. The Committee was also influenced when he told us that there had been a marked decline in the number of inquiries that he was receiving at that time. I think that the number of earlier inquiries had led many of us to think that there must be some grave difficulty besetting people who were to be affected by it. I think that the establishment of the Senate Committee gave an opportunity to those national organisations and, if they wished, individuals to come before the Committee to put their points of view. That opportunity was taken advantage of by many national organisations. As has been said earlier, access to the Commissioner, the Deputy Commissioner and the senior officers of the Taxation Office meant that information was able to be provided at that time. As a Senate committee, we did look at the statutory rules , but we found that the detail within the Income Tax Assessment Act meant that alterations were required to the Act. The Government will need to introduce legislation to deal with the recommendations in the Senate Committee report.

I add my thanks to the staff of the Committee who assisted us, the Chairman and other members of the Committee. I thank also those officers from the Taxation Office and those individuals and representatives of organisations from outside who put before us the information that was required to lead to the recommendations that were agreed to by the Government. It dealt quickly with the Senate report. I think that the exercise that was embarked upon, with the requirement by the Senate to report in the first week of October, was one that imposed some strain on our Committee staff and on others who needed to deal with the Committee's work. I think it is important to know that perhaps next September there will be an opportunity for another report to be presented by this Committee if at that time any information needs to be brought before the Government or if people who are affected by the legislation need to advise us, by way of either a public or a private hearing, of matters that they feel ought to be raised after the introduction of a new tax collection system. Undoubtedly people will need to become accustomed to something that is new. The system will need to be administered by the Taxation Office and dealt with by companies and individuals. I hope that when we reach September of next year the Committee will be able to report that the work that it has done, which has resulted in these recommendations, has simplified the administration of the system and that perhaps by that time the system itself will not need a further series of recommendations from the Senate Standing Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I wish to thank those who have contributed to this debate. I add my thanks to the Cabinet for its prompt decision this morning to adopt the recommendations contained in the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. In so doing, I point out that the Government all along had said that it would keep an eye on the implementation of the scheme and would react, as necessary, to problems which arose. It is not a question of the Government caving in, but rather a question of its complying with its original commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 September 1983, on motion by Senator McIntosh:
That the Senate take note of the paper.
Upon which Senator Scott had moved by way of amendment:
Add to the motion that the Senate take note of the report the following words:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this subject last arose I had barely started my comments when the debate was adjourned, so I will briefly recapitulate the points I made on that occasion. Regardless of the views of any parliamentary committee, certain salient facts remain concerning the situation in East Timor, and they will remain facts regardless of all attempts to deny or conceal them. It is for this reason that community uneasiness about East Timor continues to grow in Australia. In fact, I would put it more strongly; I would say that community concern about Australian betrayal of East Timor continues to become a major issue in Australia. It is for that reason that those of us in this Parliament who have taken the trouble to study the East Timor issue with some care will not accept any attempt to smother the issue. It is not good enough that the entire population of a small neighbouring country should be given over to the untender mercies of one of its larger neighbours, which in this case is Indonesia.
