It is not good enough that between 100,000 and 200,000 Timorese have died as a result of the eight-year unsuccessful campaign by the Indonesian generals to force their act of conquest on the East Timorese. I deliberately said the Indonesian generals because I believe it is not the people and not the Government of Indonesia which have been responsible for this situation but a small number of extremist elements who seem to have undue influence over the Indonesian Government from time to time and who instigated the East Timor adventure in 1975. Of course, the basic salient fact is that Indonesia did not have, does not have and never will have any ethnic, historic or cultural right to East Timor.

SPEECH.PARA: As in the parallel case of Papua New Guinea, western sections of Timor were once part of the former Dutch East Indies, and the Indonesian Government had a claim to these as a successor state. But the move into East Timor, the eastern part of the island, was a naked act of aggression designed solely to annex the territory of a people who should be independent or who at least should be given the chance to decide their own future by an open internationally supervised democratic act. The parallel with Papua New Guinea is a significant one. If Indonesia thought it did not like the political complexion of a new government in Papua New Guinea at some future time, or even thought a government might emerge which it might not like, the military adventurists-that group of generals , mostly of Javanese origin-could well feel it worth while moving to annex Papua New Guinea if and when they thought the opportunity arose and the time was ripe. Appeasement by Australia and acceptance of the East Timor conquest must surely make this all the more likely. Our reasonable and prudent response ought to be to make it quite clear to Indonesia that, while she is a friend, she is a friend of whose activities in East Timor we cannot approve.

It is worth noting, without giving undue accent to it, that the fifteenth century pre-colonial Javanese empire of Majapahit was believed by many Indonesians to include Papua New Guinea. When Sukarno discussed a future Indonesian state with the Japanese in the closing week of World War II, the Indonesian nationalists considered that the new Indonesian republic should include what was then believed to be the territory of Majapahit, and that included the territory of Papua New Guinea. Majapahit is still regarded by the Javanese as a most important part of their ethos. The mere fact that the only record of it is a poem by a court historian Prapanca which is very vague does not alter the situation that there is that basic motivation that might justify an attack at some time on Papua New Guinea. It appeals especially, of course, to the Javanese generals who we know to be so influential. One of those ex-Javanese generals is, of course, now President Suharto.

I talked recently with two representatives of Fretilin, Mr Araujo and Mr Rodriguez, who visited Australia and only yesterday with Monsignor Lopez, the former Catholic bishop in East Timor. It is significant that 43 per cent of the Timorese are Catholics. All these people who ought to know what they are talking about are emphatic that the East Timorese not only want to decide their own future but also that the country could have a viable future as an independent state. I believe that to be most important. There are plenty of small Pacific states with fewer resources which are now independent with our blessing. Why not East Timor? Instead of that constructive approach, a fresh assault is being made now by the Indonesian Army against the people of East Timor-not, it was stressed to me by my informants, the Fretilin fighters, but against the men, women and children in the villages of East Timor. The killings and sufferings are continuing. I am told that there is no way that they will stop and that only a final act of genocide could alter that in the end.

I have heard honourable senators pontificating at length in this place about the evils of the Russian invasion of Afghanistan. I agree with their feelings about Afghanistan. But the invasion of Afghanistan was a very similar scenario to the Indonesian invasion of East Timor-basically a military conquest of a smaller neighbour. I find it appalling that the same people seem to accept the sufferings of the East Timorese with equanimity and a Judas-like concurrence. As far as I know, Australia owes the Afghans no special debt. But we do have a special debt of honour to the Timorese, many thousands of whom were killed by the Japanese during World War II because they had helped Australian troops to escape from the island. These are the people that we are betraying. Those people who rationalise this situation would perhaps say to me: 'Be realistic; this is the world power game in action; we must not rock the boat. Regrettably it is now the kind of world in which such things happen'.

I would like briefly to examine that position. The first point to be made is that we are not helping the people of the nation of Indonesia by our policy of appeasement. We are not helping those who are struggling for a return to democracy. All we are going is helping a small group of military tyrants to maintain their tyranny over a vast nation which does not want them. Why are we doing this? Why does our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) subscribe to this quite monstrous situation in a small friendly neighbouring country? Is he being heavily persuaded by the United States of America not to rock the boat? That seems to me to be a possible motivation because there is no doubt in my mind that both Australia and the United States gave Indonesia the nod to invade East Timor in 1975. If that is so-if we are being influenced in that way-our attitudes are pitiably and dangerously weak.

We have seen three decades in which the propping up by Washington of a series of military tyrants in Asia has seen nation after nation become communist. Those who supported Chiang Kai-shek and Ngo Dinh Diem and who still support tyrants like Marcos in the Philippines have done more to further the advance of communism in Asia than anyone else. Those so-called conservatives are the true friends and allies of the communists. One has only to look back in history to see how successful their efforts have been to deliver large areas of Asia into the hands of communism in the last three decades. That can be laid directly at the door of those people. We should come out plainly-it is time somebody did-and say to the United States: 'We are sick of your hyprocrisy. You pretend to be one of the world's leading democracies and then you meddle around the world to establish and perpetuate a series of military tyrannies which are imposing and maintaining their rule through one of the most sickening inventories of murder and torture of innocent people the world has seen since Hitler.' That is the truth of the matter.

There are now few places in Latin America and Asia-the United States zone of influence one might say-where any genuine spark of democracy remains. There is virtual tyranny everywhere. Of course, these regimes are actively supported, financed and provided with arms by that most sinister of organisations in the United States, the Central Intelligence Agency, which hides some preposterous illegal activities behind a veil of secrecy in the so-called interests of security. This is something we can and do accept too easily. The fact is that the CIA's record is not one of any kind of success in establishing the influence of and preservation of democracy in the world but one of a repeated series of failures. Such oppression and secret crime never work in the long run.

East Timor is our neighbour to whom we owe a debt of conscience in many respects. It is the right place for us to start. We must continue to use all the diplomatic means at our disposal to see that a genuine act of self determination occurs as soon as possible in East Timor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take the opportunity to speak for a few minutes on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on the Human Rights and Conditions of the People of East Timor. It is one of two reports on East Timor which are currently being discussed by the Senate. I think both reports contain a great deal of value for the Senate and for the people of Australia because they increase our knowledge of the situation . Because there have been minority reports in both cases, there has been a tendency to indicate that one must favour one and not the other. But it seems to me that there are useful determinations in the recommendations of both committees. The report particularly before us today follows a long examination by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. It is appropriate that that Committee should have considered the situation in East Timor because it has undoubtedly been a running sore in this country for many years. I can at least say that I have consistently taken great interest in and had great concern for the people in East Timor and the people from Timor who have come to Australia and want to resume associations with their families who have been delayed for many years in Timor. I am pleased to see that most of those people have now come here and been reconciled with their families.

SPEECH.PARA: I trust that I am being realistic about this subject when I say that I recognise the great difficulties which occured after Timor was taken over by force, and of course without any right in law, by Indonesia. I say also that in the majority report before us-I hope that many people will read that report- there are interesting statements which acknowledge that there have been considerable developments and improvements in the economic situation in Timor in recent years. On the other hand, there is clearly a great antagonism felt by many people in East Timor to the ruling regime which is maintained there by force.

I do not accept that there has ever been anything like an act of determination by the Timorese people to be absorbed into Indonesia. I am not saying that it is probable now that that situation will be reversed. I think it would be unrealistic to think that. But I do not think that that absolves Australia from its obligations. Australia has had long obligations going back to the war period when the Timorese people did a lot to help Australian servicemen who were serving, under great difficulties, in Timor. I believe that we should continue with our obligations to those people.

The records of Australian governments since then have not been good. The records of Australian governments, not only in regard to East Timor, but also in regard to West Irian, I think, have been seriously deficient. We may find that these matters may come home to roost in the future. In the time of the Whitlam Government and, I regret to say, in the time of the Fraser Government, there has been a tendency, promoted partially by some elements in the Department of Foreign Affairs to ignore the situation and to think that if we do not talk about Timor it will go away. But something near to half a million people are still suffering in that country. I think we owe them more obligations than we have shown them.

The report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Indonesia which recenty visited Timor is very valuable. I noticed that my colleagues on this side in the dissenting report to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence urged that that report be given close consideration. I believe that it should be given close consideration. It has the benefit of being up to date. On the other hand, it has the disadvantage of being a report of a quick journey through East Timor. I must say that, in talking to people who have been to East Timor and in talking, last evening, together with a number of Amnesty International members, with Monsignor da Costa Lopes who was there, of course, for many years and who knows the feelings of the people in East Timor, it is impossible to obtain, very quickly, a view of what they think and it is impossible to avoid the overall presence of the Indonesian troops and Indonesian public servants who are in charge in that country. We know that, since the Australian Parliamentary Delegation went to Timor, there have been remarkable changes. The leader of the Delegation, the Hon. Bill Morrison, M.P., pointed out that the delegation was very impressed with Governor Carrascalao and what he was doing. There was a 'hearts and minds' campaign urging people to overcome their resistance to Indonesia. Since that time there has been a change. Since the Delegation came back from Indonesia, General Benny Murdani, the commander of Indonesia's armed forces in Timor, has threatened to wipe out East Timor's Fretilin independence guerrillas--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what Senator McIntosh said in his dissenting report was going to happen.

—That is true. Of course, Mr Morrison placed great reliance, as did other members of the Delegation, on the strength and support of the governor as against the military people in that country. General Murdani, in the Age of 18 August 1983, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: This time, no more fooling around. We are going to hit them without mercy.

That was a threat to clean out the remnants of the Fretilin rebels. I believe that there are more rebels there than other observers have given credit for. Perhaps when the members of our Delegation were there they saw a relatively quite period. It may be that these things have not finished. We know also that Governor Carrascalao has either been removed or, as later reports indicate, army rule has been confirmed in parts of Timor so that certainly his position is considerably under a cloud now.

I think there is every reason why we should consider this subject open and keep it very much before our minds. As chairman of the Parliamentary Amnesty Group I believe we owe obligations particularly to prisoners who are still being kept on the island of Atauro and elsewhere in East Timor. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter which the Australian section of Amnesty International wrote to Mr W. G. Hayden, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, on 23 September 1983.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL
Australian Section23 September 1983Mr W. G. Hayden,
Minister for Foreign Affairs,
Parliament House,
Canberra,

Dear Mr Hayden, The Australian section of Amnesty International urges the Australian Government to take all possible steps to ensure that the humanitarian concerns in East Timor are discussed in the current session of the UN General Assembly.

As has been mentioned in the past, Amnesty International takes no position on the question of self-determination as such, its concerns deal with the human rights violations within the organisation's mandate.
This approach to you is made after consideration of a number of factors which I list below:

(1) Amnesty International has frequently expressed its continuing concern about the human rights situation in East Timor. Attached is a copy of the Amnesty International statement delivered to the UN Special Committee on Decolonization on 2 September 1983. It details the concerns Amnesty International has in East Timor.

The evidence is that the human rights of individual East Timorese have been systematically and persistently violated since the Indonesian invasion of 1975 and that these violations have been officially condoned;

(2) Amnesty International is concerned at reports of a new Indonesian offensive . As you will be aware, on 16 August 1983 the commander-in-chief of Indonesia's armed forces warned Fretlin that if they continued to ignore his call to surrender ''the Government will use its armed forces and all its arsenal to clean up the remnants of Fretlin rebels.''

Amnesty International is concerned (as stated on page 8 of the attached document) that ''in the past the torture, extrajudicial killing and ' disappearance' of non-combatants has been associated with increased military activity''.

(3) Because of the decision to postpone the debate on East Timorese independence, Amnesty International fears that the question of the humanitarian concerns in East Timor may not be discussed at the current session of UNGA;

(4) Amnesty International believes it is essential that the United Nations continue to keep the humanitarian situation in East Timor under its consideration in order to guarantee that the human rights of the people of East Timor are protected and safeguarded.

With these considerations the Australian section urges your Government to actively seek to ensure that the humanitarian situation is discussed at the 38th session of the United Nations General Assembly.
Yours sincerely,
Harris van Beek, National Administrator

TALK.START.PARA: —Accompanying that document was also a report by Amnesty International on human rights in relation to East Timor. A document in almost identical terms was incorporated at page 569 of Hansard by Senator Primmer when this matter first came before the Senate on 8 September 1983. I draw the Senate' s attention to that document. There are serious questions. We as Australians have an obligation to ensure that we follow up the human rights situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe we have an obligation to see that Timor remains on the agenda of the United Nations. It should not be removed from that agenda. I fear for the future of the people of Timor if there is no international observation of what is going on.

We know that just before the parliamentary delegation went to Timor, a Catholic commission from England was also going to Timor. It was to be accompanied by people who spoke all the languages. It was ready to go and that mission was cancelled by decision of the Indonesian Government. One hopes that more missions go into Timor and that the International Red Cross, which has just been refused entry, will be allowed to go in and see the conditions. We should take up our obligations to ensure that aid goes to the people of East Timor. We can do these things. It will not serve our purpose if we act in any subservient way towards Indonesia. We want to be friendly with that country and we want to help that country. We recognise that it has a somewhat dubious form of democracy at this time. We know it has great human problems and a great deal of economic problems. But it is not serving the purposes of the people of Timor to ignore our obligations. It does not help us, nor does it bring us any respect, even in Indonesian eyes, to lie down and accept anything that is put before us. Therefore, I believe that Australia continues to have an obligation to the Timor people.

I hope this report and other reports will continue to give information to the people of Australia and I trust that the Government of this country will not try to put aside, as other governments have, the obligations which we have to these valiant people who live just north of our country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak as one who has some very real, genuine sympathy and, I believe, practical understanding of the Timorese people. It has been my experience to spend some extensive time on the island of Timor at both ends mainly in the then Dutch colony but also extensively in the Portuguese colony. Of course, I came to know, respect and have an affection for the people but, above everything, to understand something of the geography, something of the agricultural potential and something of the formidable nature of the island. I think it is important, for one to understand the situation, first to look at something of the geography. The island is virtually totally mountainous. It is about 300 miles long with the backbone of a gigantic mountain range running through it and, indeed, rising to heights, I think, of almost 10,000 feet if my memory does not fail me. It has very little savannah land or very little plain country. It has small pockets of flat land but precious little land in which Indian maize or corn can be cultivated. It has one of the poorest opportunities for agriculture or animal husbandry of any country in the world and one of the lowest living standards in the world. Without recrimination I can say that, with regard to the eastern end, it is a country which, during the Portuguese occupation, had very little really intensive colonisation of a broader kind, therefore there is virtually very little for the people to lift themselves up and help themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: Above all, the East Timorese are rugged individualists living in small tribal or clan groups up in the hill country, fiercely loyal to the leaders of their clans, to their kings of their tribes, quarrelling very frequently with each other. In my time there were even head hunters in the country, quite vigorous and in some cases violent people living with great difficulty off the land. That is the background. I also want to give some background on the whole of what was the Netherlands East Indies to give honourable senators an understanding of this problem. I want to give some background on what we now call Indonesia, some 3, 000 islands covering some 2,000 square miles. During the Dutch occupation from the early sixteenth century to the Japanese invasion in Dutch terms it had fairly good colonisation. It was fairly humane but not deeply ingrained in the indigenous people. Yes, the Eurasians played a significant part. Yes, the white Dutch, the Netherlanders as distinct from the Hollanders, built up a structure of organisation, but after that collapsed and the Japanese brought down their military rule there was nothing left.

I want there to be some sympathetic understanding of the tasks of the Indonesian regime from then onwards, when it faced a situation in which there was no public service at all. I do not think anyone realises the immensity of a task of taking a huge and diverse country with no public service and constructing it from the grass roots, and in doing it, of course, having very great difficulties indeed. There needs to be more and more understanding. I have an affection for the Indonesian people. I have been privileged to visit most of their main islands. I have been privileged to have some understanding of their cultures and languages. I have lived with them in their kampongs. I hope that the Australian people will draw closer together with the Indonesian people. We must look at what has happened. I remind the Senate of an article in the Quadrant magazine of May 1983 written by a very well respected ex-senator, John Wheeldon, a former Labor Minister. I read one main sentence in which he said:
There are even some grounds for believing that if Mr Whitlam had not urged the Indonesians to seize East Timor the whole operation would never have taken place .

I repeat that: If he had not urged the Indonesians to seize East Timor it would not have taken place. It weighs heavily upon us that if that is the fact, and a very respected ex-Labor Minister of this chamber wrote it, then it was an Australian Prime Minister who urged the seizure in September-October 1975, a seizure which had from the start never any practical ability for reversal.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not quite fair.

—I simply say to Senator Robertson that John Wheeldon was one of the most respected and senior persons of the Australian Labor Party here, recognised by all sides of the chamber as having a profound knowledge of foreign affairs and, indeed, as being a dispassionate observer. That having been said, to my knowledge there has never been an attempt at denial. I repeat his words:

SPEECH.PARA: There are even some grounds for believing that if Mr Whitlam had not urged the Indonesians to seize East Timor the whole operation would never have taken place .

TALK.START.PARA: —That has been constantly denied by Whitlam and successive spokesmen.

—Interjections aside, the fact is that that has been said by a respected commentator of the foreign scene and it has never been refuted. This happened at the time of the Whitlam Government and it now is basically irreversible. Nobody has suggested that it can be reversed. My basic plea in this situation is that we should now make sure in everything we do that we give practical aid to East Timor. Above everything, what it needs is a strong health team. It has been very, very short of medical teams. The people suffer very seriously from respiratory and dietary diseases.
—Order! The time having expired for consideration of committee reports, I now call on Government Business.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, as I was saying before the debate was interrupted earlier today, the reintroduction of the assets test on pensions is a genuine attempt to stop the very wealthy in the community from ripping off the system. It is not a cowardly attack on pensioners , as claimed by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney). As the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) has pointed out, of Australia's two million pensioners, three in every four will not be affected and only 17 per cent will be marginally affected. A single pensioner will lose the pension only if he or she has $104,000 on top of all the exempt assets, and for a married couple the figure is $177,000.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is totally irresponsible for the Opposition to indulge in scaremongering in this way for the purpose of cheap political gain at the expense of the elderly. It has deliberately set out to frighten pensioners in the same way as the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, tried to frighten them during the election campaign by urging them to put their money under their beds. This latest bid by the Opposition to exploit the elderly will almost certainly fail, just as Mr Fraser's attempt failed during the election campaign.

The fact of the matter is that under the previous Government the standard pension rate declined from 24.5 per cent of average weekly earnings in 1975 to 21.9 per cent in 1982. This is a measure of the previous Government's concern for Australia's senior citizens. The Opposition has the audacity to attack the Hawke Government over its alleged lack of concern when it was directly responsible for plunging 2.8 million Australians into poverty. Under the Fraser Government, one in six Australians were living in poverty, without food, clothing or housing. In a survey conducted in Sydney's western suburbs last year it was revealed that 72 per cent of families went without regular hot meals, milk and meat, and 67 per cent had been forced to appeal to charities for money and clothing at least once during the last year of the Fraser Government.

These Opposition white knights on the other side of the chamber are the same people who, when in government, forced hundreds of thousands of Australians on to the dole queues and forced many of our young people on to the streets because of their constant refusal to increase the level of unemployment benefit to under 18-year-olds. That is a measure of the Opposition's real concern for the underprivileged and the needy in the community. I would strongly urge every pensioner living in this country to question seriously the genuineness of the words emanating from the Opposition on the assets test issue. After the Budget in August 1981, Senator Chaney, the then Minister for Social Security, said:
'The Government is concerned that, in the welfare area, as well as taxation, income rigging practices are circumventing the intent of the laws and throwing undue burdens on taxpayers generally.'

He was, of course, foreshadowing his Government's moves to introduce a means test on pensions. In October that year it was revealed by the Manager of the Savings Bank of South Australia, Mr P. Simmons, that many pensioners in South Australia had begun keeping large sums of money in their homes because of the Fraser Government's crackdown on pensioners' non-interest bearing accounts. Therefore, given the practice of the previous Government in this area, the current claims of the Opposition in relation to the proposed assets test are nothing more than an act of hypocrisy.

I now turn to some other measures contained in this Budget, particularly those in the employment generation area. Unlike the previous regime, we have taken firm and positive action to correct the growing rate of unemployment. Expenditure on employment and training programs for the unemployed has been increased by a massive 110 per cent in this financial year to $733m. Apart, of course, from the $300m allocated to the community employment program, which will provide 70,000 new jobs annually when fully operational, other measures include a 23.5 per cent increase in trade training assistance, a 59 per cent increase in the area of skills training, a 20 per cent increase in funding for work experience training programs for young people, and a 28.6 per cent increase in funding for community based youth programs.

In South Australia, where we have had the highest or second highest unemployment rate in Australia for something like three years, the new measures outlined by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) will certainly assist in stopping the unemployment spiral. Although I am concerned about the absence of any special assistance to self-help and support programs for the adult unemployed, especially since many of those projects in South Australia are running into serious financial difficulties, I am advised that the Minister is currently examining the matter. In relation to transport the huge increase in spending of 45 per cent of Federal road programs will create an additional 19,000 jobs. In South Australia our share of the funds allocated is $100m. This could be expected to generate over 1,500 jobs.

Like most South Australians of all political persuasions, I would like to see the Darwin to Alice Springs railway given the green light. I find it most disappointing that the Government did not provide the necessary $12m in this financial year to enable substantial progress to be made. The railway is estimated to require about 150,000 tonnes of steel rail and it would be reasonable to expect that this would be produced at the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd steelworks in Whyalla, thereby providing the Iron Triangle region in South Australia, and indeed the steel industry generally, with a much needed boost. The multiplier effects of the construction of the rail link and the benefits to South Australia in respect of freight traffic and employment creation are too great to be ignored. I am therefore looking forward to the outcome of the Government's inquiry into this matter.

I turn now to the Government's initiatives in the housing area, which are expected to create another 30,000 jobs. The new package for first home buyers, as announced in the May economic package, together with the massive injection of funds into the public housing area, will provide a tremendous boost to the housing and construction sector, especially given the recent drop in home loan interest rates. Indicative of the Government's concern for those in most need is the increased allocation of funds in the areas of crisis accommodation for families, and mortgage and rent relief assistance.

As Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Public Works, I am particularly pleased to see that expenditure on public works in 1983-84 will be increased by 16 per cent to $575m. In the highly labour intensive area of repairs and maintenance, spending has been increased by 27 per cent. Works in South Australia will include further upgrading of facilities at the Daw Park Repatriation Hospital, works at the Woodside Army base and the Torrens Island animal quarantine complex. Other projects coming up include the Telecom Australia tower in Adelaide. I am confident of getting the support of the Minister responsible to bring forward consideration of the proposed new Commonwealth offices complex, also in Adelaide. These works will provide a much needed boost to our construction industry in South Australia and should provide hundreds of jobs in the building and related trades.

A final point I raise concerns the Government's support of a return to centralised wage fixing. Unfortunately, because of the mess left behind by Liberal governments, both State and Federal, many wage and salary earners have suffered a serious drop in the real level of their incomes over the last 12 months, particularly as a result of increases in various State charges such as gas, water, electricity and government housing rentals. Therefore, I am delighted with the decision handed down by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission last Friday week. Had real wages continued to fall as they have over the last 12 months, we would have run the risk of jeopardising economic recovery especially in the employment creating service industries, as spending in that area would be drastically curtailed. Moreover, any further drop in the level of real wages would cause even more unemployment in the motor vehicle and whitegoods industries as people's decisions to replace cars, washing machines and so on were postponed indefinitely.

While I strongly support the return to centralised wage fixation, as I pointed out in the Senate yesterday, I also see the need for moderation so that the benefit of any impending economic recovery can be shared by everyone. Unlike some of the right wing editorial writers in the national media, I believe that a return to an orderly form of centralised wage fixing will assist the measures contained in the Budget in bringing about a renewed burst of economic activity in Australia. I believe this Budget is truly a Budget for recovery. It has been well received by the business community. A public opinion poll published in the Bulletin of 20 September suggested that it is the most popular Budget brought down in the history of Australia.

There is obviously a lot more work to be done in many of those areas neglected for so long by the former discredited Fraser Government. I am sure these will be attended to at the earliest opportunity when finances and the overall economic situation permit. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said in his Budget Speech, this year's Budget was about a reordering of priorities and giving a fairer deal to ordinary wage and salary earners and the underprivileged in the community. In that regard, I believe this Budget has been a resounding success and that it has set the scene for a sustained economic recovery in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make some observations on the 1983-84 Federal Budget. Honourable senators opposite are no doubt feeling very pleased, since this is the first Budget since 1975 to be presented to this Parliament by a Labor government. However, I suspect that they are the only people in Australia who are satisfied with its contents. The ordinary Australian will have remembered on Budget night the statement of the present Prime Minister, then the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hawke, in his election policy speech, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I offer no fistful of dollars to be snatched back after the election.
Australians will recall Mr Hawke saying that:
Under the Labor Government, increased growth will be restored by-
amongst other things-
tax reductions for low and middle income earners, widening of opportunities for borrowing by business, farmers and home buyers, and providing support for private sector investment.

Yet Labor's very first Budget not only does not attempt to achieve these objectives but actually retreats from them. There were no increases in rates of income tax, and perhaps the Prime Minister believes that we should be grateful for that; but inflation will continue to eat into the taxes and drive more and more Australians into the marginal tax rates. So much for the pre-election promises to 'prevent the erosion of after-tax income by inflation'.

More importantly, what the Prime Minister did not promise was increased excises and widening sales taxes on a whole range of items in everyday use. What he did not say was that these increases would be indexed to an inflationary situation which this Government is doing nothing to redress. It has built into its revenue -raising measures a vested interest in inflation, and by its budgetary policies it has built into the Australian economy the guarantee of future inflation. Essential items such as motor spirit have been subject to further rises in the discretionary rate of the excise, from 7.155c a litre to 8.655c a litre, an increase of 1.5c a litre. For a government which claims to be concerned about inflation and the prices which ordinary Australians will pay for virtually everything they buy, this is incomprehensible in itself.

An increase in the price of petrol, apart from increasing the cost of private motoring, will also impact on costs of transporting food, clothing and appliances-in fact, almost everything that finds its way into Australian homes. What is more, not content with the additional revenue that will accrue from that measure, the Government then adds another 0.37c a litre to account for the movements in the consumer price index for the March and June quarters of this year. In a Budget brought down on 23 August for the forthcoming financial year, I can see no relevance to the movement in the CPI for the past six months of this year, yet this Government has used this as an excuse to increase excises which were already subject to rises in the discretionary rate, and as an excuse to increase the excise on other items such as beer, cigarettes and certain spirits, for which the discretionary rate would have otherwise been unchanged.

Diesel fuel received the same treatment as motor spirit, with increases in the discretionary rate and in the actual rate payable through the effect of the excise indexation. However, in keeping with the inconsistency which is the hallmark of this Budget, the rebate for eligible off-road users in the mining, farming, forestry and fishing industries will not be indexed. That means that as from Budget night those previously exempt from the diesel fuel levy will now pay it, initially at a rate of 1.87c a litre but at an increasing rate as future indexation increases are applied.

Primary producers, who have also been affected by the loss of write-off allowances for land clearing and swamp drainage and by the 20 per cent increase in sales taxes on business and industrial users of oils and lubricants, once again have no reason to thank this Labor Government. Farmers who were already reeling from the May economic statement, which will cost farmers in Western Australia alone about $5.7m next year, must now face additional burdens as a result of this Budget.

The excises on aviation gasoline and aviation turbine fuel, which were raised by 2c a litre in May by this Government, were increased a further 0.5c a litre in the Budget and a further 4.3 per cent after contemplation and the calculation as a result of the retrospectively applied indexation increase. In effect, that has taken the excise on aviation gasoline, extensively used in the pastoral industry, from 4.555c a litre to 7.358c a litre in a period of three months and will cause an additional cost of $15m to that industry.
Those are the actions of a party which in its pre-election statement commented that:
No sector of Australian industry is more important than our great primary industries, which still provide 50 per cent of Australia's export income in normal circumstances.

I accept completely the sentiments of that statement, yet I must conclude that the Labor Party in government, by reverting to its traditional anti-rural stance , has conveniently forgotten its own empty rhetoric.

Primary producers are not the only ones to have suffered at the hands of this Government. In May the Government reintroduced the income test for age and service pensioners aged over 70 years and now the same Government has reintroduced an assets test which will act as a positive disincentive for people to save for their retirements. In the previous session the Senate quite properly rejected a quite diabolical piece of legislation to impose a new retrospective tax on innocent vendor-shareholders. As an instrument of its budgetary policy, the Government has decided to resubmit that legislation, with some modifications , despite which, I am sure, it will be condemned to the same fate. The Government has decided to reduce the incentive to invest in Australian films, to the detriment of the film industry. It has decided to impose a tax on grape spirit, despite its solemn promise that it would not do so, much now to the dissatisfaction of wine producers throughout Australia. The only person who appears satisfied by that decision, apart from the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who see that as yet another grab for revenue, is the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) who, by a remarkable twist of logic, was able to claim on 25 August that he was satisfied that the Labor Party had completely honoured its promise. I am sure that at the first opportunity his electors will pass judgment on that, as will the wine producers of the Swan Valley of Western Australia and in the south-west of Western Australia, who have also recognised this as yet another broken Labor promise.

All Australians will also be surprised by the magnitude of the overall Budget deficit, I suspect, especially after the mock horror with which the Prime Minister trumpeted his imagined projected deficit figure for 1983-84. The proof now lies in the Government's own Budget statement-indeed, in the Treasurer's Budget Speech. Total outlays are expected to increase by 15.8 per cent and receipts by only 8.6 per cent in 1983-84. The Budget deficit in Labor's first Budget will almost double, from $4,473m last year to $8,361m in the next financial year. That does not reflect on the Budget policies of the previous Government. It is a testimony to the incompetence of this Government and its commitment to the same old tried, tired and failed public spending policies of other socialist governments, most notably those of France and, to a lesser exent , of Scandinavia. I remind honourable senators opposite of the words of the last Labor Treasurer to bring down a Budget in this Parliament:

If Budget outlays . . . were again to grow faster than total spending, a further decline in the private sector share of GDP would ensue. That would mean an accelerated decline in investment and productivity as well as a further contraction in job opportunities.

That is a quotation from the past Leader of the Australian Labor Party and a past Treasurer, Mr Bill Hayden. In assessing this Budget, his former economic adviser was reported in the Australian as saying that the Government's Budget strategy was 'manifestly absurd'. Dr Peter McCawley, a former economic adviser to Bill Hayden, has correctly described the Labor Government's plans as absurd. He has said more than that. In a speech to the Australian Graduate School of Management he said:
I don't see any reason to expect any drop in unemployment. In fact, I can see it running at 15 per cent and more. On present economic policies, that is what we are facing.
Our greatest problem is low growth and we should concentrate on growth to attain price stability and low unemployment.

Of course we should. I am quoting a past adviser to Mr Bill Hayden, a past Treasurer of the ALP. The clear expectation which the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) created in the minds of Australian people in his policy speech was that a Labor Government would pursue policies which would be supportive of private enterprise. As the last Labor Treasurer to bring down a Budget made clear in his policy speech in 1975, it is madness for Budget outlays to grow faster than total spending, that is, the gross domestic product. Yet what has happened by this Budget is that the outlays have increased by a record of 31.6 per cent of GDP, which represents a real increase of 7.2 per cent in expenditure. That real rate of spending increase has been excelled in recent times only by the 1974-75 Budget of Dr Cairns, which resulted in a record post-war inflation level of 16.7 per cent and unemployment which more than doubled in one year. That is what the plan for so-called economic reconstruction which has been peddled by the Hawke Government is all about. Its consequences will be disastrous.

The Australian Chamber of Commerce has predicted that, as a result of the overall Budget strategy, something little short of a miracle will be necessary to prevent Australia sliding back to double digit inflation. The outcome of inflation of that magnitude will cause a dramatic rise in interest rates, compounded as the Federal Government increasingly moves into the loan market to finance its own deficit which, on its own estimates, will be $8.36 billion or 4. 7 per cent of GDP. Budget deficits in Australia have exceeded that proportion of total national production only once before and that was during the period of the Whitlam Government whose economic policies failed. Capital for the private sector will, of course, become restricted, thus delaying or perhaps even aborting the tentative moves towards economic recovery that have been noticeable since the introduction by the previous Government of a popular wages pause policy. The demonstrated effect of a large increase in the Budget share of GDP is a corresponding decline in company trading surpluses. Between 1973 and 1975 the Budget share of GDP rose from 23.8 per cent to 30 per cent, while profits over the same period declined from 14.5 per cent to 11.7 per cent of GDP. Inevitably that affected the ability of the private sector to expand and, ultimately, even to maintain its existing labour fource. As I said earlier, that prospect has been underlined by one of Labor's own former economic advisers. That is the effect he sees this Budget having on business and employment prospects in the private sector. Dr McCawley has quite rightly pointed out the misplaced priorities of this Budget and, while I do not totally agree with what he says, by and large he is going down the right track. In the same speech to which I have previously referred, he said:

Instead of spending money on health, social security and housing, the Government should have injected funds into a more productive infrastructure-such as roads, railways, bridges and harbour building.

Once again he has identified a major failing of this Budget. The real increase in health expenditure is 16.1 per cent; in social security 10.5 per cent; in housing 14 per cent-compared with an overall increase in total outlays of 7.2 per cent. By comparison, the real increase in funds to the States, the Northern Territory and to local government, which have had and still have the main responsibility for capital works, has been a mere 2.8 per cent. The hand of union pressure in this area is unmistakable. In this one-sided prices and incomes accord the Labor Party was forced into the position of promising greater spending in these non-productive areas as a price for wage restraint which, as is already clear, will not be forthcoming from the unions.

The prices and incomes policy obliges the Labor Government to provide national health insurance which, by the Treasurer's own figures, will cost $680m in the first financial year-of course, that is a bodgy figure; we know we can add $550m on to that-and a staggering $1,800m in the next full year, all wasted on duplicating services already provided in the private sector. That same agreement with the unions has also resulted in significant increases in unemployment benefits and other areas of welfare spending which will reduce the incentive of individuals to work and to provide for themselves. That is amply demonstrated by the Government's attitude to pensions, to which I have already referred briefly. People seeking to make provisions for their own requirements and according to their own capacity to accommodate their needs are penalised by this Government's policies. There is no balance in this Budget between the undeniable need for the community to provide for those disadvantaged by economic circumstances, albeit that they are circumstances which have been exacerbrated by unrealistic union demands for higher wages and shorter hours, and the need to provide incentive for private sector expansion that is our main hope in restoring full employment or something approaching that situation.

The Treasurer's own predictions for the year ahead make very gloomy reading, much gloomier reading than the hopes which the Labor Party unrealistically created during the election campaign when promises were cheap. The Treasurer says that real total growth in public sector spending this year will be in the order of 4 1/2 per cent, while private consumption expenditure will be in the order of 1 1/2 per cent. That breaks the basic rule enunciated by, amongst others, a former Labor Treasurer and Leader of the Opposition. The Treasurer predicts a decline in fixed business investment in the coming 12 months. It is an easy prediction to make because with his policies inevitably forcing the Government into the loan market to a greater extent than previously, interest rates of course will again move upwards to deny business the capital it needs to generate employment and to renew productive capacity. His policies towards a greatly expanded Budget deficit make a mockery of the prediction that private dwelling investment will continue to increase notwithstanding temporary aberrations because, like business, investment in that area relies on a stable low interest rate and a stable and declining inflation rate. What is more, for the government that is claiming to be pursuing the dual policies of controlling inflation and unemployment, it is remarkable that the Treasurer's own prediction is that unemployment will not ease this year. Despite the 80 per cent increase in spending for employment and training programs, which represents a massive 52 per cent increase in real terms, the Treasurer is saying that the unemployment situation during the coming period will not ease. What an utter self- condemnation of his priorities and policies that admission represents. I recall the present Prime Minister saying in his policy speech that growth cannot be restored to the economy 'by taking money out of the weekly pay packet or the pensioners' cheque'. More importantly, when Australians recall that promise, they will understand how far this Government has gone off the tracks in just five short months.

The combined effect of this Budget and the May mini-Budget has been to impose an additional cost to the average household of $16 a week, a burden on the average Australian family. That is only one of the many hopes and aspirations which the Labor Party has cruelly created in its pre-election statements which has now been torn down once it scrambled its way into office. Labor promised to decrease the price of petrol and it has increased it, not once, but on an ongoing basis. Labor promised to retain the accelerated depreciation allowances. All Australian primary producers know what became of that promise. The Government was able to keep it barely a matter of two months.

I do not have time to list all the promises and hopes built up by the Labor Party which have been dashed by this Budget, but no doubt my colleagues will continue to contribute to that list in the time provided to them. However, I notice that the Treasurer has sought to perpetuate the cruellest hoax of all-the promise of employment and training opportunities for 300,000 people a year. They are not permanent jobs; they are illusions that can be maintained only by increased Government spending. Yet, as I have said, to appease the militant unions, with which this Government believes it has some sort of accord, it is money which the Treasurer believes is well spent. It is not well spent. The only real permanent jobs are those created through demand for goods and services by the community and this Budget does nothing to assist that objective. It is clear that it was never an objective which this Government had in mind.

I conclude by referring briefly to page 70 of Budget Statement No. 1. I believe it says it all. The section of the Treasury viewpoint entitled 'Further Ahead' warns that financing the deficit will not only force up interest rates as the most likely scenario but also could crowd out any improvement in private sector investment. It warns that the Government appears to have predicated its deficit on the assumption, described as 'comfortless in the reasoning that underlies it' , that public sector borrowing can be accommodated because the private sector will become weaker and weaker and there will be less and less demand. If that turns out not to be true we will have a renewed bout of inflation which will make us even less competitive on world markets or, as Treasury went on to say, we could have rising interest rates which:
. . . could act to seriously inhibit, if not choke off, the tendency for recovery in private sector activity.

That is the course which the Labor Government has chartered for Australia. In time, if it is not already, the Budget will be seen not as a mild, conciliatory, popular Budget but as a recipe for absolute disaster. It will put out the glimmer of optimism that a recovery is foreseeable and possible. In the end it will force even more people to seek the assistance of the State to survive. As time goes on and events speed up we will see a manifestation of the distortions, the misunderstanding and the incompetence of this Government in designing this Budget. I am sure the economy can go only one way under this Government and that is down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Budget brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) only a few weeks ago. In doing so I think it is important to look at the situation that the Hawke Government inherited from its predecessors. When the Hawke Government came to office it inherited an economy in deep recession, the worst recession in 30 years. Inflation was running at more than double the average for countries of the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development. Unemployment was nearly three quarters of a million, having increased by 250,000 in just 12 months. There was no comparable increase of that kind in the previous 50 years. Budgetary policy was out of control with a prospective Budget deficit of $9.6 billion. That, of course, was the great deception, the big lie of the election campaign. Everything else paled in comparison with that one big lie. Gross domestic product was also falling at an alarming rate. It dropped by 3.9 per cent in the last financial year. The Fraser Government had totally lost control of economic policy.

SPEECH.PARA: I am reminded of what Paul Keating, when he was shadow Treasurer, said very early in the campaign. He said that John Howard as Treasurer had been reduced to the role of commentator on Australia's economic affairs. I think it is true to say that not only John Howard but also Malcolm Fraser and, indeed, the whole Government were powerless and immobilised in the face of an economic disaster that had overwhelmed them. The former Government's policies had plunged Australia deeper and deeper into recession-deeper than most comparable countries . Most of those policies were brought about by the sheer electoral opportunism of that government. Even the Valder report concluded that the Fraser Government' s actions had never matched its rhetoric. I commend that report to honourable senators opposite. I hope they can adopt most of its recommendations. I had been confident that the Australian Labor Party could govern for 10 years but if those recommendations are adopted it will make the Menzies era look like a brief interlude.

By March 1983 the Australian electorate had had enough. It clearly wanted and needed a new approach to economic policy. The Hawke Government has provided just that. We have rejected the policy of fighting inflation first, the one that never worked. We have embraced a policy of fighting the twin evils of inflation and unemployment simultaneously. Given that honourable senators opposite have been quoting some of Mr Hawke's statements prior to the campaign, I will quote Mr Fraser on the subject of inflation. On 12 September 1978 he said:
Inflation at an annual rate of 5 per cent is within our reach by mid-1979. It will go on falling under the policies of this government.

Of course, by June 1978 the inflation rate was 8.8 per cent. By mid-1979 when Mr Fraser had promised that it would be 5 per cent it had reached 10.7 per cent, more than double the rate he promised. It kept on rising during the rest of his reign. The new approach we have developed and implemented has been achieved through a spirit of consensus and consultation. That process was begun so startlingly at the National Economic Summit Conference held only a few yards away in the chamber of the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame.
—It must be regarded as a shame by Opposition senators that the Prime Minister received a standing ovation from all the participants in that Summit, bar one.
—Sycophants.

—It is interesting that Senator Messner would refer to some of Australia's most prominent business people as sycophants. I am sure they would be fascinated to register that comment. In marked contrast to the division and despair so evident in the latter years of the Fraser Government, the Prime Minister and the Ministers of his Government have given Australia, represented in that Summit, something for which to hope. People had had no hope for the previous seven years. The broad guidelines for our Budget were developed during that consultative process. Consultation took place not only with business and unions but also with State governments. There was so much consultation that, despite the protestations of those opposite, the Budget strategy has had general endorsement from all those groups. It has also had endorsement from most of the financial Press for one very good reason-this Budget, in conjunction with the other arms of our economic policy, is the most appropriate for the difficulties we face.

SPEECH.PARA: By any definition this Budget is expansionary. Its emphasis is on the restoration of economic growth and the creation of jobs. It provides a marked increase in public sector spending while private sector spending remains weak. It provides a marked acceleration in capital works as well as substantially increased welfare payments. It should contribute substantially to real growth over the year. The current predictions on growth, which I think are worth noting by all honourable senators, run to 5 per cent for non-farm GDP and over 6 per cent for total GDP this year. That is in stark contrast to the negative growth of the previous 12 months. The Budget is designed not only to restore growth which is real and which can be sustained, not frittered away by inflation.

Several key elements of this expansionary policy were put into place prior to the Budget in the May economic statement to provide an early and much needed stimulus. Significant among those was the housing package designed to lift activity in several depressed areas. The building industry which is, of course, a key to any recovery in this country is already showing signs of benefit from that housing package announced only a few months ago. The community employment program came into being to assist the long term unemployed. Additional funds to the States through tax sharing grants and loan programs are already showing benefits. These policies and the budgetary decisions are designed to provide a floor of activity while the private sector recovers because it is private sector recovery that in the end will provide the answer to our unemployment problems. While private sector activity is at a low ebb the Government accepts the need for a substantial role for the public sector. As I have said, recovery in the private sector is essential if the tentative signs of recovery already so evident are to be sustained.

Even when that upturn becomes more firmly entrenched and established, business investment will not be improved until we can see better prospects for that upturn remaining in place over a longer period. What business needs more than anything else is the restoration of economic growth. Traditionally, through the long periods of Liberal Government, business Budgets as they were called were characterised by handouts, concessions and the like. This Budget, on the other hand, while not being characterised as a business Budget in that mould, is a Budget that is good for business. It is a Budget that provides the framework for a private sector recovery, for the restoration of growth, and for that growth to be sustained. I quote the Treasurer, Paul Keating, on Budget night:
The key task of our policy therefore is to facilitate a sustained recovery that wears away the unacceptably high levels of unemployment we are now experiencing.

The concept of sustained recovery is crucial to our thinking. We are not merely waiting for the American recovery to hit us; its length and durability will always be in question. We are looking for a sustained recovery that will go on irrespective of overseas developments. In reference to business, I might say that this Budget, despite the protestations from those opposite, has been acclaimed in board rooms across the country. It has been acclaimed by union executives; it has been acclaimed by commerce; it has been acclaimed by the financial Press; and, yes-the thing that honourable senators opposite most fear- it has been acclaimed by the people. They have said yes, and that is what the Hawke Government has been about.

The beneficial effects of our expansionary policies are already evident. The housing sector is recovering at an encouraging rate both in terms of finance and in terms of actual construction. This should be compared with a decline in dwelling construction last financial year of 25 per cent. Retail sales are on the up and motor vehicle registrations increased by over 18 per cent in August alone. Consumer confidence has increased markedly. A survey done only last week I think, by the Melbourne University Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research, suggested that consumer confidence was at its highest for two years. Of more significance is that we have been able to bring down this Budget, with its admittedly attendant financial risks, in a climate of falling interest rates . As the headline in the Australian Financial Review this morning heralded, yesterday interest rates fell again, this time for large borrowers. The prime rate fell for all banks by between one-half and three-quarters of one per cent. I look once again at the performance of the previous Government in regard to interest rates, and I quote Malcolm Fraser on 3 December 1977:
A 2 per cent reduction in interest rates in the next 12 months is a target that can and will be achieved.

At the end of 1977, new housing loan mortgages were at interest rates of 9.25 per cent to 10.5 per cent and by the end of last year they were at 13.5 per cent . It is only since the Hawke Government has come into office that they have begun to fall. These and earlier falls have occurred while the Government has raised close to $5 billion towards financing the deficit. That $5 billion has been raised in only three months, another sign of the confidence that people have in this Government.

Although many favourable signs are emerging, the extent of our economic problems, particularly those we inherited from our predecessors, should not be understated for they are immense. Recovery will take time. While I have often heard Bob Hawke referred to as the messiah, it should be stated that this Government does not offer miracles. The severity of our problems was and still is distinctly greater than that of most other Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development countries. The one area that will take considerable time to show improvement is the area of unemployment. The slump in employment under the Fraser Government, as I have already mentioned, was unprecedented for the post-war period and it will take some time for sustained economic growth to generate jobs.

I might say that the Labor Government was elected primarily on the issue of unemployment. It recognises its responsibilities in this area and if it fails over the years to meet the problem of unemployment it will not be elected again, and it will not deserve to be. In the early stages of the upturn that we are now experiencing we will not see a marked decrease in unemployment. One can assume that initially increased productivity will take up most of the upturn rather than increased employment. Already there is evidence that more overtime is being worked; already many firms have returned to working a full week. With growth in our working population-it must be remembered that that is rising all the time-it will take quite a while for the upward trend in unemployment to be reversed. Present predictions already are that more than 130,000 jobs will be created by the end of this financial year.

Despite this, because of all the factors I have just mentioned, there could still be a worsening of unemployment during that period. This Government does not back away from that likelihood. In fact, we have tried to provide that floor of activity so that private sector recovery can be sustained and we can have more jobs. If we are to be criticised for our performance on unemployment, then I would like to contrast that performance with Mr Fraser's address to the nation in November 1975, when he said:
Unemployment is now estimated to rise to over 400,000 early in the new year. Tens of thousands of school leavers will start life on the dole. Where is the recovery we have been told about?

In seven years Mr Fraser failed to provide any sort of recovery. By the end of his reign a further 350,000 people were out of work. In the clear recognition that unemployment will not be reduced significantly in the short term and that there are disadvantaged groups in the community, this Budget has been about increasing assistance to those people. Compassion has been the hallmark of the Cabinet's deliberations on these matters. There has been a substantial re- ordering of our priorities. The principles of fairness and equity have finally been applied to the formation of a Budget in this country. We have focussed aid on the victims of the recession, on those people in expenditure areas who have been so sadly and long neglected by the Fraser Government, our predecessor.

Today's unemployed, in particular, are victims of circumstances well beyond their control and, at least in the immediate period, this Government has to set about trying to relieve their plight. The combined measures announced in the May statement and in the Budget will increase the unemployment benefit for a single person by more than 21 per cent, or $14 a week. The married rate will increase by over 16 per cent. More importantly, the rate payable to under 18-year-olds, which had been increased only once in seven years, a truly miserable performance by those opposite, has been increased by $5 a week. That is going to a generation that has been given no hope in the last seven years, a generation that will create many social problems on an enormous scale for our community to meet over the next few decades. The income test has been liberalised, from $10 to $20 a week. These are just some of the short term measures that the Government has introduced to assist the unemployed. In the welfare area, additional assistance has been given to families, to the handicapped, to the aged, and to those who are in poor health. Additional educational expenditure and student assistance has also been provided, but our priorities have been redirected towards the needy. Our priorities are now directed to providing more adequate living standards for those who are unemployed, to ensuring that where benefits must be paid to the needy they are actually received by the needy-a great innovation.

This has all been done within a framework of responsible economic management. I would like to mention in regard to that framework of responsible management Medicare, which I note has been mentioned by a number of speakers from the other side during the afternoon. Not only will the Medicare system as announced by the Hawke Government extend these principles of fairness and equity so that a reasonable system of health care is available at a cheap cost to so many people in our community, but also it will bring some sanity to the system. The health care arrangements were changed so many times during the previous seven years, at such great cost, that I believe many people in the community are still confused as to what health care is available to them. I quote from the 1975 election speech of Malcolm Fraser:
We will maintain Medibank and ensure that the standard of health services in this country do not decline.

In 1975 health cover for a family on average weekly earnings amounted to 1.1 per cent of income. As of last year, the cost had increased to 6 per cent of average weekly earnings. Between July 1975 and June 1982 the cost of basic family health insurance increased by 220 per cent compared to an average weekly earnings increase of less than 100 per cent. Such is the Fraser Government's record in care for the sick. Because of the dismal fiscal inheritance it was not possible simply to add all of our programs such as Medicare on to those of our predecessors. Indeed, $2.5 billion of new expenditure programs had instead been achieved by reducing expenditures of the previous Government where this Government considered them to be of a low priority. The Expenditure Review Committee, which met over only a couple of months, achieved more in those couple of months than the now infamous Lynch razor gang achieved in more than six times that period. This Government showed that it had the political will to match its convictions and those cuts went ahead.

More importantly, though, we are now setting about ensuring that those who have not been paying their fair share of the tax bill in Australia begin to do so. That process has started. We are recouping more of the revenue still owed to the people of Australia by those who have indulged in tax avoidance practices. The withholding tax legislation shows our determination to collect tax from those who have been evading it by resorting to the cash economy. The figures already available to us from the Australian Taxation Office show a very early success in that endeavour. Indeed, more than 16,000 new applications were received by 19 September for taxation file numbers. The Taxation Office has estimated that 4, 000 of those were from entities, either individuals, companies or partnerships, which had been in existence but which had previously not been paying tax. That will mean a tremendous amount of new revenue for the Government. By limiting also the potential for avoidance from the conversion of income into capital gains, we will further ensure that the burden is more fairly distributed.

On the general question of tax avoidance, while Malcolm Fraser may have said in November 1977 'We will move to close loopholes which permit tax avoidance', the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union in its 1981 interim report said:
This industry has developed in Australia, particularly over the last five years --
So the Whitlam Government cannot be blamed--

at a rate far in excess of any other industry and has brought with it profits comparable only to the heady days of the Victorian gold rush . . . The amounts involved are very large indeed, amounting to many hundreds of millions of dollars per year or more. The impact on the community has been very serious.

Already the Hawke Labor Government has set about removing those inequities. It is to be hoped that when the tax recoupment legislation comes into the Senate in the very near future this Senate will accept its share of the responsibility and pass that legislation and pass it quickly.

I turn to the question of the assets test which has admittedly caused so much heartache and anxiety to many elderly people in our community. Much of what I have said in the previous 20 minutes I hope will show that this Government has acted and will continue to act with the compassion that has characterised it since 5 March. When anomalies are brought before the Government they will be reviewed during the 12 months that it will take before the assets test is introduced and there will be very few pensioners indeed who will need to worry about its introduction. The previous Government and, indeed, Senator Chaney on many occasions were prepared to concede that the incomes test was failing, that there were too many ways around it. The assets test is in the end the only alternative. There is work still to be done on it and this Government has pledged to continue that work.

To conclude, this Budget can be seen as providing a substantial macroeconomic stimulus within an acceptable balance of risks. That said, there should be no doubting the magnitude of the task ahead. In attempting a sustainable recovery while inflation remains at double digit figures, this Government is attempting what no industrial economy has yet achieved. The Hawke Government, in extraordinarily difficult circumstances, has in this Budget kept to its major commitments in pursuit of that objective.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the 1983-84 Budget Papers I think it is worth noting a Commonwealth Bank report of last week which anticipates that Australia's inflation rate could soon be down to just over 7 per cent. If this comes about our inflation rate will be similar to that of many of our trading partners in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. The report went on to say that this forecast is the result of the wage pause which was introduced by the Fraser Government some nine months to 12 months ago. This is all well and good if the governments and the Australian Council of Trade Unions sees fit to support this principle. But will they?

SPEECH.PARA: We now see the push for increased wages-increased wages for the haves, those people who are now protected in jobs. But the ACTU and the rest of the union system do not seem to concern themselves with those outside the system-the have nots, that group which is steadily growing and which is made up particularly of young people and other unfortunates. The Labor Government forecasts that the time is coming when some 10 per cent and more of the population will be unemployed. It seems to me that the electors have been taken for a ride because a major plank in the Australian Labor Party's platform was to attack unemployment. Last week we saw statements in the national Press that the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said that jobs are not on for all. The Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, is reported as saying that the working class ' should learn to retire early and see early retirement as a thing to look forward to rather than view it with ''absolute horror''.' They, the workers and certainly myself and no doubt all other senators on this side of the chamber would ask: 'Retire on what?' Where is the nest egg to bring about this to come from? Will it come from an increased number of unemployment benefit payments and from the age pension which is to be means tested? Mr Hawke also said last week that the easy years are over. It was not so long ago that we can remember hearing him jeering at the saying: 'Life wasn't meant to be easy'.

To my mind and to those of many people of Australia governments have become pessimists. But is this fair to Australians? I for one do not believe that we have to accept the role of being at the bottom of the barrel. I believe that there is good reason for us to live up to that motto that has been around for the last few years: 'Life. Be in it'. Many things can be done if the militant unions temper their demands. For instance, our goods could be better priced on national and international markets. New projects and industries can be created. One example is the construction of the rail link between Alice Springs and Darwin from which overseas trade alone, not to mention our main industries, must receive a fillip. Another example is the development of Australia's uranium mines, which is often mentioned in the Senate these days. Our vast pastoral and primary industries are ready to blossom again if costs in the areas of freight, fuel and so on can be contained. I believe that the world's markets desperately want Australian produce if they can afford it. Australia and its people can be lucky again if that is what they want.

Many honourable senators have spoken in this debate on various aspects of Australia. I am one of the few senators in this place who come from the remoter parts of Australia and as such most of my remarks will be directed to the people who live in that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Welcome to the club.

—I thank Senator Crichton-Browne. The honourable senator, whom I heard speak just recently, has a vast electorate in the outback to represent and he serves it well. I would like to look at the effects that increased freight charges are having on the Northern Territory. It is interesting to note that some settlements in the Northern Territory are so isolated that they have to depend on freight transport for everything. I am talking about barges that operate along the north coast, transport trucks that have to wend their way hundreds of miles inland, rail and aircraft. It is interesting to note that the Northern Territory Government is holding an inquiry into the cost of freight in the Northern Territory. I understand that the results of that inquiry will be made available to the Northern Territory Government, and no doubt to the Federal Government, in possibly January next year. This inquiry will be of the utmost importance if the problems of the people of the outback are to be recognised and if those people are to be given a fairer go than they are getting now.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to see some of the facts that have come out of submissions to the inquiry. For example, the shop manager at Angurugu-Angurugu is an Aboriginal settlement on Groote Eylandt-submitted that the shelf price of goods was between 75 per cent and 90 per cent higher than in Cairns or Brisbane. I am referring to a co-operative store on an Aboriginal settlement. No one can say that the margins charged there are high. They are set to cover costs only. The high prices were necessary because of the freight charges. For example, the freight cost for dry groceries is about 30 per cent to 37 per cent of the value of the goods. Fresh fruit and vegetables are flown in weekly from Katherine. The freight costs average 100 per cent of the value of the goods. I am referring to just some of the items which are mentioned in the submission.
