The shop manager indicated that on comparing his prices with those of Jack the Slasher in Cairns and prices in Brisbane, he found that his shelf prices were, as I said, 75 and 90 per cent higher. He indicated that the freight costs for dry groceries averaged between 30 per cent and 37 per cent. He indicated also that to fly in the vegetables and fruit from Katherine on a weekly basis brings up the cost by something like 100 per cent. This cost is obviously far too high for the people of the outback to have to endure, particularly now that we see the freight costs have been increased in this Government's Budget. The impact of the new excises on fuel contained in the August Budget is only now being fully appreciated. The increase of 1.5c a litre on diesel fuel excise is now being seen as particularly damaging to the tourist industry, an industry which employs many people. Not only is it the fastest growing industry in the Territory but also it promises to be a most important one. As I said, it will employ more people every year.

Recently compiled figures show that an average tour service bus travels some 38 ,500 kilometres carrying, on average, 4,054 passengers a year. The increase in the excise will cost each bus just on $500 per annum alone, a cost which the operators must absorb because their tariffs are set a year to 18 months in advance and they are locked into those fares. This further burden, far from encouraging tourism in the outback, will be a positive disincentive. The six- monthly rises in excise will compound the financial burden. The diesel fuel excise also affects remote tourist establishments, increasing their costs by up to $3,000 a year. Perhaps this may not seem very much for operators in the more populated parts of Australia, but they should bear in mind that the pioneers in the outback-they are still pioneers-live in extremely difficult situations. They have to pay higher fuel costs for the production of their own power and so on. They are in a most unenviable situation. This is a special worry because, since last year's Budget, those places have not been eligible for exemption from the diesel fuel excise.

Over the last few months the Federal Government has conducted an inquiry into the anomalies of the diesel fuel excise. I found it disappointing that, despite the best efforts of those in the outback and representations made by members on this side of the Senate on behalf of the tourist operators, no relief was given to people in the outback. I still cannot understand the situation. It is in sharp contrast to the Budget decision made in the wake of the review granting a $1m subsidy to Queensland's Great Barrier Reef island tourist resorts to relieve them of some of the financial burdens of the excise. Good luck to them. They have a problem of carrying fuel over water. The decision to give the Queenslanders this subsidy was made ostensibly, as I say, because of the high cost incurred in transporting the diesel over water to the island resorts. Yet territorians, the people of the outback who suffer crippling freight charges in transporting diesel fuel over large areas of land, received nothing. It appears to me that a State election may have had something to do with the situation. Perhaps I am being overcritical. I am most disappointed that the people in the outback have been so ignored. During the last few days we have heard much about the First Home Owners Bill, which provides a grant of $5,000 to many Australian citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seven thousand, Senator. Do not cheat us like that.

—If the figure is $7,000, I stand corrected. I believe that this legislation will be of considerable advantage to people on lower incomes. It will be of particular advantage to the people who live in the more populated areas. As I have said before, people who live in areas which have a higher cost of living, such as the Northern Territory, have to pay more for fuel, groceries and electricity. The cost of living in the Northern Territory is considerably higher than it is along the eastern seaboard, in the metropolitan areas, the major cities and so on. Because the average weekly income of a person working in the Northern Territory is slightly higher than it is for people in the States, but not the Australian Capital Territory, I believe the means test will exclude many of the people in the outback who should have the opportunity of receiving the grant. Perhaps the Governnment has not fully understood the situation. This situation might apply to only a few people-the population of the Northern Territory is only some 150,000. I must admit, compared with the population of Australia now, that is a very minute figure. But we must consider that people go there to develop the outback and the north. I think they should be given due regard for this.

SPEECH.PARA: In talking about the development of the north, as I am now, it is interesting to compare the latest growth figures of the Northern Territory with those of the States. Last year the population of the Northern Territory increased by some 5. 56 per cent. The Australian average increases in population was 1.71 per cent. This means that the Northern Territory is now growing at a rate that is more than 300 per cent higher than the Australian average. The State which experienced an increase closest to that of the Northern Territory was Queensland with 3.17 per cent. This means that the population in the Territory is growing at a rate that is almost double that of Queensland. The other States fall away to varying degrees, with Tasmania and South Australia experiencing no increase at all.

I have spoken briefly on various matters relating to the outback. I now speak about some funding of the Aboriginal population. I am pleased to see that in very many areas funding is increasing as demands require it. I refer to the community development employment projects scheme. This scheme seeks to bring employment to remote areas where employment conditions are at a low ebb. As we know, over the years there has been difficulty in that Aboriginal people have been unable to receive money on which to live and many of them have been in receipt of the unemployment benefit. The unemployment benefit is not particularly acceptable to many people on Aboriginal settlements. Many people believe that the payment of 'sit down money'-I also can well believe this-is detrimental to them; it takes the incentive out of life. As one old fellow said: 'The Government does not want us to work. It puts money into our hands for us to sit down.'

Over the years both governments have endeavoured to find another form of subsistence, and so the community development employment projects scheme was developed. This has now spread through the outback. I am not knocking this scheme but I suggest that the Government should look at it because I do not think that the Government or the Aboriginal people are receiving their money's worth from the vast amount of money that is being spent on it. Money should be spent on fishing, gardens, animal husbandry, abattoirs and all those things, but such projects appear not to be encouraged. If those projects were encouraged we would see more employment and better food for the people. Only last week I made a trip to Arnhem Land and I was told by the Aboriginal people that the CDEP scheme is now just another sideline of the unemployment benefit. Many people are being put on to the payroll of CDEP but never work. I think that is sufficient comment. I believe that the Government should take a very realistic look at this situation because the social problems that are growing there should not be encouraged.

One of the problems within the pastoral industry in the Northern Territory-this applies around Australia-relates to the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign. This has been going on for some years with the aim that by 1992 Australia should be free of brucellosis. In February 1983 the Australian Agricultural Council endorsed a plan to accelerate the campaign over a nine-year period, costing some $290m. The newsletter of the Northern Territory Cattle Council states:
The apparent lack of Commonwealth commitment to the eradication of brucellosis and tuberculosis casts a shadow of uncertainty over the future of the National BTEC scheme.

Frankly, I cannot understand what is happening. It was assessed by the authorities-that is, the Commonwealth authorities, the Northern Territory authorities and the cattle organisations-that, for example, in the Northern Territory some $112m was required for a comprehensive and accelerated program of eradication. But I see now that the Northern Territory allocation is $19.1m, or 86 per cent below the amount endorsed by the AAC. Also, the original funding for BTEC was intended to be 75 per cent Federal Government and 25 per cent Northern Territory Government. It now appears to be a 50-50 situation. The point I make is that for Australia's good this campaign must be accelerated. If people could see the situation in the north now, with vast numbers of cattle and buffalo living in uncontrolled situations, they would ask how on earth Australia could be free of brucellosis by 1992. If we are not free of brucellosis by 1992, what will happen to our world markets? We have only a few years in which to succeed in this eradication campaign. It is not an easy job. In fact, Australia has to make an all-out effort now to be free of brucellosis by 1992. Much has to be done, but the only way it can be done-naturally the pastoral industry will participate in the funding-is for the onus to be on the Federal Government, conjointly with the States, to bring about a much more comprehensive program than is being anticipated now.

In the past few weeks much mention has been made of the disappointment following the Budget announcement that the railway link to Darwin from Alice Springs is not to be continued. I am heartened to some degree that at least the planning and surveying of the route continues. I think that some $5m is being made available so that within the year the planning for the line will be ready. At the moment I believe some 100 people are involved in this planning aspect. The Labor Premier of South Australia and the Country Liberal Party Chief Minister of the Northern Territory have both gone to the Federal Government to indicate what will happen following the construction of the line. For instance, tourism in Darwin will increase by 176 per cent. This is real development of the north. A minimum of 2,000 jobs will be created as a direct result. Actual construction of the railway is expected to increase gross domestic product by between $163m and $352m.

It is interesting to note that last week the Aboriginal people, particularly those along the planned track, indicated their support for the route. It will run through part of the Warlmanpa claim area. The traditional owners have said that the land will be available to the Government for the construction of the line. I hope that, at the end of the inquiry that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is now bringing about, the Federal Government will understand and believe that the time has come for the line to be constructed.

I was disappointed to hear that defence was not included in the terms of reference. I believe that if we are to envisage the rail link as a viable project, defence must play a very real part; it would be a major customer of such a line. I turn briefly to the defence of Australia. People of the north and the outback are perhaps more aware of the necessity for greater northern defence because many people are still alive who were bombed, straffed and harassed by the Japanese during the Second World War. Many hundreds of people in Darwin and on the northern part of our coastline were killed. They look with considerable concern at the various projects that are still being considered by the Federal Government. I cite Tindal and the necessity of a full scale project for the FA18 fighters, the replacement aircraft for No. 75 Squadron which has just returned from Butterworth to Darwin and is a most essential part of northern defence. The Jindalee over-the-horizon radar is an amazing project developed by Australian scientists. While situated in the middle of the continent, it can actually locate aircraft and vessels way out in the Indian Ocean. But this project at the moment seems to be held up. The project which was brought about earlier to test the system has been proved. It now needs funding to bring it into an active situation.

The patrol boat base in Darwin is a very important project. It has been completed in the last year or so. New patrol boats have been constructed in Cairns and are now patrolling the northern coastline. It is a very sophisticated patrol boat base and is working well. I commend the planners. If one visits the area one can see that there are areas of deep water for extra wharfage for other boats. I believe the time has now come to conjointly construct that extra wharfage with other defence projects and provide for the new FFG destroyers that will be delivered to Australia in a few years. What could be more natural than for base and wharfage facilities to be made available at the top of Australia so that our latest destroyers can be maintained and victualled for patrolling the Indian Ocean?

Very briefly, I deplore the fact that the Government has seen fit to decrease the intake of secondary and tertiary overseas students and to raise the fees for the students by $400 to $2,900. I believe this is wrong and is a short sighted approach. We should be assisting these people from South East Asia. We should encourage them to go into the universities of Australia. I believe that because of this a further university should be established in Darwin. I believe that by doing that we will ensure that in future those people to whom we are now leaning more and more will have a greater appreciation of Australia and become part of Australia. In fact, it is interesting to note that people who, over the last few years, can be considered friends of Australia from South East Asia and the Pacific include Singapore's Minister for National Development, Ministers of the Fijian Government, the King of Tonga and other people who now communicate with Australia in so many ways, and who have been educated in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those listening to this debate recently may be surprised that we are debating the Budget. The convention is that honourable senators can raise all kinds of matters in this debate. I wish to concern myself with some aspects of the Budget. I feel that one of the great inadequacies of the Budget is that it has failed to take sufficient notice of the need to provide for the unemployed. Australia's huge unemployment rate has become a cliche. It is dangerous to the extent that people are now beginning to take it for granted and do not understand that we are, to an extent, not only losing a large proportion of a new generation of young people who are the best educated generation we have ever had in this country, but also that many other people later on in their lives, in their forties and fifties, who have lost their jobs and have not been able to find new ones are facing a degree of frustration which is deplorable. This is a social problem which has vast consequences for this country. It is not good enough simply to say that unemployment will go on.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that we have underway now important areas of temporary relief under the community employment program. But these can do nothing to solve the overall problem. They provide short term work only. I think the Government must be given credit to the extent that it is providing that and that there is a training element in this area so that, at least, young people will be trained for a few months in some kind of new skill, albeit a not very advanced one. Their problem after that, of course, is to find work and to put those skills to use. Here, of course, we reach the crunch.

The unemployment problem certainly looms massively enough. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, said yesterday that the problem is that somehow we must create as many as 120,000 new jobs every year just to maintain employment at its present rate. This, of course, is because of the rapid growth of the labour force. The Minister said yesterday also that he felt things were on the improve which he defined as a gradual turnaround that will become clearer as the year goes on. In this respect the Minister reminds me of the canoeist who lost his paddle, was drifting towards a waterfall and was hoping for a wind to get up to blow him back to safety. The Government seems to have the naive hope that things will improve all by themselves although the Government has also warned the community that, on its present program of activity, there will continue to be mass unemployment for many years to come. The Australian Democrats believe that that is the coldest possible type of comfort for the unemployed. We do not believe it is good enough. I want to use this occasion to discuss what, perhaps, might be done about it. In doing so I will look at several matters which were part of the Democrats' alternative Budget which was presented earlier this year and which raised a large number of innovative and interesting ideas in many areas of government.

The second major inadequacy of the Budget seems to be the Government's failure to understand that new jobs can be created most easily by encouraging completely new and innovative industries and that there is little point in continuing to train people for occupations already overcrowded. This seems to be a point of basic importance which should inform our national policies. It is absurd that we should be going on with university courses which are training large numbers of people in the professional fields which we now know will be overcrowded for years to come. What can we possibly hope to achieve by that kind of attitude? We need, of course, a master indicative plan for the economy that will identify new areas of possible endeavour, especially in the languishing manufacturing industry which has shed job opportunities year after year for many years at a catastrophic rate in Australia. Again it is a major task for the Government to change that and to provide the climate where it can change.

In that regard I was interested to notice that at the technology summit last week the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was reported as saying that we needed to get into new technology all right but the approach of business and academics to that so far had been pathetic. That may well be true, but here again we find that curious naivete that somehow industry will get into these magic new technologies all by itself. I doubt whether that can reasonably be so. It is a fact that the new technologies are, to a large extent, interdependent. For instance, the development of new successful and massive solar power stations in the United States of America in recent years and the planning of even larger ones up to the hundred megawatt range, which is a pretty big sort of power station, has been due to advances in computer science. The two industries, and indeed a third, the development of more and more sophisticated microchips, go together. They are interdependent. That has to be recognised first. The second major point is that Australian business at the moment is very demoralised. The new sunrise industries are very expensive and rather risky to get into. Money is short and nobody is in the frame of mind to risk huge sums of it on isolated enterprises that might well turn out to be damp squibs.

If the Government does not think that it has a special responsibility to the nation at this time to provide an informed, accurate and comprehensive framework within which industry and investors can operate in the fields of these new technologies then it is time it realised that it has that responsibility. The accident of the ballot box, or perhaps the deliberation of the voter, has put this Government in control of the country at a crucial stage at which we must make rapid changes, at which we must face up to the necessity that new things are going to have to happen, and soon, not in one year's time or 10 years time or 15 years time. It will be too late then.

This accurate, informed and comprehensive framework should be the work of our Department of Science and Technology, which at present is a mish mash of various loosely assorted, vaguely scientific organisations which have been brought together under a sort of umbrella and which as far as we can see from results so far has little sense of direction. I am not criticising that Department or its employees. What is needed now is a well organised technology task force which can enlist people from business, from the universities and from the Public Service expressly to find out what industries are most suitable for new opportunities in Australia, which can be naturally associated in the sense of assisting each other so that they are complementary, and the basic financial nitty gritty behind this. That task force should now be a major and urgent priority of the Government. As I have said here before, the Government is lucky. It has a man in charge of science and technolgy, the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, who has a deserved reputation for intelligence, breadth of vision and imagination.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a good memory.

—And a good memory, yes. It would seem to me that his main problem so far is that the Government is trying to duck out on the undoubted truth of a lot of the things he has to say. I can understand the Government's problem because a lot of things the Minister has said in his book and elsewhere, and the Australian Democrats say them too, are unpalatable. There is going to be change, there is going to have to be a big alteration in community attitudes, union attitudes, and government attitudes. The Australian Democrats advise the Government: 'Give Mr Jones his head. Let him tackle the necessary and urgent task of getting Australia into new job creating and wealth producing technologies'. I believe that this Government will in the long term be regarded by history as having been either a failure or a success on the extent to which it succeeds or otherwise in that job.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot repeat too often that a hit and miss, ad hoc approach to new technology would be a disaster of the worst order. We need to know clearly where we are going as a nation, what areas of industry we can reasonably specialise in , what the markets for such products would be, the basic economics of that, and the extent to which government can reasonably assist industry with research grants, subsidies and tax concessions. I suggest that even the announcement of a positive approach of this kind would give everyone in Australia, from the financiers through business to the work force, the growth in confidence we now need to break through in what we hope will be an improving but still highly competitive world scene.

I discussed these thoughts with a senior executive of a major Australian insurance company only yesterday. That company happens to be one of our major investors. His response was: 'Yes, you are absolutely right. We have been thinking along those lines for some time. You can take it from me that business cannot and will not wade into the cold water of innovation without some kind of national framework of guidance.' It is a fact, of course, that in virtually every country where new and innovative industries are being developed that framework is being provided. I suggest that the Government should get this technology task force going and that its first job should be to consult with Australian business and finance houses to see what parameters they feel they can operate within. We do not want an ivory tower. We do not want a group of people going off in a huddle at some summit or other somewhere, as with the technology summit last week, and saying: 'This is great. This is a good old boys situation and maybe we will have another one like it in a year's time.' That is the last thing we want. We want something that gets down to practicalities right from the start.

Having done that, the Government can then see how it can approach the matter to meet other long term community needs. For instance, it is high time we recognised that all kinds of things-fuels, metals and other minerals-are fast running out. New energy industries are an obvious area for urgent study, and they are being urgently studied in a major way in virtually every country except Australia, where the amount of expertise devoted to them is pitiably small and where we do not even seem to understand what is going on in the rest of the world. We still get people standing up in this place and saying: 'Solar energy is airy fairy. Wind energy is just for the future. It is science fiction stuff'. That is nonsense. These things are working extremely well in other countries, and they are a major source of attention in countries such as Japan and the United States of America, where people are not exactly silly in areas of business.

The basic tenet of the philosophy of the Australian Democrats is that we must create a sustainable society in Australia, as indeed must be done everywhere else in the world. Eventually and inevitably, everything we use must be renewable. It is high time governments, including the Government here, devoted themselves to that thought, not just paying lip service, but in reality. To this end we feel it is imperative that more funding be provided for research into renewable energy sources. This is a matter of urgency as our fossil fuels are being consumed at an exponential rate. The present glut of oil products, which perhaps reassures us, is artificial and will be short lived: We can be sure of that. In another five or six years there will be another petrol crisis. One shot fired tonight in Riyadh, the Saudi Arabian capital, and this country would be in grave trouble within three months-very grave trouble. That is all it would take. We are as dependent as that on events overseas.

An increase in research funding, although vital, is not the only necessity if our dependence on non-renewable energy sources is to be broken. We must actively encourage all consumers in the use of renewable resources. These new endeavours would, of course, create whole areas of new employment. Solar energy technology has advanced to such a stage that it is a viable commercial proposition, the use of which could be enormously increased if users were allowed a tax deduction or rebate on the cost of the installation of solar hot water heaters, an established known technology already in production in Australia, as is the case in California in the United States, where a 55 per cent tax credit is allowed for the installation of approved solar or wind energy systems. By the end of this year the SolarCal Council, a technology guidance body formed for the special purpose and with which I have been in close touch, expects that there will be 200,000 solar heaters and 150,000 solar space conditioning installations in California. New government buildings in California which have floor space exceeding 10,000 square feet are required by law to use solar hot water heaters. Existing government buildings are being converted to solar heating. By 1985 this program is expected to save 15 per cent of the oil and gas California would otherwise have had to import and-this is the interesting point-to employ about 30,000 people of all levels of skill and experience, from skilled to unskilled.

It can be demonstrated that such a program could be introduced into Australia just as easily, and that it would dramatically increase employment at an even rate through all Australian cities and towns, not only industrial centres, because this would be a regional requirement. The experience is available for the asking. All we have to do is go to California and ask for its experience. There is no difficulty about it. There is no possibility that it will not work. There is absolutely no risk, and it would immediately put young people and others in Australia into employment. It would also have the valuable merit of starting the trend toward renewable energy, which we know has to come if we are not all going to rush eventually into mass suicide through sheer deprivation.

By 1990, according to the Petroleum Gazette, which is an industry paper, Australia's oil demand is predicted to be 120 million litres a day. Less than half of that will come from known fields. By the year 2000, 134 million litres a day will be used, on current projections, and only 27 million litres will be available from current fields. Self-sufficiency in oil will drop from about 68 per cent now to 43 per cent in 1990, and to 20 per cent by the year 2000. We hope that major new finds of oil will come, but that cannot of course be relied on. It is not a safe basis on which to proceed into the future.

I visited the United States last year and was greatly reassured to find a general renunciation of nuclear energy, which is widely seen in that country now as being dangerous and uneconomic. Of course, the reason why so many utilities are cancelling their orders for nuclear plants-even some which have put tens of millions of dollars already into the projects-is that it is seen now as not a viable source of investment for the future. I also found, to my great pleasure, a genuine practical effort to turn to other means, which we in this country could reasonably emulate. I visited the world's largest solar power station, Solar I in the Mojave Desert, 50 miles east of Los Angeles. Its operations are automated and computerised to the extent that its needs, including maintenance, can be met by a staff of three. While the sun is shining, Solar I produces 12 1/ 2 megawatts of electricity, enough for a fairly large town, and this daytime solar running can provide power for 6,000 households.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.
(Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I had urged the Government to set up a special task force on technology which would be designed to research new areas of high technology industries that could enable a significant breakthrough to be made in Australia's ailing manufacturing industry , and which would be a major source of new jobs. I suggested this on the basis of the axiom that it is useless to train people for areas of work which are already overcrowded although, surprisingly enough, we are in Australia still training people for areas of work which are overcrowded. It is only an indication of the extent to which habit becomes part of national routines.
—And people's choice.

—Indeed, and people's choice, but there again I would suggest that it should be part of the Government's role to suggest to people that they are being trained in areas in which they have no reasonable chance of finding work in the future. I went on to say that new jobs could be provided by new and innovative technologies but that it was the Government's job to research a feasible framework for Australia in this direction, so that we would get a collection of new technologies which, as I said, tended to be interdependent, dependent on each other, and complementary, which would be a goer and which would not expect industry to do one-off expeditions into higher technology which would not work.

SPEECH.PARA: I instanced the state of California's SolarCal Council as a model for such a task force. The SolarCal Council has been responsible for a number of years for a conversion of the State of California to an effective use of tried areas of solar technology. It has succeeded brilliantly in that and has, amongst other things, created 30,000 jobs which did not exist before in these new areas of technology. At the same time, of course, it has also made things easier for the United States of America in the long term, because it has reduced substantially the demand for non-renewable areas of industry.

When I visited the United States last year I was greatly reassured to find a general renunciation of nuclear power, which is now widely seen in that country as dangerous and uneconomic with orders for new nuclear power houses being cancelled regularly, even where large sums of money, as much as tens of millions of dollars, have already been invested because it is seen as dangerous, uneconomic and in no way a suitable source of power for the future. Associated with that I found a genuine practical effort in the United States to turn to other means of power generation. When I visited the world's largest solar power station, as I know a number of other senators have done, that is Solar I in the Mojave Desert near Los Angeles, I found a remarkable, almost space age, technology there actually in operation. Its operation is automated and computerised to the extent that its needs, including maintenance, can be met by a staff of three.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the space age, Senator.

—Indeed, it is the space age. But one would not know it in Australia. The extent to which we are exploring these new technologies in this country is deplorably low. We seem to think this is still far into the future, a sort of science fiction, when every other advanced society is well into research and getting practical things going on the ground.

SPEECH.PARA: Solar I is a perfect example of that. It produces 12 1/2 megawatts of electricity and on this daytime running Solar I can provide enough power for 6, 000 households. So it is obviously a sensible type of installation for decentralised use for relatively small country towns which are, nevertheless, communities of considerable size. At night-that peak period that comes after dark, when the requirement for power is, of course, still there-a thermal storage unit retains surplus heat attracted during the day, and enables Solar I to go on producing seven megawatts of power, almost half its daytime capacity, for four hours. Of course, at that time the demand for power starts to fall off. The storage unit consists of nearly 7,000 tonnes of rock and sand and a quarter of a million gallons of a type of oil specifically developed as an efficient heat exchanger. All that technology, of course, is tried and established. It is available to Australia if we want it, but apparently we do not. We prefer to live at the tail end of the old industrial era and we will have to be carried kicking and screaming into the new one.

It is of interest that a second similar power station is being built nearby by a private enterprise corporation which is so confident that it has already contracted to supply solar power to California's major supply authority at a lower price than that of power generated by burning fossil fuels, or nuclear power stations. That technology has been backed up by another completely new industry, a huge factory which will do nothing but manufacture mirrors for solar power houses. That again is another source of employment. Those are the sorts of innovations which I suggest that the Government's new task force on technology- if and when we ever get it-should look at.

Wind power is being seriously studied in Hawaii and is actually in use in a number of small scale operations such as businesses and cattle ranches. The lesson there is that perhaps the very huge wind generator is not necessarily a good thing, but that something about the 55 kilowatt range, which can supply a number of communities, is a viable alternative. However, I did visit the largest of these generators, a joint National Aeronautics and Space Administration and Department of Energy project, which generates 220 kilowatts of power. It has functioned very successfully for a number of years and operates most of the time quite automatically without any regular staffing whatsoever.

Plans are in preparation quite near that site, on the island of Oahu, for a much larger facility, a wind farm of 20 machines which will produce a total of 80 megawatts. Accordingly, it is a facility which is comparable with the late lamented Gordon below Franklin Dam in Tasmania. This is very important because research has already shown that the west coast of Tasmania is probably the world 's best area for wind generators for electric power. I must suggest to Mr Robin Gray that when he gets all his money from the Commonwealth in compensation, he might look at that not only as a means of providing power to Tasmania but also as a means of enabling Tasmania to become an area of manufacture of such machines which could then be exported to other parts of Australia and, indeed, to other parts of the world, because there is a rapidly growing market for such things.

What I have said indicates above all a great need for rapid change in community attitudes and responses. That is a matter also for the Government to do a public relations job of sufficient conviction to persuade people that this change is necessary, as indeed it is. The Australian Democrats do not believe that any change should be applied dictatorially by governments. Such things must come in consultation with the community itself. Government must involve people more and increase the ordinary citizen's share in the process of government. Only in this way shall we achieve an impetus sufficient to make the rapid changes which are necessary. To that end I again urge honourable senators to think carefully about and to support the concept of electors initiative, citizen initiated referenda, which, as honourable senators will know, I put forward originally in my maiden speech here nearly five years ago, as a private member's Bill. The present system which restricts the right to initiate law in the Parliament is, as I have said before in this place, an anachronism in this day and age, and it must go. This is an idea whose time has come. The sooner we face up to that, the better.

The relevance of our present sytem to the nineteenth century may have existed, but it is no longer enough for a free and highly educated people who are very much more interested in public affairs than their predecessors were to have the right to elect one party or another to government and to have no real control over the legislation process beyond that. I do not suggest that every piece of legislation should be handled in this way; I mention only those areas of great importance to the community, controversial areas, areas of vital concern. To that end I have proposed a system whereby any petition carrying no fewer than 250,000 signatures would be put to referendum with other such petitions once a year. If carried, they would become law without any sanction from parliament.

Earlier I mentioned the SolarCal Council and events in California. It is significant that this system, the citizen initiated referendum, has been part of the means of government in California from the beginning of this century. Indeed , other States such as Washington and those States in the United States which have this means, in virtually rallying, conscripting and organising public opinion to their requirements, have been a much greater success than those that do not have it. I would say that the classic example of this is to be found in Switzerland, where 25 per cent of a very adequate defence budget-the Swiss have very good armed forces for their size-is allocated to civil defence, so that the Swiss, unlike us, have the best defence against possible nuclear attack of any country in the world. The interesting thing about that is that it was brought into operation in 1962 as a result of a citizen initiated referendum. The people know what they want and they know where their best interests are. It is a perfect case in point.

In the time remaining to me, I should like to describe an employment scheme which has been in use in the United States of America in various forms since 1933 and which the Australian Democrats wholeheartedly support and recommend to the Government as a unique and extremely useful way of alleviating the problems of youth unemployment and the slow but certain destruction of our natural environment. The American Conservation Corps, as it is now called, seeks to provide employment and training opportunities for young men and women, particularly those who are disadvantaged and living in areas of high unemployment, in labour-intensive projects accomplishing the conservation, rehabilitation and improvement of natural and cultural resources located on public or Indian lands. The projects include forestry, nursery and silvicultural operations-including reafforestation, which, heaven knows, we need badly enough, as anyone who has driven through the New England plateau and seen the depredations of die-back will know-wildlife habitat conservation, rangeland conservation, recreational area development, fisheries assistance, road and trail maintenance, pollution control, fire prevention, insect and rodent control , energy conservation projects, and reclamation of strip-mined lands, among many other possibilities.

This program provides a preference for those projects which provide long term benefits to the public-these are the guidelines, and I suggest that our Government note them-provide interesting work experience to those involved and useful work experience in the sense of the training element, and are labour- intensive and can be planned and initiated promptly. Even with the community employment program, I suggest that those should be the guidelines. Accommodation , meals and medical care are provided, and those involved are paid no less than the wage required by the United States Fair Labour Standards Act 1939. In addition, up to 10 per cent of available funds are used to provide education services and materials for academic study during non-working hours to upgrade literacy and numeracy skills, to allow the young people in the program to finish high school, to obtain a university degree or to enhance their present employable skills.

I know that there is trouble over this with the unions. Our union movement, which I regard as one of the most conservative in the world-one of the most conservative forces in the world, not just one of the most conservative union movements-a true conservative group, does not want this. It is perfectly happy to let young people go on in desperation and without jobs as long as those with jobs can keep them. I should have thought that it was the task and opportunity of the Labor Government to persuade the unions differently and, please, to persuade them that some sort of scheme such as this, which would give our young people an opportunity for the future, could come into being. That is one of the two or three major tasks that I have outlined in talking about the Budget tonight which I see as necessary, and historically, for this Government, occupying the treasury bench as it does at this time, to carry out. As I have said, the Government will be judged by history on the extent to which it can successfully carry Australia through this period of change or fail to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in this Budget debate, I should like to say that Labor's handling of the economy, whether it be at Federal or State level, is best measured by the price of fuel at the bowser. On 16 February 1983 the then Leader of the Opposition said:

SPEECH.PARA: As part of Labor's anti-inflation package, and in recognition of the burden of extra taxation levied by the Government on people affected by the wage freeze, Labor will reduce the price of petrol by cancelling the January 1 oil price increase of $3.23 per barrel. This will have the effect of reducing the price by 3c a litre. It will reduce the consumer price index by half of one point.

Furthermore, the then shadow Minister for Primary Industry, now the Minister representing the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in this place, Senator Walsh, said on 28 February in a Press statement that petrol prices would be immediately cut by about 3c a litre and that liquefied petroleum gas prices would be cut by 1.5c a litre when Labor became the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a promise, too.

—There are many broken promises. I shall mention a few of them later. In Queensland every Australian Labor Party candidate, from far flung Kennedy right through to urban McPherson, campaigned on the emotional issue of 'petrol cuts'. Labor has now been in power for seven months, and none of us has seen any sign of those petrol price cuts. What we have seen is an increase in the price of fuel, in other words, taxes through extra fuel prices.

SPEECH.PARA: Today in the Senate, Senator Gerry Jones from Queensland, presented loaded notices of motion against the Queensland Government. I point out that the Queensland Government has the best economy in Australia. It has a balanced Budget. It does not have a deficit-not very much, anyway; not by comparison with the deficits in some of the other States. There is a $40m deficit in New South Wales, and Victoria too, has quite a big deficit. In Queensland Mr Keith Wright, the Leader of the Opposition, has made a lot of promises, hoping that Labor would come to power on 22 October. But if he thinks, as he has said, that there is a deficit in Queensland, it is a wonder to me that he made all these promises . It is a wonder that he did not say: 'I cannot do anything because there is a deficit and it is not possible to make all these promises'. But certainly he will not have an opportunity to keep his promises in any case. The people of Queensland can see for themselves the progress and development that has taken place in our State.

As a matter of fact, 700 people a week know the progress and development that is taking place in Queensland. On Monday of this week the Sydney Morning Herald contained an article by Jenny Tabakoff called 'Monday' which told of a tropical paradise and about a chap by the name of Jim who used to drive interstate trucks for 18 years, often driving for days at a time. Then he would go home to his family, but he did not have much spare time because he was continually driving these big transports. Then, she said, he saw the light-the clear Queensland light-and he drove north with his wife, his children and his dog in the family car. Now he works an eight-hour day, lives by the beach, hates Melbourne, distrusts the south and loves Queensland. As I have said before, there are 700 people a week doing the same thing. Honourable senators might say that that is because of the good climate there. I maintain that God gave the climate to Queensland when he made the world. To my way of thinking, it has taken people the last 10 years to decide that the climate in Queensland is good for them to come in such numbers. It is the political climate that is so good in Queensland and the tremendous development that is taking place there. It is the most decentralised State in Australia.

I should like to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that there is no doubt that Queensland is the lowest taxed State in Australia. Nobody can deny that. There are no State gift duties or death duties. We do not have to pay road permit fees in Queensland. We do not have a State tobacco tax. Neither do we have a State fuel tax, which ever so many States have. We have the highest exemption level for payroll tax and we have the lowest third party insurance premiums. Most certainly we do not have that iniquitous financial institutions duty that has been imposed on so many people throughout Australia. I cannot understand why Senator Gerry Jones cannot produce sensible notices of motion to help the people of Queensland. Why can he not produce a notice of motion asking his Labor Government when it intends to give Australians fuel price cuts instead of increases?

Labor's record on fuel prices is a sorry one. In the May mini-Budget it increased the excise on aviation fuel by 2c a litre. The cost to the aviation industry was $15m. It abolished the special depreciation allowance for petrol storage. In 1983-84 it decreased, at a cost of $10m, the subsidy payable under the petrol products freight subsidy scheme. Then in the August Budget the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme was cut back to save $2m. It removed the sales tax exemption for oil fuels and lubricants. It increased by 1.5c, or 2c at the bowser, the excise on petrol and diesel fuel for tractors. This is a rather sad and sorry story, I am afraid. It also increased the excise on aviation fuel by 0.5c a litre on top of the 2c a litre increase in May. As I said, it is a sorry record. Labor has increased the cost of every kind of transport fuel it can find. In other words, the voters were ambushed.

I am sad to say that State Labor governments have also been using the petrol bowser to prop up ailing State economies. Queensland is the only State where there is no petrol tax. In 1982, in New South Wales and Victoria, the tax on petrol was 3.02c a litre for super and 2.95c for standard. The people of Queensland certainly will not want a new direction that will mean State taxes on fuel. They will realise that a State Labor Government would mean broken promises , just as we have seen from the Federal Government. The Federal Government started out by promising 500,000 new jobs. It promised that there would be no increases in taxes. I have just been talking to the Senate about the increased taxes that have arisen through the increased fuel prices. Instead of having lower petrol prices we have higher fuel prices. The Labor Government said there would be no superannuation tax. We all know the sad story about that. There is a 30 per cent superannuation tax. We have seen evidence of the effect of that-the airline pilots strike over the last couple of days.

The Government also promised that it would not hurt pensioners. We know exactly what has happened to them. It was estimated that the initial 1.5 per cent increase in fuel excise would yield $300m. The federal taxes on petrol and diesel fuel will raise more than $4,600m. That certainly ought to help to reduce the deficit that the Labor Party keeps telling us it faced when it came to power . Everybody-families, businessmen, rural people-will be hit by the fuel tax. In fact, as far as rural peolple are concerned, the more they travel-distances are very great in this country-the more they will have to pay by way of fuel tax. People who go on holidays also have to pay excessive prices now for their fuel. The airlines have had to put up their fares because of the rise in aviation fuel and of course that hits tourism. There is no doubt about that. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Mr John Brown, promised a tax deduction for people holidaying in Australia. I feel that it would have been much better if he had decided that deductions would apply to firms which would provide jobs for people rather than what he has suggested. Of course, in Queensland Labor has come out with the idea of one vote one value for rural people to take away representation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh! How appalling! What next!

—In Western Australia it is one to seven. Certainly in Queensland it is a lot less than that. Somebody ought to look at the gerrymander in New South Wales. When Labor got into power in New South Wales it amalgamated country shires. That is something that I am sure the people in the country in New South Wales are not very happy about. I think that people should think about equal representation for people who live in the country. I want to get back to the problems that have been caused by the increase in the cost of petrol and oil . This will mean increases in the cost of a whole range of goods and services.
—Why don't they drive hydrogen cars?
—The road transport industry, under threat, will have to pass on the costs to consumers which, of course, will result in substantial increases in road haulage rates, from 8 per cent to 15 per cent.
—Use the trains.

—In Queensland, to run the trains we have to use diesel fuel and the cost of diesel fuel has also gone up, thanks to the Labor Government. Honourable senators on the Labor side of the House do not like what I am saying, so they have to keep on talking about it. Housing will also be affected. Road transport's input into housing costs is about five per cent. Indexation of excise will build in automatic increases. I feel that the decision to index petrol was certainly very ill-conceived. To me it was actually a very sneaky sort of tax. It will be increased every six months. It will be indexed without any announcement about it. Every six months people will have to pay more for petrol. This will react, I am sure, against the Labor Party at the Queensland election on 22 October. Primary producers are the biggest users of fuel in the world and the Budget has certainly placed a greater share of the burden on the primary industry sector. Actually, outlays for the agricultural and pastoral industries in the 1983-84 Budget fell by nearly 10 per cent whereas the overall Budget outlay increased by 16 per cent and assistance to the manufacturing sector is up 30 per cent. It is certainly easy to see that this Government is anti-rural.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget makes a complete mockery of the Treasurer's statement. In his Budget Speech, he said:
We have sought to share the burden of extra taxation fairly through the community so that nobody, other than blatant tax avoiders, is expected to make major sacrifices.

That is something that we ought to remember and think about. Increased freight charges, because of the rise in excise and indexation, will impose a heavy burden on the cost of goods in country towns. Food prices could rise by up to five per cent. I think this all proves that rural people will have to bear an unfair share of extra taxation through fuel tax rises.

According to the Budget statement, farm incomes fell by 53 per cent in 1982-83- the largest fall in 30 years-due to costs rising more rapidly than product prices. Having said that, what does Labor do? It increased the excise on petrol and distillate, and indexed it. Labor does not understand practical rural Australia. Labor thinks it is the farmer's friend but its damning policies condemn it as far as the rural sector is concerned. Certainly it calls itself the farmer's friend but I do not think, from what I have told the Senate, that that is quite right. The increase in the price of diesel by 1.5c per litre will also be reflected in rail freight charges and that, of course, will be a tax upon a tax. It will increase the cost of transporting coal from mines to ports, which will make it harder for mines to compete on the export market. People need only to look at the fuel bowsers to remind them of Labor's disastrous policies in this connection.

The tourist industry will be particularly hit by the increased excises and their indexation. Tourism contributes $2.2 billion to Queensland's economy. There is an annual growth rate in the industry of 7.4 per cent in Queensland compared with the national average of 1.6 per cent. Tourism is the immediate cash flow to north Queensland and, to a great extent, it helps the north. What about removing the fuel excises and their six-monthly indexation to encourage tourism and give cheaper holidays rather than give tax deductions to Australians who holiday within Australia? The best thing I could suggest to the Government would be to drop fuel excises altogether. That would be the best tax decrease possible for everyone, particularly people in Queensland which has such vast wide open spaces and where people have to travel such distances. People in Queensland use a lot of fuel.

The fuel tax strikes at the heart of the family budget. I suppose one could say that fuel is one of the necessities of life. Tax on fuel affects every aspect of the family budget. Nothing escapes it. Some people have to travel perhaps 15 kilometres to work. It is estimated that those people will have to pay an extra $2.20 per week. Of course, outings at the weekend will cost more. These facts prove that the increases in fuel prices will have a disastrous effect on Australia's economy.

Much has been said about the Government's reintroduction of the pension income test and the interpretation thereof. I suppose this Government has blamed everybody but itself for the misunderstanding and misinterpretation in the community about the test. Nowhere in the Budget Papers does it spell out that single pensioners may have up to $17,000 in savings accounts and married couples up to $28,500 and still be eligible for the maximum pension. I believe that this was a serious mistake by the Government. It has certainly caused a lot of anxiety and concern to the people who are involved. Even now, there still seems to be quite a deal of uncertainty. The income test certainly must be complicated if it has to have 1,500 staff to carry out the initial assessments and if it is to cost $35m to establish the system in the first year.
I want to say a few words about Medicare although I made a speech when the legislation to introduce it was before the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us again.

—I think it is a very good idea to reiterate some of the points I made on that occasion. The Budget is significant for what it does not say about Medicare. In Queensland there will be a shortfall of $21.2m as a result of the Federal Labor Government's failure to honour Medicare funding arrangements. Queensland submitted a case for extra funding of $36m. In fact, the Queensland Government considered its case was so sound that it included the extra funding in its 1983 Budget calculations. But the Federal Government allocated only $15m. Thus there is a shortfall of $21.2m. The Federal Labor Government is failing to recognise that Queensland has had a free hospital system for decades. By not providing it with compensation equal to that provided to the other States this Government is penalising Queensland for having maintained its free hospital system, which is unique in Australia.
—Introduced by a Labor government.

—I acknowledge that it was introduced by a Labor government and I wonder why the present Labor Government does not give the Queensland Government credit for having carried on the idea for all these years. I have never said anything about that. That system is now under threat. Labor has introduced a new one per cent tax to make Queenslanders pay for what they already receive for nothing. Public patients in Queensland are being discriminated against financially compared with what the Federal Government pays other States for their public patients. I am talking about making sure that we get our just dues in Queensland. I make it clear that all Queensland is seeking is recompense for public hospital patients equal to the per capita average being paid to the other States, that is, $50 per head and not $29. If the State's public hospital system is put in jeopardy through a lack of funding it will be solely the Federal Labor Government that is to blame. The Queensland Labor Party is so paranoid about not upsetting its Federal counterparts that it will not stand up and argue for Queensland's rightful allocation.

SPEECH.PARA: The first Budget of the Hawke Labor Government will long be remembered for the ruthless use of fuel as a taxing pool and for penalising Queensland for maintaining a free hospital system by allocating only $15m instead of the right compensation of $36m. The Budget initiatives which benefit Queensland are the State's entitlement. Queenslanders pay tax like everybody else and are not impressed by ministerial visits from time to time giving money here and there for projects as if they are gifts from Canberra. Many problems for Queenslanders are revealed in this Budget. Time alone will show not only Queenslanders but also Australians that the change in government in Canberra has not been to their advantage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this Budget-an admirable Budget that set out to advantage all Australians by setting in motion its program over this and the next two Budgets for fairness, equity and a re- ordering of priorities. It unashamedly sought to reallocate resources and direct assistance to those most in need and most disadvantaged in our community. Economic recovery will advantage all Australians better than any specific payments for the needy. Australians prefer to manage for themselves. They want work, economic independence and the dignity that goes with being able to make choices for themselves. I want to address the Budget in terms of its specific and general gains and advantages for women. I appreciate that this is a somewhat artificial and arbitrary analysis but as women are disproportionately represented by higher numbers in the categories of the disadvantaged, the unemployed and the poor this analysis has considerable value because it highlights the aims and gains of the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a balance-a needed balance-between spending on programs and containing the deficit. There has been a balance between provisions for the poorest and provisions for the other sectors in the community. I revert to a symbol I have used before-real regard has been given to the roses as well as the bread. The principal advantage for women in this Budget is that they have been recognised. There is an acknowledgment of women at all levels in the Budget. The major areas of impact in the Budget cover such things as health, social security , welfare, employment and training, and education. I will go through each one of those and consider it in relation to its particular gains for women. Honourable senators must understand, of course, that I am not suggesting that men are disadvantaged but I think there is some real value in emphasising how this Budget has addressed the needs of women.

This Government came into office with a policy specifically directed to women. That is no accident. The women in the Party over the last three to five years have been actively developing that program. The program is based very widely on consultation with many women throughout Australia. The policy is actually known to women and addresses their needs. I think that is reflected in how women's needs are part of every section of the Budget and are in all the major programs and policies. In fact, the Budget also emphasises and continues the beginning steps of an agreement of the National Economic Summit Conference to promote greater equality and independence for women. We also appreciate that that is a first step and we hope we will take more steps before the next election.

The Government has made major commitments to upgrading the status of women. I think the first emphasis of that can be seen in the move of the Office of the Status of Women to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Prime Minister's own Department, with improved resources and an upgrading of advice available to the Government. Further, the Government has established a Task Force of Permanent Heads on the Status of Women and this will mean that government administrators in all sections of government will not be able to overlook the perspective of women when looking at problems and solutions. It also will mean that women will have a part in contributing to those solutions that will be proposed. As well as that, an increased allocation has been provided in this Budget, from $32,000 to $60,000, for the Australian Council of Trade Unions Working Women's Centre, the National Council of Women of Australia, the Country Women's Association, the Women's Electoral Lobby and the Young Women 's Christian Association. I think that that range of women's groups needs to be borne in mind. It is yet another example of how wide ranging is this Government' s concern for women. It covers women from all spectrums in Australia. It is a point that the Opposition has completely failed to acknowledge or act upon.

The Government is also committed to increasing and broadening consultation with women and women's organisations. To this effect, some $376,000 will be made available in 1983-84 for a program of consultation, research and information on the status of women. Not only will we be talking about women and with women, but also money is set aside for the very important business of collecting data, doing the necessary research, and then providing ways of communicating that information, that education, to the community and to those people in government who will make decisions based on that research.

One area of very real interest to me is Medicare. If ever there was a piece of legislation that advantaged women it is the new Medicare legislation. Again I make the point that it advantages all Australians but, as I have said before, I am addressing myself to the particular gains for women. The Medicare legislation is particularly good for women. Principally it is good for women because of its general aims. It is an equitable, affordable, universal and simple health scheme , and for all of those reasons it will advantage women. It will also be a considerable help because it will, in its very establishment, contribute to the lowering of the consumer price index by some 2 1/2 per cent. Of course, that will have benefits across the board in terms of economic recovery as those benefits flow on.

The one per cent levy, which will be the cost to those people who have taxable incomes above the level of $128 for a single person and $214 for a couple, will mean that something like two-thirds of Australians, and probably more, will be paying much less for their basic health cover than they are currently paying. It also means that the estimated two million Australians who are currently uninsured will be covered against any possible medical expense or need for health care. The particular advantage of the one per cent levy, involving as it does a smaller amount of money per week for families, and in particular women, is that people will have money in their pockes to be spent on other things. That will, I think in a quite considerable way, contribute to a consumer led economic recovery.

One of the things I know from talking with women, and I am sure honourable senators opposite know this, is that when people are poor the first thing they go without is food. Secondly, they will go without their medicine. After that they will manage without heat and power. The last thing people want to give away is the basic shelter. They will somehow manage their rental or mortgage payments but they will find themselves living in a sort of undernourished half-starved way. Perhaps starving is too strong a word, but many people live without sufficient food. Even if it is only $8 a week in a family's pocket, that $8 will make an enormous difference to just the amount of food a family will eat. I exaggerate not at all; my work in the community health centre made that very clear to me. I also know that that is the experience of many of my colleagues who have been in the business of getting out and about and finding out what the real world is. It may seem a small amount of money to some of us, but for many people $8 a week might be 10 per cent of their income.

The other important part of Medicare that will advantage women is the better planning and use of one central computer for the collection of data. That will allow for better distribution of services, for the provision of services where the need is. Also, research and information will be valuable. For example, we have had experience and evidence of unnecessary surgery. The information that the number of hysterectomies in one part of the country is five times the national average is the sort of thing that I suppose could be said specifically to benefit women. Tonsils come in both sexes, but uteruses do not.

Another part of the health and Medicare platform that will be of advantage to women is the proposed establishment of an occupational safety and health commission. I am delighted that the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, has already allocated $100,000 a year to the Lidcombe Workers Centre for the next three years. That centre was one of the places that really started to collect the data , provide the information and do the necessary lobbying of people in the community who needed to know about the impact of rapid repetitive injury. They also can tell us that that is not an illness or a health problem that relates to high-tech or upmarket work; it is principally still a problem of the assembly line. That is where lots of poorer women, including migrant women, work and that is where they largely get that sort of illness. The community health program too is being funded under the Medicare scheme, at 1975 real levels as a start. There is also money set aside for initiatives in the community health program. Those of us who have worked in that community health program are aware of the impact of social conditions on the health of people and in particular on the health of women. The most impressive example of that is the effects of grinding poverty on ill health.

Further, the health policy specifically addresses itself to an aged care program, with increased money for planning and research grants. As women predominate in the older age groups in our community, these programs will particulatly advantage women. The grants have been increased from $1.5m in 1982- 83 to $3.4m in 1983-84. The aged care program, as with all the Government's programs, contains an element of money that will allow for research and better planning and the provision of services where there are old people. A lot of money and planning will be provided to establish assessment teams so that elderly folk will be enabled as much as possible to live out their lives at home , with domiciliary assistance and so on. Many people, in particular many women, are unable to do home maintainance tasks but to all other intents and purposes can live by themselves quite successfully. Jobs such as cleaning leaves from gutters or changing light bulbs can be difficult problems for older people. Services such as that can mean that people can continue to live in their homes, I might say very much more cheaply in terms of what it costs the Government. That is not necessarily the reason for the establishment of the aged care program; it has been established principally because this Government cares about people living in the place of their choice.

Enormous gains for women have been made in the social security and welfare area . Again, that is largely because of the enormous number of women in this country who depend on social security and welfare payments for their subsistance. I guess the first gain is the increase in the unemployment benefit. This is a sort of tragic gain, I suppose, because it points to the problems of so many women, particularly young women, in the unemployed category. There are more unemployed young women than young men and the percentage is horrifically high. But the other area of unemployment in our community which I think is lost often in assessment is the number of women in their late forties and fifties who are too young for an age pension, who no longer have dependent children and who have to somehow manage, particularly if they are living alone, on the unemployment benefit. It is a horrible vulgarity trying to manage on the unemployment benefit particularly when one actually suffers a loss of income as one's children leave home.

Further assistance to families in the Budget was specifically addressed to those families who are most needy. There has been an increase in the children's services program of $20.9m including $10m to new and expanded projects and new policy initiatives. This $10m will be increased to $30m in 1984-85. There have been specific assistance programs for poorer families. In particular the additional pension and benefits for children has been increased to $12 per week. Similar increases have been made in the family income supplement which will assist those families which are trying to survive on very low incomes. As well, sole parents, about 90 per cent of whom are women, will benefit from the extension of the mother's or guardian's allowance to recipients of sickness, unemployment and special benefits. I suppose it is a savage comment on our society that so many of these pension and welfare payments advantage women because of their disproportionate representation in those categories.

Perhaps on a more cheerful note, the housing assistance in the Budget will be of great benefit to women in particular because of the amount that will be put into public housing. The waiting lists of people for public housing, of course, again, include very large numbers of women. But, as well, families, particularly those with dependent children and in receipt of only modest incomes, will be eligible for the first home owners scheme. With the aim of so many Australians to have a home of their own, this, of course, will be of advantage to women.

In the area of assistance to handicapped people a new spouse carer's pension has been established which will allow a husband of an age, service or invalid pensioner wife to receive assistance on the same basis as the wife's pension. It is peculiar sometimes to find these little exceptions to the even-handed distribution of pensions to people performing a similar sort of service. I guess that redresses a peculiar imbalance that existed in this case.

Particular emphasis has been placed on assistance to migrants and grants in aid have been provided to migrant communities. Some of this money is specifically earmarked for migrant women. Again, those of us who have had the experience of working in the community with migrants will know that migrant women are disadvantaged in a particular way, very often because they are confined to home and therefore find it difficult to master the English language. They cannot participate in any real way in the community until they can speak the language. They sometimes seek work to try to supplement the family income and that work tends to be in the poorer paid, harsher work situations. I think the most important thing we can give migrant people is the opportunity to master English because when they can, many other things become easier to manage. In particular they can have access to rights that are available to other Australian people but which are not taken up if people do not know about them.

An amount of $550,000 has been provided to help establish child care services in association with the adult migrant education program. Again, that simply points to another real difficulty. If we fund programs that enable women to go to school but make no provision for the care of their children, then the whole exercise will be a hollow one. This Government has provided money for child care in association with the adult migrant education program.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about permanence for adult migrant education teachers?
—We have established it for those who have spent two years in the service. It has been fulfilled. It is there. Thank you for reminding us.
—Order!

—I thank the honourable senators for that contribution to the debate. Specific assistance has been given to Aboriginal peoples and in particular to Aboriginal women. Aboriginal women and communities will benefit from the expanded role given to the National Aboriginal Conference and the expansion of existing programs in the fields of employment, health, legal aid and community management.
—And education, Senator.

—And education. I thank the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. In particular these programs will be addressed to Aboriginal fringe dwellers who sometimes miss out in mainstream Aboriginal funding. The Government has also established an Aboriginal women's task force. This group will essentially consult with Aboriginal women to find out what their needs are and to let them have a say in what is the best way in which to respond to those needs.

SPEECH.PARA: Another very important part of this Budget that I would like to touch on is the community employment program. As I mentioned before, particularly young women but also older women who are perhaps part of the hidden unemployed, are enormously disadvantaged in terms of effective employment. A specific term of reference of the community employment program requires 50 per cent of jobs under the program to be provided for women. That 50 per cent is not required in any one proposal for jobs but in an area, a region or a State. The Government acknowledges very clearly and very publicly its intention to make jobs accessible for women of any age as well as for men of any age. The program is particularly addressed to people who are longer term unemployed. The Government acknowledges the limited benefits of the scheme. It would much prefer that we had a return to something approaching full employment. However, it is also appreciative of the effects of unemployment, particularly over any length of time, on people who are out of the work force. So $300m has been allocated across Australia for the community employment program. I notice that the first allocation of money has gone through to South Australia in the last day or so. The program is particularly addressed to providing people with experience of work and the possibility that at some time in the future they will have access to more permanent employment. I suspect that the program creates some degree of optimism for these people.

The education policy specifically addresses itself to requirements for women. The policy is concerned with participation and equity and addresses itself to the needs of youngsters at school. It particularly notices that, although the retention rate of girls at secondary schools has improved over the last few years, that retention rate does not flow on into tertiary institutions in anything like the same percentages for young men. So much work is still needed to be done to encourage young women to exercise their options about further education and the Government has addressed itself specifically to that aim.

There has been a return to the original guidelines of the Schools Commission with an emphasis on priority funding on a needs basis. The Tertiary Education Commission specifically addressed itself to the need for priority to be given to women as well as to other minority or disadvantaged groups. This Government unashamedly has policies and programs to try to combat discrimination and provide equal access for women into education facilities at all levels. The Schools Commission national projects program to improve educational outcomes for girls has been more than doubled and will provide a quarter of a million dollars in 1984. There has also been some increase in the allowances for students at the tertiary level. Again, as women tend to be amongst the poorer and disadvantaged people, those things will advantage them.

I am appreciative that I have almost used the time available to me in this debate. I would like to conclude by commenting that as far as I am concerned this Government in the Budget has taken to heart its promises for care and concern in real ways for the security of us all. Our Budget re-affirms that stance. It is in line with other actions by this Government. I particularly refer to the appointment of an ambassador for disarmament.
