It is something that the women of Australia are very heartened by. I also know that men in Australia are heartened by that too, but women's involvement in actions for peace in our world is widely known. They take heart from this Government's initiative. They can see this Government's commitment to women having equal opportunity in jobs, finance, security and a real place in Australia's society. This Budget reinforces those attitudes and legislation with real dollar gains for so many women in Australia. It is a Budget to be proud of. I commend it to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING STATIONS LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1983TELEVISION STATIONS LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 September 1983, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not the practice of the Liberal Party of Australia to oppose Government legislation on principle. It is our practice, as a responsible Opposition, to look at each piece of legislation and, where appropriate, not to oppose legislation which we believe is either proper or is part of the Government's essential program. The Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill and the Television Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill, which we are now considering, are revenue measures. They are part of the Government's revenue program. It is not the intention of the Opposition to oppose these Bills. We believe this is a proper course for a responsible Opposition to take. I will speak only briefly and make a few comments about the Bills and about some of the features which have caused concern in the industry and need to be brought out here.

SPEECH.PARA: Because the amounts of money being collected are considerable these are not merely cost recovery measures. They are not merely attempts to raise from the industry amounts to cover the cost of money spent on behalf of that industry. They are, in fact, revenue measures designed by government to boost its revenues for general purposes. The legislation increases the maximum percentage on gross earnings of both television and broadcasting stations which can be charged for licence fee purposes. The Bills actually propose an increase of one-half or one per cent on the gross earnings of stations. The percentage for television stations will now be 8 per cent instead of the previous figure of 7.5 per cent. For radio stations it will be 5 1/2 per cent instead of the previous figure of 5 per cent. It is worth putting on record that both the industry associations-that is, the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations and the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters-oppose the increases. That should be part of the public debate.

The fees are based on a percentage of gross receipts and not on net profits. This means that, in fact, there may be some disadvantages to the stations where their gross earnings do not reflect their real earnings. It may, in fact, not always be possible for the stations to meet these increased licence charges without suffering some net detriment. We can understand that the industry is concerned about this. The fee structure may also ignore the fact that many commercial radio stations in particular are not operating profitably at this time and the new fee structure may be an imposition upon them. Further, the increase from 5 per cent to 5 1/2 per cent represents a very considerable jump, if one looks at it as a percentage of what the level was previously. Similarly, the jump from 7 1/2 per cent to 8 per cent is fairly considerable. In both cases the increases are well above either the previous or the projected rates of inflation in Australia. The industry is concerned about that.

This is only one of the areas in the communications portfolio where the Government has attempted to gain extra revenue. I simply mention the 25 per cent increase in radio communication licence fees which has been imposed. It is worth recalling the extra $100m tax impost on Telecom Australia which, of course, is a particularly financially successful statutory authority of the Commonwealth. One wonders the extent to which the Government will pursue revenue raising as opposed to cost recovery in its approach to communications generally in Australia. Having said all that, I come back to my first point. This is part of the Government's revenue program. Whatever our reservations might be, and whether we would do things differently as to quantum may be another question, because it is part of the Government's program and because it is not our intention now or ever to oppose all Government legislation as a matter of course , I indicate that the Opposition will not be opposing these measures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill and the Television Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill, essentially for the same reasons as those espoused by Senator Peter Baume on behalf of the Liberal Party of Australia. We have been approached by the same organisations. We have sympathy with those organisations in their view that a government should raise additional revenue in this area by way of legislation rather than by regulation. We raised with the Government the idea that perhaps the legislation should be withdrawn or amended so that the additional revenue would be raised by way of legislation, so that if a government of the day wanted additional revenue out of broadcasting it had to go to the Parliament and say: 'This is another Bill. Give us permission to enact it'. Rather than dealing with the matter by way of regulation, that proposition appealed to us.

SPEECH.PARA: In our inquiries we were shocked to find how many ways in which a government of the day, irrespective of its political persuasion, can raise additional moneys simply by way of regulation. I can recall during the halcyon days when I was a Liberal that Sir Robert Menzies wrote a pamphlet called 'Government by Regulation'. I think that sometimes it is good for those of us who are still in parliament and politics to realise how much executive governments or Cabinets can do by way of regulations, without reference to the Parliament. The power to disallow regulations is one of the precious things that we have in this Senate. Admittedly, the House of Representatives has similar powers but, for some reason , it does not seem to take as keen an interest in the disallowance of regulations as we senators of all persuasions do in the Senate. Several Senate committees deal with the matter. The fact that we do have these mechanisms in the Senate provides the individual with a great protection.

I simply say that the Democrats support these Bills. We express some hesitation about the way in which this money is being realised. I have been approached by the organisations which Senator Baume mentioned. Senator Jessop has taken an extraordinary interest in this matter. He also raised it with me on a personal level and I confided my concern to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Chipp's concern about the raising of revenue by regulation rather than by legislation. I recall that last year, when the Fraser Government was in control of the treasury bench, I raised this matter with my colleague Senator Peter Baume. At that time television licence fees were raised by, in some cases, 3,000 per cent by means of a regulatory measure to which I objected. I took the matter up on behalf of the industry and with the complete co-operation of Senator Peter Baume and the head of the Department of Communications at that time. The Minister for Communications at that time, Mr Neil Brown, recognised that there was an anomaly and that revenue should not be raised by regulation in this manner but ought to be raised as a result of a specific Act of Parliament. I remember that on that occasion the Hon. Neil Brown asked Senator Peter Baume to make that point in his reply in the Senate. Senator Peter Baume said that it was the intention of the then Minister to bring in an Act of Parliament just to put this particular matter into order. I was alarmed when I heard Senator Chipp say earlier that the reason why the Government was not going to do it was that there are other areas where this sort of method of raising revenue is employed.
—Including income tax.

—Exactly. I think it is bad. It is a very serious indictment on Government. It was a serious indictment on the Fraser Government. I would have thought that the so-called progressive Labor Government would have recognised the point that was raised by Senator Chipp in his letter to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications, Senator Button. I would have thought that the Minister would have recognised the anomaly and would have brought in or agreed to bring in an Act of Parliament so that the Senate and the House of Representatives could subject the Government's action in these matters to scrutiny and protect the industries concerned against excessive increases in fees. Incidentally, at the time to which I refer last year, the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills cast doubts on this way of raising revenue. I think it questioned the constitutionality of the whole thing. I believe it could be in breach of the Constitution. I suggest that the Government look at this matter again. If there are other areas where revenue is being raised by regulation in, I suggest, an improper way, that situation ought to be corrected. I am very grateful for Senator Chipp's contribution in this matter.
—There is an argument that by regulation you have greater flexibility.

—Sure. That really brings the whole matter into question. If there is greater flexibility for governments to impose heavier penalties on an industry in any area, we should look at that situation. I remember that some years ago-Senator Peter Baume has reminded me of it-we as a government introduced a limited capacity for government to impose greater penalties on industry. I think that if that sort of attitude were adopted it could be acceptable to the Opposition and to the Australian Democrats. The Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations has approached me, as it has other senators. It has raised a number of points. Firstly, tax imposed under the Television Stations Licence Fees Act is based on gross earnings and not profitability. Consequently, the amount paid by stations increases each year by at least the same rate as market growth. Also, some stations move to new higher plateaus of licence fees according to increases in revenue.
—What does that mean?

—This is a phoney attempt to raise revenue on the basis of gross earnings and not profitability. That point ought to be made. The second point is that the effect of the proposed amendment will be that all licensees with gross earnings in excess of $10m a year will be required to pay a substantially higher fee. This will be caused by a combination of four points: Firstly, a significant increase in the formula of last year; secondly, the growth in revenue; thirdly, the proposed change in formula; and, fourthly, in some cases, because of the 6.7 per cent increase in the ceiling.
—This Government learned that technique from the Lend Lease Corporation.
—That would not surprise me, Senator Chipp.
—Order! Senator Jessop, I think you might assist the Chair at least if you would direct your remarks through me and have your private conversation later.

—I believe you are quite in order in drawing my attention to that , Madam Acting Deputy President. But the third point I want to make is that the burden of this increase will fall on the metropolitan stations, the major commissioners of high cost Australian drama, variety, sport and new programs. The fourth point is that, in the case of the Adelaide market, the variation to the fee structure will impose an additional burden of approximately $80,000 in total this year on the licensees. In Sydney the equivalent increase will approach $1m this year.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point that ought to be considered is that an undertaking was given by the previous Government, when it substantially increased the same fees last year , that the new formula would remain constant for a period of at least three years. This Television Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill sweeps aside that arrangement, which is unfortunate.

Government policy, as enunciated at the National Economic Summit Conference and which has been so proudly broadcast and publicised throughout Australia, was to stabilise charges in an endeavour to encourage employment opportunities. The proposed changes contradict that policy quite emphatically. The Australian Labor Party policy is to seek high levels of Australian content in programs. I am sure that Senator Withers, being a Western Australian, which State in recent times proudly won the America's Cup, would appreciate the importance of Australian content. The ALP policy is to seek high levels of Australian content. Currently, the television industry is expending well over 50 per cent of its revenue on the production of Australian programs. The level of Australian content has never been higher. The imposition of increased fees shows no recognition of the responsible attitude being adopted by the industry in the face of the high risk nature of producing Australian content, a venture which employs Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote this?
—I wrote it myself and I am proud of it. It is obviously pricking Senator Tate's conscience because he is listening to it. I am glad that the honourable senator from Tasmania is doing so.
—Who is that?

—Not many people have heard of him. Speaking of Australian content, it was interesting to note that on 23 August Mr Duffy issued a Press statement relating to this Act. He announced, among other things, that as an offset to licence fee increases the Government would consider proposals to encourage the production of Australian television programs. At a time when Australian content is running at an all-time high level, the Government is placing these impositions on the industry. I am sure that Senator Withers would have viewed the Channel 9 programs Waterloo Station, Kings, Starting and Taurus Rising.
—No.

—He said no; that is quite right because the Australian public rejected those four programs. Channel 9 did not get the ratings. It cost Channel 9 about $10m or less to produce those four Australian programs with which it is now saddled. These programs contained the Australian content that we all believe ought to be promoted but they failed to meet with public approval. So we are now imposing upon television channels in Sydney $1m of extra fees per year which is equal to a one-half per cent rise. That does not sound very much but many businesses in Australia work on far less than that in order to keep afloat in the current recession.
—What about that new movie known as Early Release?

—I am not sure who is making this speech but I think my colleague is out of his seat and I think he is out of order in intruding into and interrupting my speech. Madam Acting Deputy President, I ask you to protect me against this invasion by my colleague.
—Senator Jessop, you have the floor and the Chair protects you.
—What about Early Release instead of Prisoner?

—I was talking about the importance of the Australian content in Australian television and the fact that it employs Australians. I think, at a time when the profitability of the television industry is decreasing, we ought to have regard to that. It is decreasing due to the adverse economic climate and the escalating cost of the Australian content. I think it is inappropriate to impose a significant additional burden which is implicit in this Bill because I think it will result in the industry having to reduce expenditure which, in turn , will adversely affect the service provided to the Australian public. Further, I understand the Government is about to announce decisions regarding the introduction of new technologies and services. Increases in licence fees weaken the industry's ability to absorb this impact. Where appropriate, the industry is anxious to increase its technological capacity, but I believe that the measure we are considering will inhibit the capacity of the industry to do that and maintain also, at the same time, high levels of Australian content. I think the Government ought to re-examine the whole question that we raised earlier. Senator Chipp made mention of it with respect to raising revenue in this way. The Government ought to consider the whole question of introducing legislation to deal with matters that raise revenue in this way rather than by regulation because only in that way can the Parliament of Australia deal with it appropriately and prevent unnecessary impositions being placed on the industries of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to join with Senator Chipp and Senator Jessop in voicing some concern about the way in which these fees and royalties have been added to the costs of broadcasting interests throughout this country. The imposition of a royalty applies not only to television interests. Across the whole spectrum of licence fees a royalty has been imposed. Press release No. 77 of 1983 by the Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Duffy said that in former years fees were levied on a cost recovery basis. But as part of the overall 1983-84 Budget strategy the Government had made a decision to exercise its option under the Radiocommunications Licence Fees Act 1982 and include a royalty component in the fee structure.

There is some real doubt as to whether such an action is constitutional, and whether it should be done by regulation is very doubtful. In my view such an action should be done by statute. It should be brought before the Parliament and Parliament should give permission, as Senator Chipp and Senator Jessop both said . I am not about to move for the disallowance of these regulations. The Government has to raise a lot of money to cover its expenses for this year. Its deficit is huge and we all know that it has to raise money in every possible way it can. In fact, Mr Duffy, referring to these regulations, said in that same Press release:
. . . $21.5 million would be collected in radiocommunications licence fees in 1983-84. The royalty component of this figure was about $4 million.

That is a fair sized impost to make by way of regulation. Senator Chipp said earlier that he found quite a list of these revenue raising regulations. I would be only too pleased to see a list of such regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even income tax rates.

—As Senator Chipp said, even income tax rates can be increased by regulation. I think that is unsatisfactory. It is time this Parliament or maybe a committee of the Senate prepared a list of revenue raising regulations. We should look at the matter and ensure that the Parliament has some control. I do not believe in running the country by regulation. We cannot have a situation in which--
—Sir Robert Menzies said it could be done.

—Sir Robert Menzies may have said it could be done, but why on earth should we allow a situation in which a regulation can be brought in when Parliament is in recess and may not sit for several months?
—Until Parliament meets you cannot unscramble the egg.

—Exactly. If a regulation is imposed during a recess there is no way of forcing the Government to give back any revenue it may collect during that time. It is entirely wrong. It is entirely contrary to our way of operating in this country.
—It is not democratic.

—It is not constitutional and, as Senator Jessop said, it is not democratic. In fact, there are a lot of things going on that are not democratic. Senator Withers said a moment ago that there is a new program in New South Wales for the early release of prisoners. Maybe that is a scheme which a lot of people in this country will watch over the next few months. Two wrongs do not make a right.
—Many wrongs do not make a right.
—As Senator Chipp said, many wrongs do not make a right.
—No, Arthur Calwell said that.

—Maybe it is time we followed what was stated in Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 10 which in part relates to the Radiocommuniations ( Frequency Reservation Certificate Tax) Bill. That Alert Digest states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee draws this clause to the attention of Senators in that such an uncontrolled right to levy taxes by regulation may be considered to be an inappropriate delegation of legislative power.

That was stated by a committee of this Parliament. The members of that Committee are Senator Tate from Tasmania, who was here earlier, Senator Missen, Senator Bolkus, Senator Crowley, Senator Durack, and Senator Haines who is here now.

TALK.START.PARA: —What an outstanding group.
—Well, it is a very good group.
—Its average IQ is at least double figures.
—I am informed that the total intelligence quotient is at least double figures.
—That is the average.
—I am sorry, the average.
—Order! Senator Townley, please bring yourself back to the Bill before the chamber and address your remarks through the Chair. Then I think we would all be satisfied.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I am sure you would agree with me that that group is a very informed group in our Parliament, having people from virtually every State and every walk of life. I think it is time this Parliament paid attention to what they said in that report. I believe that one other report, the seventh report in May 1982 of the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills, also mentions something along those lines. I hope that the Government will pay some attention to what I have said and that the Senate will set up a committee to look at the ways in which revenue is raised by way of regulation. I would be only too pleased to be part of such a committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to a couple of speakers from the Opposition side and I am mystified as to why they paid so much attention to denouncing the practice of increasing revenue or charges by regulation. There seems to be some confusion in the minds of some of the people on the other side regarding the charges which were increased by regulation under the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905 and the charges for broadcasting and television station licence fees which are being increased by the legislation before the Senate. I fail to see the relevance of a good deal of what has been said on the other side to the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill 1983 and the Television Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill 1983, which are actually before us.

SPEECH.PARA: The point has been made, and made correctly, that these charges are levied on gross income and not on profits. I note the point, and I will come back to it in a minute, that some valid criticisms can be made on those grounds. However, there has been a considerable change apparently in Opposition thinking on this matter in the last two years because when charges were substantially increased in 1981 the then Minister for Communications, Mr Sinclair, said correctly:
Licence fees are calculated on the basis of gross earnings of stations . . .
He went on to say:
The area of the licence determines the size of the market and, to a large degree, the gross earnings. It was felt, therefore, that the criterion-
I interpolate that that was the criterion of levying charges in accordance with gross income and indeed at an escalating rate-
has a very real relevance to the extent to which an individual station can be called on to pay a higher fee.

The point he was making there was that there is some correlation, indeed quite a high correlation, between the absolute amount of revenue gained by a station and the degree of profitability. Granted it is not a perfect correlation, but evidently some members of the Opposition have travelled to Damascus since 1981 and have come to realise that if a royalty or rent component is to be included in these charges-

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you holding up Ian Sinclair as an authority?

—No, he was speaking for the government of the day at the time. To the degree to which these charges do levy a royalty or a tax on economic rent, whichever one would like to see, it is arguably an imperfect tax. I think it was Sir Reginald Ansett who said many years ago that a licence to conduct a television station was a licence to print money.
—Lord Thomson of Fleet.

—Lord Thomson of Fleet said that, did he? I think Reginald Ansett might have repeated it. Lord Thomson may have originated it. The point he was making was that if restricted entry into any business is really effective-that is, if it succeeds in keeping out a large number of potential new entrants- inevitably some rent income will accrue to whoever happens to hold the licence. Contrary to Senator Townley's apparent belief, I suggest it is quite proper for at least some of that rent component which accrues to the holder of a licence to be taxed by the State. Whether it is appropriate to do that by way of a licence fee positively correlated to the aggregate income received by the station or in some technically superior way is perhaps another question.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that the Opposition in the Senate is not pursuing the amendment which was moved in the House of Representatives by Mr Lloyd and which essentially criticised the Government for increasing these fees beyond the point of cost recovery. That is in accord with the sentiments which seem to have been expressed by Senator Townley, and that is that there is a royalty component in these charges, as indeed there has been for a considerable time. Senator Townley seems to believe, as the Opposition in the House of Representatives appparently believed and showed in the amendment it moved, that there ought to be no charge of a royalty type on the economic rent which accrues to the holder of a television licence. That is not a view which the Government accepts. We believe it is quite proper, as indeed the present Opposition parties agreed when they were in government, to apply a tax in some form or other to that rent component. However, I note that the Opposition, in spite of those criticisms, is not opposing the Bills. I do not intend to delay their passage any longer.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 September, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a first time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill provides for an amendment to the Barley Research Levy Act 1980 to give effect to decisions taken by the Government when framing the 1983 Budget. The effect of the amendment will be to increase the maximum rate of levy payable under the Act from 20c to 50c per tonne. The rate of levy effective from 1 October 1983 however will be 30c per tonne compared with 20c at present. The levy applies to all barley delivered by a grower to another person, unless that person is storing it on the grower's behalf.

The amendments contained in this Bill are in response to a submission from the Australian Wheatgrowers' Federation and a recognition that continuing increases in the cost of research have eroded the real value of levy collections. In accepting the Australian Wheatgrowers' Federation's submission, the Government has recognised the need to increase productivity in grain production so that Australia remains competitive on world markets. We also need to be able to meet the increasingly exacting quality characteristics required by purchasers of barley. This requires increased research especially in such areas as improved crop varieties and cropping systems and disease control.

The recent drought severely reduced the funds available for research in 1983-84 and it has been necessary to curtail essential work in a number of areas. Reserve funds maintained by the five State Barley Industry Research Committees and the Barley Industry Research Council have been largely exhausted in maintaining ongoing research programs. The Commonwealth matches industry contributions on a dollar for dollar basis and the Bill reflects the importance the Government places on the need for continued research into significant issues facing the graingrowing industries. The new levy will enable present levels of barley research to continue, assist the industry to increase its productivity and maintain Australia's competitiveness on world markets. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not oppose the Barley Research Levy Amendment Bill 1983. Very briefly, the purpose of the Bill is to raise the levy from 20c a tonne to 30c a tonne. I think it should be known that this is at the request of the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation. It will be matched on a dollar for dollar basis by the Commonwealth Government. I think it is important that research into our crops is kept up. It is significant that one of the reasons for the suggested increase was the low tonnage of the 1982-83 crop, brought about by the drought. It has meant that the pool of money which is normally there for research has basically dried up. Therefore, the industry has come to the Government with the suggestion that this increase be made.

SPEECH.PARA: It is ironical that, as I indicated, the pool has dried up as a result of the drought which affected the 1982-83 crop, when one of the researches which is always going on in our great rural industry is into crops which can be more drought resistant. The increase levy will undoubtedly aid that research as well as research into diseases, the minimal use for maximum benefit of fertilisers, and all those things that help make our great rural industries more efficient. I think the public should be aware that this does not benefit only the farmer. Of course, it is of a benefit to him but it obviously flows on through the community as better prices are received for our crops. We have only to look at the recent serious downturn in industries associated with the rural industry brought about as a result of the drought. There was a compounding effect in that farmers were not buying machinery, plant, fences and so forth, thus creating a ripple effect right through to the manufacturing and service industries. I think it would be timely to remind the people of Australia that when rural Australia hurts, all Australia hurts.

In this instance, we have had industry coming to the Government suggesting an increase in the levy to enable further research to be done to help our barley industry with drought resistant strains, disease resistant strains and generally to help the industry to produce a better crop, thus having the effect of a flow- on to the betterment of the whole community. As I said, the Opposition does not oppose this legislation. We wish it a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Barley Research Levy Amendment Bill 1983, despite some initial reservations. As has already been stated by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) in the second reading speech, the Bill provides for an amendment to the Barley Research Levy Act. The effect of the amendment will be to increase from 1 October 1983 the rate of levy to 30c a tonne. This is an increase of 100 per cent since the levy was first introduced in 1980, a period of less than three years.

SPEECH.PARA: This enormous increase is at the request of the affected industry itself, that is, the barley producers by way of their representative group, the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation. Because of this, the Australian Democrats will not oppose the Bill. In our discussions in relation to this Bill with the relevant representative groups-we have contacted not only the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation but also the Barley Industry Research Council and the five State barley industry research committees. The gist of the discussions is basically that the recent drought has severely reduced the funds for barley research in 1983-84. As a result of this reduction in the funds collected by the levy, there would have to have been a curtailment of essential research work in a number of vital areas. It was therefore proposed by the barley producers that the only way to find the ongoing research was by increasing the levy. On the contrary, we believe that if one looks at the commitment of government in Australia to research in the primary industry area one sees that it shares something in common with our support for research right across the board.

In terms of comparable nations, we are excessively poor and there is excessively meagre provision in terms of the way in which governments in Australia support research in our basic industries. One would have hoped that the Government, rather than at this time immediately accepting the submission of the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation for an increase in levy-given the extreme hardship caused to the rural industry by recent droughts and floods-may have been able to look at its total research commitment and, in line with the various statements made in the runup to the recent election, would have sought to start to rectify the inadequacies of the previous Government's funding policies. There could have been an increase in the Government's commitment to basic research in primary production and particularly, because we are discussing this Bill, in barley research.

Consequently, while not wishing to commend the Bill, we assure the Government of our support. In the meantime we hope that the Government will look at its commitment in this and other areas so that in future years we do not necessarily see a never-ending string of Bills providing for an escalating cost of the order that we have seen in the past three years in relation to barley research.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Barley Research Levy Amendment Bill, the purpose of which is to amend the Barley Research Act 1980. The operation of the Bill is to match dollar for dollar the contributions made by the Government and the industry, and at this juncture at the request of the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation to raise the levy from 20c a tonne to 30c a tonne. It must be remembered that 1982-83 was a very bad drought year the effect of which was to reduce the crops severely and, accordingly, the amount of funds available for research in 1983-84. The tonnages over the last few years were: In 1980-81, 2.7 million tonnes; in 1981-82, 3.5 million tonnes; in 1982-83 , 1.8 million tonnes; and in 1983-84 it is estimated to be 4 million tonnes. But the drop from 3.5 million tonnes to 1.8 million tonnes effectively halved the revenue from the levy and, as such, completely depleted the funds that were available for the following year.

SPEECH.PARA: Tasmania, of course, is not a major grain growing State, but barley is the main grain grown in that State. In a normal year, the Tasmanian crop averages about 2 tonnes to the hectare, which is about 50 per cent above the national average. It is expected that this year a sowing of about 13,000 hectares will produce about a 26 kilotonne crop. I am happy to say that a substantial proportion of that crop is used by a highly respected producer of a very famous amber fluid. Besides that, its main purpose is to produce superior bacon and pork. About a quarter of Tasmania is still experiencing drought conditions, so the full capacity of what might have been grown this year will not be achieved. In fact, I had hoped a while ago to be able to declare an interest as a grower; but, unfortunately, I will not be growing any barley this year, so that situation does not arise. It was expected in Tasmania this year that about another 7,500 hectares of barley would be sown to replace the pea crop, a substantial proportion of which was cancelled at a very late stage. But it does not appear that the necessary quota will be available, so that will not be achieved either.

As with any of these other productions, I believe that industry should make contributions, as should the community generally. Barley is very much a world crop. There is a substantial trading of barley. Our export sales, as usual, fix our domestic price very considerably. In other words, our internal wage and costs structures act against our exporters in this commodity, as they do with others. It is not unreasonable that it should be acknowledged that those who achieve the benefits from the system under which we operate should also be expected to make some contribution through the national economy towards funding it.

Research is vitally important. At all times it needs to be considered that what we are trying to achieve is better yields, improved disease resistance, economies of fertiliser and irrigation, higher standard equipment for cultivation, and for planting, harvesting and storing; and of course, barley, besides that, is a very great rotational crop, with many others in the various States. The Barley Industry Research Council meets twice yearly and reviews its projects in a manner that I could recommend to any other similar bodies. Its report mentions the sort of studies that it undertakes. It is desirable that we should look to see what it covers. I should like briefly to run over a few of these.

The development of techniques for screening barley for resistance to scald disease received a grant. It covers studies of the host parasite interaction in the technology of breeding barley for resistance to scald; the development of a standardised test for assessing susceptibility of barley cultivators to barley yellow dwarf virus; a study of the developmental physiology of barley grain from fertilisation to germination; reseach into the stress metabolism of barley. So it goes on, with research into the soils, the nutritions, the fertilisers, the quality, the weeds, plant breeding, agronomy, biometrics, rodents, and all the other things that go with the operation of the barley industry. I believe that the way that the Council does its investigations and the programs that it sets up are first class and are most necessary to the continuing improvement of the barley industry.

The total expenditure in 1981-82 was $531,298. As I have said already, the very short year in production has meant that the volume of money available for research was correspondingly much lower than it had been in the previous year. I think that we should also take into account the fact that the Balderstone Working Group, in 'Agricultural Policy: Issues and options for the 1980s', on page 119, at paragraph 9.30, says:

Overall, the group believes that agricultural research funding should be increased and that increased expenditure should be concentrated on applied research. The benefits producers derive from research justify an increase in their proportionate contribution to research funding. The Commonwealth should also significantly increase its overall funding of agricultural research. The Group considers that research is an appropriate area for providing assistance to raise farmer incomes on the grounds discussed in Chapter 4. That is very important, because it is far better that we should support the concept of providing assistance to increase productivity and increase profit than it is to do this by handouts and in other ways. So this is exactly what assistance with research can do and should do.

In May 1983 the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation also produced what I consider to be a very fine discussion paper called 'Getting the Most from the Research Dollar'. The sections I found most interesting were sections 6 and 7 which covered the questions of who decides the research priorities and who should undertake that research. It is very good to see these matters being dealt with so objectively. On page 10, under the heading 'Accountability and Review', the Federation goes into the matter quite thoroughly. It states:
Every research project which is funded should specify:
(i) why the project is proposed (that is, the problem which the project is seeking to resolve must be defined clearly);
(ii) what is hoped to be achieved;
(iii) how the project will proceed; and
(iv) how long the project will take.
It goes on:
The review process is considered to be of vital importance for a number of reasons:
(i) to make the researchers aware that their professional work will be the subject of the scrutiny of those who fund their work;
(ii) to make researchers aware that they are accountable to those who fund their work;
(iii) to enable those who fund the projects to re-assess the relevance of particular projects prior to completion against the original objectives of the projects and changed research priorities;
(iv) based on (iii), to enable those who fund research to make decisions on whether research projects should continue, be terminated, or be amended prior to completion; and
(v) to facilitate the setting of priorities for subsequent research projects.

I find that a very orderly and satisfying approach. Barley, Australia-wide, is a very important crop. There is still great potential for improvement in the industry. The industry is certainly in good hands at present. I recommend its research and goals. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-It has been generally agreed by all speakers that, firstly, it is appropriate that the industry make a contribution; and, secondly, it is appropriate that the Government make some matching contribution, which just happens to be a matching dollar for dollar contribution. That is also the view of the Government and I do not intend to delay the passage of the Barley Research Levy Amendment Bill 1983 any longer.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without requests or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 August 1983, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Ombudsman Amendment Bill 1983 and the Ombudsman (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1983 make important and quite extensive, but I believe non-controversial, amendments to the Ombudsman Act. They arise out of experience with the operation of that Act since the original Bill was passed by the Parliament in 1976 and as a result of the establishment of the office of Ombudsman and the appointment of Professor Richardson some six years ago. That was an important initiative of the former Government, the Fraser Government. It was part of a considerable package of legislation covering the establishment of new procedures in the administrative review area. We saw the establishment of the Ombudsman and, in 1976, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal , and the passage of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act and the Freedom of Information Act. As a whole, I think, these procedures have had a major impact in widening very extensively the rights of the citizen in his dealings with the bureaucracy. Certainly the passage of the Ombudsman Act and the appointment of the Ombudsman and his experience over these years has been a notable feature of those major reforms. There have been major improvements in the rights of the citizen.

SPEECH.PARA: Appropriately, the role of the Ombudsman and the operation of the Act was review by the Administrative Review Council. The Council made a report in 1980 about the jurisdiction of the Ombudsman. The Administrative Review Council is also part of that initiative to which I have referred and is one of the centrepieces of the whole process of administrative review and reform which, as I have said, was a major policy of the Fraser Government. The Administrative Review Council, as its name implies, is the major advisory body for the Government in regard to this whole area. It has made a number of important reports, many of which have been implemented. As I have said, one of the major purposes of this legislation is to implement the report of the Administrative Review Council on the jurisdiction of the Ombudsman. Substantially, this legislation was introduced by Mr Fife, the relevant Minister in the Fraser Government last year. Some additional amendments have been included by the present Government. So it is a bipartisan matter. Indeed, support for the Ombudsman and the entire system of administrative review has been largely a bipartisan matter, although there have been some very sharp differences of view in respect of some aspects of it, in particular those relating to freedom of information.

The Bills before us, as I said, are not just machinery Bills, although substantially they are certainly non-controversial and deal with what might be described as machinery matters. Nevertheless, some of them are very important indeed. For one thing, the legislation clarifies a matter which has been the subject of quite a deal of dispute although it is not, in my view, one which should have been in doubt because of the very clear policy of the Ombudsman Act. There was doubt as to how far the Ombudsman could investigate the material on which Ministers made their decisions and actions taken to implement such decisions. The legislation makes it quite clear, as was certainly always the intention, that the Ombudsman would have the power to investigate the machinery by which Ministers were advised, even though-and it is one of the principal features and policy of the Ombudsman Act-the Ombudsman cannot investigate the actual decisions of the Minister himself.

Another important matter which has been included in this legislation is a method of resolving disputes which regretfully, although perhaps not surprisingly, arise between the Ombudsman and agencies that he is investigating and even heads of departments. There have been occasions when quite bitter disputes have arisen between the Ombudsman and a head of a department. This legislation provides the machinery for the jurisdiction of the Federal Court of Australia to be invoked in order to resolve such disputes.

One other very important provision in these Bills gives statutory force to the position of the Defence Force Ombudsman. Indeed, a new Deputy Ombudsman position is created for that purpose. Although there has been a Defence Force Ombudsman, he now has statutory rights and status provided in this legislation. There are some exceptions to the role that the Ombudsman will have in regard to the Defence Force which I think take account of the situation of members in the command structure of the Defence Force. He will not be able to investigate matters of discipline. He will also have to desist from investigating a complaint for a period, I think, of up to 30 days to enable the complaint at least to be dealt with in the ordinary way. Then, if the matter is not resolved within the ordinary command structure he may then commence to investigate it. He is also precluded from investigating questions of giving honours or awards to members of the Defence Force. Again, I think that is consistent with the particular role of the members of the Defence Force.

One matter, I think, is left to decide in this legislation. It has been pointed out by my colleague Mr Sinclair in another place. It is certainly a matter in which I had some experience when I was Attorney-General. It concerns provisions contained in Defence Force regulations for application for a redress of grievance to be made to the Governor-General. The procedure, of course, is like that for all other matters which go to the Governor-General-in-Council. Decisions are to be made on the advice of the Minister-in this case, the Minister for Defence. Yet there is undoubtedly an expectation that the Governor- General-in-Council is acting in a quasi-judicial capacity, whereas the reality is that he must act on the advice of the Minister or those close to him, such as his advisers, who are perhaps the very people against whom the redress of grievance procedure is really brought.

Although there has been a well-established procedure for the Governor-General- in-Council to deal with these matters-certainly there is provision for a hearing at which the Attorney-General is present and the Council perhaps receives his advice as well-nevertheless, it is basically a most unsatisfactory procedure. It is not in any way consistent with the development over recent years of administrative review in the very elaborate and sophisticated manner which I have mentioned. I think that is still a matter that needs attention. I do not suggest that it is necessarily the Ombudsman who will provide the solution to it , although that might be one method. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal is obviously another possible candidate for the review of this type of grievance. However, I mention that because in my experience it has given concern to at least one Governor-General and certainly to some Ministers. I was particularly interested to notice that my colleague Mr Sinclair, a former Minister for Defence, saw fit to refer to it in another place. I think it is certainly worth mentioning in this debate.

As I have indicated, the Opposition supports these measures. I believe they will make some very useful, important and beneficial changes to the Ombudsman legislation and will enhance the value and effectiveness of that office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words, likewise in support of this legislation. This is an opportunity to pay some tribute to the work which the Ombudsman, Professor Jack Richardson, has done over the last six years or so. I think Australia has been very well served by ombudsmen both in the State and Federal spheres since the office was instituted in various places. I think it is now operating in all parts of Australia. I believe that Professor Richardson has performed his job very well. I am a former chairman of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. That Committee had the opportunity at various times both in dealing with the reports the Ombudsman made and having him before it to discuss problems which arose in regard to his jurisdiction. I am glad that there has been a very thorough survey of the role of the Ombudsman and that the recommendations of the Administrative Review Council are now being put into effect.

SPEECH.PARA: The working paper which the Council prepared is very elaborate and thorough. A number of things in the Ombudsman Amendment Bill will be helpful to the Ombudsman, not only the matters which were referred to by Senator Durack but also the provisions in the Bill to ensure that there is a minimum of formality and that resources are properly used in the Ombudsman's work. He will also have the opportunity to publish work and information on current investigations where it is desirable to do so. Other provisions will make easy co-operation with other ombudsmen in dealing with matters of mutual interest.

Another matter that Senator Durack also spoke of was the difficulty or doubt which is resolved by this legislation is regard to action which the Ombudsman takes that might be close to a Minister's role in investigations-not of the Minister's action but of the actions which precede or succeed his action. I have always been of the opinion, frankly, that a Minister's actions ought to have been included as one of the matters for investigation and I argued unsuccessfully for this when the original Bill was before the Parliament in 1975 . It is interesting to read in the working paper the reference which is made to the problem in these terms:

The explanatory memorandum on the Commonwealth Ombudsman Bill 1976 stated that the exclusion of the actions of Ministers did not exclude the Ombudsman from investigating a recommendation made to a Minister, or action by a Department to give effect to a Minister's decision. However, at p. 42 of his First Annual Report, the Commonwealth Ombudsman refers to an advising to the effect that recommendations to Ministers and implementation of Ministerial decisions may not be investigated by the Ombudsman.
Paragraph 146 of that working paper went on to say:
It is the Council's view-
That is the Review Council--

that the Ombudsman should have jurisdiction in respect of recommendations to Ministers. If it is considered that there is a likelihood that, on the proper construction of the Act, the Ombudsman would not have this jurisdiction, then the Act should be amended to clarify jurisdiction.

I am glad that that is being done because I think it would greatly inhibit his role if such doubts about his jurisdiction were to continue to operate. The role of the Ombudsman has expanded already in relation to the Freedom of Information Act and in other areas. I trust that the Ombudsman will be used more extensively in the operation of that Act which will be a matter for debate in this chamber later this week.

In passing I refer to the Ombudsman (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1983 which is also before the Senate which brings similar provisions into line relating to complaints concerning the Australian Federal Police Act. I believe it is desirable that we have uniformity. I commend both Bills and wish them a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government expresses its gratitude to Senators Missen and Durack for their complimentary remarks about the Ombudsman Amendment Bill 1983 and the Ombudsman (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1983 and for the support for the Bills on behalf of the Opposition. Professor Richardson has adopted a vigorous and robust approach to his job of keeping governments and public servants who work for them honest and sensitive to public interest considerations. This measure will, among other things, give him further wherewithal to continue that task, not that it is quite as necessary now under the new Government as it was under the old. As a result I express once again my gratitude to the Senate for the obviously speedy passage with which these Bills will now proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY LAW AMENDMENT (LEGAL AID COSTS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 September 1983, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Family Law Amendment (Legal Aid Costs) Bill is to enable the Government either to promulgate regulations or to make grants subject to conditions in the family law area, the purpose of which is to ensure that private legal practitioners acting in legally aided matters under the Family Law Act should be bound by an Australia-wide scale of fees. I think it is necessary, in order to understand that, that one should appreciate the rather complicated arrangements that exist at present for the delivery of legal aid throughout Australia. The significance of this proposal is the fact that a very large proportion of legal aid is given in family law matters. A large proportion of that legal aid is provided by the private legal profession and a large amount of legal aid work done by the legal profession is done in family law matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Broadly, the position is that the previous Government's policy was to dismantle the Australian Legal Aid Office which had been an agency established by the Whitlam Labor Government and to have legal aid delivered by independent statutory bodies established in each State under State legislation with which the Commonwealth would make agreements for substantial funding contributions. The reason for that was to ensure that legal aid would be delivered by independent bodies, that is independent of Government, and administered as close to the clients as possible rather than being delivered by a national government agency substantially administered from Canberra. Unfortunately, that program was not completed. Perhaps the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in his response might indicate what progress is being made with the States of New South Wales and Tasmania and with the Northern Territory in completing that program.

The result, however, is that we now have independent legal aid commissions operating in Western Australia, South Australia, Victoria and Queensland and the old Australian Legal Aid Office still operating in New South Wales, Tasmania and the Northern Territory. In the areas in which the ALAO operates, there has been in place for some time a special legal aid family law scale, whereas each of the States which has its own independent commission has made its own arrangements for scales for legal aid with the private practitioners with which it deals.

The Attorney-General in his second reading speech indicated some considerable discrepancies in payments per reference to private legal practitioners in family law matters in respect of the different States, and the general picture is that the expense of providing legal aid in family law matters in those States where the ALAO operates is considerably less than in the States where independent legal aid commissions operate. Admittedly, the total cost of legal aid has been increasing sharply, particularly the cost of payments to the private legal profession for its contribution to the legal aid program. There are many and various factors to be considered. One reason is that there was something of a lag in the fees being paid to legal practitioners in legal aid matters keeping up with increases in the cost of living generally and in the wages and salaries having to be met by legal practitioners. Certainly in recent years there has been a considerable increase in these scales.

As I have said, one has to have regard to the dominant position of family law on the legal aid scene. Certainly the Government faces a major problem. It is not a new problem; it is simply a growing problem. It arises largely because of the growing demand for legal aid. The Government has been able to hold down the cost of legal aid in those areas where it has direct administration through the Australian Legal Aid Office. In fact, it was the previous Government that imposed this special scale because it was finding that the funds were insufficient to meet the demands of the people eligible for legal aid, and with the general pattern of financial restraint something had to be done. However, I would have hoped that that was, as far as possible, only a temporary solution. In fact this Bill provides that that should be a general and, by the look of things, a somewhat more permanent solution to the problem.

I think this raises some very major matters concerning the long term future of legal aid. The position, as I understand it in the States where there are independent legal aid commissions, is that members of the private legal profession are offered 80 per cent of the normal family law cost scale for legal aid work in family law. I think two points need to be made about that. Firstly, the family law cost scale has been reviewed from time to time by an independent person, namely, Mr Justice Williams, Deputy President of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. As I have said, this scale has been reviewed on several occasions and updated by him. On one occasion other aspects of it were very thoroughly considered by him, and major changes were made as a result of his review. Other reviews have simply tried to keep the quantum of the scale reasonably up to date. I think it is fair to say, however, that that scale has not really been kept completely up to date. I think many members of the legal profession would regard it as out of date and inadequate. As far as legal aid matters are concerned, the States that are presented with the problem to which this Bill addresses itself are paying only 80 per cent of that scale. So even in those States that are said to be raising the problem of cost, the legal profession is by no means greatly advantaged. If anything it is rather severely disadvantaged in legal aid work.

Nevertheless, the Government now seeks to provide an even lower scale in these States by virtue of the powers it seeks to obtain under this measure. As I have said, that is based on a special scale which originally was brought in as a temporary measure by the previous Government and unfortunately has remained although it has been increased and changed to some extent when there have been increases in costs generally under the family law cost scales. Nevertheless that is a particularly light payment to those practitioners. This measure is to apply that scale Australia-wide and to replace the existing arrangements for the payment of costs in family law matters in those States that have the independent commissions.

The Opposition appreciates the difficulty the Government is facing because of the very considerable demands on legal aid generally at present. These demands have been rapidly growing in recent times. That pressure will undoubtedly be with us for the time being at least. I do not think it is fair that this cost should be so severely borne in the long term by the private legal profession. Certainly I took the view very strongly when I was Attorney-General that the private legal profession had an obligation to do legal aid work on reduced scales of costs, that it had a long and noble tradition of doing legal work for those who could not afford to pay the normal costs. The profession has accepted that responsibility, although perhaps with varying degrees of dedication and certainly, I think it would be fair to say, without any great enthusiasm. Nevertheless, the profession has accepted that undertaking.

I am glad that the Attorney-General has indicated in his speech as he has on other occasions that he does see a long term, continuing major role for the private legal profession in the delivery of legal aid. There may be some differences between the present Government and the previous Government or between the present Attorney-General and me in relation to the mix of the private profession and salaried lawyers employed either directly by government or by independent legal aid commissions. Nevertheless, I think there is a fairly broad agreement that both are required and desirable and that they should be long term partners in this very important social policy.

The Opposition is not opposed to this measure. However, I think some serious long term problems have to be addressed. The Attorney-General indicated in his second reading speech that some other and rather positive avenues are being explored. I hope they are explored vigorously and perhaps with some success. However, I do not think very tough cost cutting measures are a solution in the long term because they really will be made at the expense of the private practitioners who are prepared to do this work. Although the Attorney-General has said that he does not believe legal aid should be some form of industry assistance for the profession, it is nevertheless true that large numbers of young practitioners in particular have been able to build up their practices by very substantially relying on legal aid work particularly in family law matters. Although it is all very well for some large, well-established firms with a variety of remunerative work to do legal aid work on a shoe string or at substantially reduced fees, such an arrangement would be very hard on those practitioners, a substantial portion, if not the majority, of whose work is under legal aid. When one considers that there is a growing degree of specialisation in the profession-and there is specialisation in family law matters-it becomes doubly hard if those practitioners are kept down by very low scales such as the one that is proposed to operate Australia-wide under this measure.

I am sure that members of the legal profession will be prepared to shoulder their responsibility and this burden that they will have to carry. But I do not think that what is proposed in the legislation ought to be looked at as a long term solution. I think in principle the policy that has been followed by the independent legal aid commissions of paying 80 per cent of the normal scale is an ideal that one would like to hope would be the long term solution. But, as I have said, bearing in mind the various Budget problems that now exist, the Opposition certainly does not intend to oppose this measure which the Attorney- General presents as a Budget measure. The Opposition only expresses the hope that other ways of providing solutions to this problem will be found in the long term and that this will be only a temporary solution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting this legislation-I think with a little more enthusiasm than the Opposition has done-for two primary reasons. The first is that, of course, we support in principle the extension of the availability of legal aid through the community and limiting the cost of that aid. After all, I think anybody with any sort of compassion at all would agree that the purpose of legal aid is to put the protection of the law within the reach of ordinary people, especially those in the lower socio-economic brackets and the lower income groups. It would be petty minded if anyone stood in the way of that extension.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that too often in the past the legal profession has perhaps been seen as a group of practitioners whose services have been almost entirely restricted to the wealthy sections of the community and, in doing so, that profession has been seen as making access to the protection of the law something relating to income. Of course, that has discriminated against the poor and those who are ignorant of their rights. In the past truth and justice have sometimes seemed to have had very little to do with whether one has had correct treatment at the hands of the law. I am reminded of a comment in Barchester Chronicles in which a reverend gentleman who was approaching with some trepidation a case in which he was involved was told by an erstwhile friend that had he placed the matter in the hands of a good lawyer he would not have heard any more about it. With some indignation and, I think, some justification, he made this retort:

If I am dragged before that tribunal, an innocent man, and am falsely declared to be guilty, because I lack money to bribe a lawyer to speak for me, then the laws of this country deserve but little of that reverence which we are accustomed to pay to them.

I suggest that anybody who puts forward any idea that legal aid in this country is some form of luxury would be holding the legal processes of this country in some less reverence than they should be held in. The extensive availability of legal aid obviously breaks down the nexus between the wealth of the client and the recourse to protection under the law, and is to be welcomed.

Secondly, we support the thrust of the legislation to incorporate the Australian Legal Aid Office's cost scales into family law. These regulations will lower costs and make them uniform throughout Australia. As has already been pointed out by both the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Durack, there is a wide range from State to State of costs for a family law referral ranging from as high as $858 in Western Australia to $429 in Tasmania. Therefore, I am somewhat concerned at comments made in a submission from the Law Council of Australia regarding this legislation. It states:

In presenting this submission to you, the Law Council reaffirms the traditional commitment of Australian lawyers to the assistance of the poorer members of the community and to the right of all to have equality before the law. The Council also recognises the Government's difficulties arising from increasing costs in the legal aid area, particularly in relation to family law matters.
It goes on to state:

It questions, however, whether the Attorney's aim of reducing legal aid costs will be achieved by the measures proposed in the Bill. It also questions whether , in attempting to achieve those aims, the Attorney does not unreasonably seek to have a legal profession bear the financial consequences of social change in Australia and the community at large suffer the effects of his experimentation for a saving which the Attorney has set at $4 million per annum after three years operation of the new scale.

I understand that the Law Council of Australia represents some 20,000 practitioners. On my reckoning that means a sacrifice of in the vicinity of $200 a year per practitioner which, given the average incomes after tax, after deductibility of overheads and various other interesting items that most lawyers can come up with, is not a very great deal indeed compared with the value of the service that they are providing or should be providing to a disadvantaged and underprivileged section of the community. This would seem particulary essential at a time of economic stress since this necessarily places associated stresses on individuals and families which, of course, necessitates additional recourse to legal aid by those people.

In supporting this legislation, however, I make it clear that we do not regard it as being either a solution to the heavy expenses and delays incurred in taking action under the Family Law Act or as a solution to the problem of the availability or cost of legal aid. It is neither, simply because there are too many other problems. To begin with, the amount of work to be done by practitioners in the family law area has been increased by the various conciliation techniques imposed in the Family Law Act 1975. In addition, insufficient judges have been appointed to the family law courts to handle the volume of work effectively and efficiently. For example, I am informed that in New South Wales at the moment it takes something like 22 months from the time of an initial application for a custody hearing to come on. This delay, with the resultant multiplicity of interim applications in regard to property or custody matters, has the effect of greatly increasing costs. Of course, this was acknowledged by Senator Gareth Evans in his second reading speech. I hope that the action that he indicates as being necessary is implemented as soon as possible.

Finally, we share the belief that the whole area of legal aid needs to be looked at. Senator Gareth Evans, again in his second reading speech, indicated that he is, in fact, initiating a general review of legal aid and the role of the Commonwealth in the delivery of that aid. In our view, the review or inquiry should be established so that it is not just a departmental matter but a thorough and on-going review. I wonder whether the Attorney-General has as yet made any decision about the composition of the review committee and whether he has given any thought to including representatives of client organisations, such as the law reform groups and the Family Law Council, or groups such as the Australian Council of Social Service which represent low income groups, single parents and people involved in family law disputes. I certainly hope that Senator Gareth Evans will be able to give the Senate some idea very quickly of who will be on this inquiry and how deeply it will be allowed to penetrate the present quagmire of legal aid in Australia. In the interim, in the interests of the increasing number of Australian families in need of affordable legal aid, the Australian Democrats support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am grateful for the spirit in which the debate has been approached by those who have contributed to it and the recognition of the problems which the Government experiences in this area that has been made by both Senator Durack and Senator Haines. The task confronting governments is, as Senator Haines said, to try to spread the legal aid largesse coming from the Government as widely as possible, which becomes very difficult indeed given the explosion in legal aid costs that has occurred in recent years. What this measure is really all about is an attempt to equalise, as far as possible, the availability of scarce resources in the legal aid area. To the extent that that does involve some lessening of the returns to practitioners in this area it is to be regretted but, unfortunately, it has appeared to the Government, after weighing very seriously all the alternatives, to be the only one realistically available to it.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Haines indicated, and as I said in my second reading speech, we are taking a number of steps to review the delivery of legal aid generally in order to see what economies might be made. We are looking at it not only from the point of view of the cost of legal aid but also in terms of the court procedures , particularly in the family law area, and the way in which costs may be being incurred at the moment by unnecessarily cumbrous procedures. It is against that background that a task force has been established, mainly as an internal departmental affair at this stage, to try to identify where some cost savings and rationalisation might occur. I am giving consideration to expanding the formal membership of that task force to include representatives of the kind that Senator Haines has indicated, although I would see that present exercise as being only a small and quick exercise rather than one that is necessarily directed to the rather more fundamental questions that I suspect a number of people have thought we were on about in this respect. I simply indicate that it will be an ongoing concern of this Government to try to rationalise not only legal aid delivery procedures, fee scales and things of that kind but also the whole question of the way in which legal services are rendered in this country and the way in which the court system contributes to the escalation in costs that we are experiencing.

I have several quick points to make in response to matters that have been raised in the debate. The first is the suggestion by Senator Durack that what we have here is another example of that age-old phenomenon of the temporary measure becoming permanent. It is not quite true as far as the adoption here of the Australian Legal Aid Office fee scale is concerned. Although it may have been originally introduced as a temporary expedient significant changes were made to that structure, as Senator Durack will recall, late last year. Indeed, as part of the present exercise it is proposed that there be significant modifications to the ALAO scale to make it perhaps a rather fairer scale for practitioners, particularly sole practitioners or solicitors who appear as advocates rather than as briefing counsel, than it is at the moment. Those proposed modifications are set out in the second reading speech. As far as the permanence of the scale is concerned I also indicated in the second reading speech that it was proposed by the Government to review the operation of this scale after two years. That will really be the first occasion we will have to review a body of data about the way in which all of this has operated in practice.

The second matter that was raised by Senator Durack as a general point was the burden on the legal profession which he regarded as being imposed by this measure. Certainly, the adoption Australia-wide of the ALAO scale, even with the proposed modifications, will represent something of a financial squeeze. All the evidence is that the cost per case is cheaper in those jurisdictions where the ALAO scale is now operating than in those where the 80 per cent of the Williams scale is the norm. It is a matter of argument as to how deeply that squeeze will bite, to mix metaphors. Practitioners are not manifestly worse off in New South Wales, Tasmania and the Northern Territory-the ALAO States-than they are in those non-ALAO States where the general fee scale, on the face of it, now prevails.

Certainly, it can also be said, as I said in the second reading speech, that overall figures show that someone has been benefiting from the explosion in legal aid expenditure in recent years. It just is the case that the real cumulative increase over the last four years from 1979-80 to 1982-83 has been 64 per cent and is estimated to be over 80 per cent when one includes the current financial year, whereas the number of cases which have been referred to private practitioners and which have been paid for by that very large real increase in expenditure has represented an increase of the order of only 28 per cent. So the gap between the number of cases going out to the private practitioners and the real cost of paying them for the services they render is large and widening.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they comparable cases?

—Yes, to the extent that it is possible to derive comparability from the figures. I have done this in the second reading speech. There does seem to be that sort of gap which does rather indicate that the profession has been deriving perhaps a little more nourishment from legal aid expenditure in recent years than was previously the case. I think that conforms with most people's experience in the legal profession area which is that in times of obviously very difficult economic constraints for the legal profession, in times of real economic depression, there has been clearly a much greater reliance by legal practitioners on legal aid to keep themselves afloat, and perhaps some padding of the bills in respect of individual cases as compared with the way in which they might originally have approached the task. To the extent that there has been a degree of padding, clearly there is a case for slimming down the financial claims a bit.
—One reason for it was the increase in the Williams scales.

—It is certainly the case that there have been some quantum jumps in the fee scales over that period. There is no doubt about that. All I am saying is that this has to be taken into account and weighed in the balance against the claim that great sacrifices have been demanded of the legal profession in recent years. It is clearly not desirable to put too much of a squeeze on the private legal sector in this respect because I readily acknowledge that it is the case that many young practitioners do quite genuinely and properly rely very substantially on legal aid funds, particularly in family law cases, to put them on their feet. But I have to repeat the point that I have made constantly in debate around the country on this issue, and again in the second reading speech-a point that was repeated by Senator Durack in quoting me- that legal aid, whatever else it is, is just not a form of industry assistance for the legal profession. Its social and economic justification is very different from that. Regrettably, in a world of scarce resources and tight budgets, that is not a perspective through which we can approach that degree of expenditure.
