SPEECH.PARA: Finally, Senator Durack asked me what the progress was on negotiations with respect to the establishment of legal aid commissions and a State based model in those jurisdictions, namely, New South Wales, Tasmania and the Northern Territory, where such commissions do not presently exist. It is a fair question because it was one that I constantly asked of him in recent years when I was in Opposition. I have to say that not a great deal of progress has been made in the six months that the Government has been in office, simply because in this area I have regarded the primary task as being to lay the foundations for negotiations by first of all rationalising the fee structure-this measure is a very important one in this respect; trying to untangle and rationalise funding arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States; trying to bring some order and increased resources into the public sector staffing aspects of legal aid delivery; and trying to resolve some of the outstanding questions of principle about the mix between private practitioners and salaried professionals in this area. Also associated with this exercise is the question of the future of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Council and its re-establishment, as is Government policy , as a statutory commission.

All of these considerations are intertwined and at the moment I am looking forward, in the first half of next year, to having all the threads pulled reasonably together and as a result bringing to fruition the negotiations for what everyone accepts is a desirable objective, that is, the creation of legal aid commissions in those jurisdictions where that structure does not presently exist. I repeat that I am grateful to the Senate for the support given to this measure and I am glad to see it enjoying a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate that the Government, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats support this measure, but I wish to ask a couple of short questions of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). In his second reading speech he detailed the cost of average family law referrals in the various States. Admittedly, these costs will vary because of duration and other factors, but it is quite evident that in New South Wales and Tasmania, for example, where the average costs are $469 and $429 respectively, costs are far lower than, for example in Victoria and Western Australia, where the average costs are $834 and $585 respectively.

SPEECH.PARA: As was said during the second reading debate, New South Wales and Tasmania are the two States in which payments are made through the Australian Legal Aid Office. The first question I ask is: Given the fact that payments in those States are substantially lower than in the other States, is there not the additional impost in those States of delays in payments through the ALAO? The second question-I will make it brief-is: Can the Attorney-General tell me the amount of money that is paid internally by ALAO-that is to say, to its legal salaried staff-in respect of family law matters?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, as to the latter question asked by Senator Harradine, I do not have information readily to hand but I will be happy to make it available to the honourable senator in subsequent correspondence when we have had a chance to see what figures are available. As to the first question about whether there is any significant delay factor built into the payments system for the two Australian Legal Aid Office States-New South Wales and Tasmania-and whether this might be one of the considerations making it cheaper on the face of it to deliver legal aid in those States, it would not appear that there is any significant delay factor. I do not have the Tasmanian figures to hand, but for the Sydney ALAO and the payment of bills of private practitioners briefed by that Office, the basic figure is four weeks for payment to be tendered. If there are no particular problems associated with the matter, if a routine, straightforward bill is submitted, and if the request for payment is submitted through regional offices the delay is of the order of six to eight weeks. Again, that time can stretch out in the context of a more complex matter involving more complex costing exercises for the Office. But on the face of it those orders of delay would not seem to be unreasonable. Certainly, I have had no submissions whatsoever since I became a member of the Government suggesting that that was any kind of a serious problem in the jurisdictions in question. I will seek out some sort of answer for the honourable senator as to the latter question.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a third time.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Canberra Mail Exchange: Industrial Dispute-Anna Franke-Royal Australian Air Force: Mercy Flights

PROCTEXT.PARA: Canberra Mail Exchange: Industrial Dispute-Anna Franke-Royal Australian Air Force: Mercy Flights

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., in accordance with sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter that I attempted to raise earlier today but was ruled out of order. It relates to the matter of the mail situation in Canberra as it exists at present. The mail strike has been going on now for quite a while. It started on 15 September 1983 when apparently a certain event took place at the Kingston mail centre. An Australia Post security officer allowed an employee from a nearby service station to enter the mail centre to seek to identify someone who was thought to have passed a bad cheque. I do not think there is any doubt that perhaps that was a foolish action. Certainly, Australia Post has apologised for allowing that to occur. But the employees then went on strike which I suggest was a hasty response. Perhaps that could have been handled somewhat differently in terms of resolving their feelings about this person having been allowed into the mail centre. The strike lasted for a week. The sorters returned, I think, at about 2 p.m. on 22 September. The problem which has arisen since then is that work bans have been enforced in the mail centre on mail coming into Canberra which has not been distributed and on mail going out of Canberra which has not been allowed to go out. This is because the employees of Australia Post, the sorters at the Kingston mail centre, seek to be paid for the time that they were on strike. The end result, of course, is that the people of Canberra are being seriously affected by this situation.

SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon I sought to raise the extent to which a government authority was being inconvenienced. But I suggest that perhaps many sections of government are being affected. I do not really know whether or not they are coping. I am aware of the extent to which individual businessmen are being affected in Canberra because of the number of representations that have been made to my electoral office by people having difficulty paying wages because they have not received cheques over this time. Certainly I have had representations from constituents who have had difficulty in maintaining what would otherwise be regarded as quite normal mail contact with their families in other parts of Australia. It is a great inconvenience. It is costing the people of Canberra a great deal.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about pension cheques?

—I believe that pension cheques have been getting through; special arrangements have been made. There have certainly been complaints from people about pension cheques but the sorters have said that they are allowing social security cheques to get through. I hope that is the case. I know of one couple who depend on superannuation cheques, not government cheques, which they receive fortnightly from Sydney. At this stage they have not received two of those cheques. They have not got through the mail centre. Because of their nature they cannot be identified in a way which makes them as accessible as government social security cheques. I am sure that couple is not the only couple who depends on an income coming in that manner. The effects flow on to many areas. I am sure most honourable senators saw the case in yesterday morning's Canberra Times of a young girl who is dependent on a certain type of medicine. Her father had to go to Sydney to collect it. I am sure that many honourable senators who have seen their airline tickets know how costly it is to travel between Canberra and Sydney at the present time.

SPEECH.PARA: I think this is a case in which both sides have been in the wrong. But the impact on people who have not been a party to this dispute is severe indeed. They are primarily the people of Canberra. I wonder whether the rest of Australia knows that their mail to the national capital is not getting through, that the information they are required to send to Government, the cheques they are required to send to Government and other mail is not being answered because it is not being received. I know of an instance where certain legal documents were sent by a woman to her son in Canberra. They were urgent. They had to be signed and returned. As it happened, she had to make a phone call to him that proved to be difficult but he had not received the documents. He did not know that they had been sent. There does not seem to have been much response to the problem from the other representatives in the Australian Capital Territory.

The Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) has been contacted and, I understand from the reports, has said that it is not his problem, that it is the problem of either the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations ( Mr Willis) or the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy). This attitude of the Minister for Territories and Local Government has certainly caused a lot of disappointment because I think many people in Canberra believed that he was our Minister, that he cared about us and that in a situation like this, in which individual citizens of this community are being affected, they could rely on him , a senior member of the Party who has been around a long time, to intervene and to seek to find a solution, even though in fact he is not the Minister responsible. Unfortunately that does not seem to be the way he sees the matter.

There is a problem with the courts. In recent times, I think for good reason, summonses have been sent out by mail. It is much cheaper and, in the normal course of the mail, it is a fairly reasonable way to do it. Under the regulation it is deemed that a summons is received two days after it is posted unless the court receives evidence to the effect that this is not the case. Normally another couple of days does not really matter, but if summonses are returnable in, say, four weeks from the date on which they were sent out, given the length of time that this dispute has gone on a considerable amount of difficulty could be caused for many people who ought otherwise not to have had that problem. I do not know what the outcome will be, but I hope that the parties will discuss it. I hope they realise that the dispute is between Australia Post and the relevant union, that the people of Canberra have not done anything to bring this on themselves and that the dispute ought to be ended.

I think it was a hasty decision to go on strike in the first place. The Canberra Times has referred to the matter several times. It has referred to the fact that there is undoubtedly fault on both sides and has canvassed the range of mail that can be held up-including job applications, which at a time like this are important, applications for tertiary study, medicines not available in Canberra, wedding invitations, sad letters about deaths in the family, love letters, birthday cards and holiday arrangements. I received a complaint from a motel relating to monies not being received by way of deposit from people who were expecting accommodation here. I received a complaint from a person at the university who had had to cancel a trip overseas because of ill health and some weeks ago now had sent 30 letters advising people of the inability to travel and attend certain pre-arranged functions. On receiving a cable last week, it became apparent that those letters had not got out and that people did not know. The cost of sending cables is quite considerable. These are stories-and there are many others-of individuals who have been greatly inconvenienced by something which, as I said, is not of their own doing. I ask the Ministers concerned to seek meetings so that this can be resolved and so that the people of Canberra and the people of Australia are not continually affected in the way they have been. It has gone on for far too long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to mention briefly in the Senate the plight of one Anna Franke, a resident of Launceston who was recently sentenced to three years gaol after pleading guilty to the manslaughter of her husband Wolfgang Franke. The sentence was backdated to 24 February, the date she was taken into custody and she will be eligible for parole from 24 February 1984. But there are many in the community in Tasmania of the view that it would be the mark of a compassionate society for Anna Franke to be freed before that date. Christmas is often mentioned as an appropriate time when that compassion should be made effective. I understand this to be the view of the group headed by Ms Robyn Friend of Launceston.

SPEECH.PARA: Without traversing all the gruesome details, this is a case where sexual humiliation and sadism were apparently practised by Wolfgang Franke against his wife. It is the case that during such an incident Anna Franke struck the blow which simultaneously killed her husband and thereby released her from the battering and perversion of her tormentor. She killed her husband and society was right to record a conviction for such a blotting out of a human life. It is possibly right that some period of imprisonment should be required of the convicted woman in recognition of the commission of that crime, but I hope that the State Government can feel able to advise the Governor to exercise some power to release Anna Franke early.

Whilst it is true that this is a matter of State concern and falls within the province of State Government response, nevertheless I believe some matters are raised which are of wider concern. There is the question of the attitude of the criminal law to provocation giving rise to a killing, whether provocation cannot be said to lie in a particular incident but rather is sustained over a lengthy period of degrading and brutal mistreatment such that eventually the provoked party retaliates.

The question I wish to raise tonight is that of the different sentencing procedures of the courts in various jurisdictions, and indeed amongst different judges, in respect of similar incidents. Judges are given very few guideposts and almost no legislative guidance from the elected representatives of the people as to what should be an appropriate sentence in relation to situations such as this, about which I believe society only over recent years has become aware. I recall that the Law Reform Commission in its report entitled ' Sentencing of Federal Offenders', I think in 1980, suggested the creation of a national sentencing council comprised of a majority of judicial officers on a part time basis. The council would, amongst other things, suggest guidelines which, whilst not curtailing the humanising element of judicial discretion in sentencing, would nevertheless offer a more precise indication to the judiciary of acceptable parameters within which sentences could fall.

I know that that council was to be concerned with offenders against Federal laws, but I see the recognition there of the problem as relevant to the misgivings about and even outright hostility to the type of sentence which has been awarded in the case of Anna Franke. Whilst I hope in relation to this type of case that some guidance can be given to justices throughout Australia by some appropriate body, this will clearly not be of assistance to Anna Franke over the next few months. I sincerely add my voice to those Tasmanians who wish to see her released from imprisonment before Christmas. This must not be a campaign in which Anna Franke is used for some symbolic purpose. She has been used-or abused , more properly, perhaps-enough. Rather the campaign needs to be part of an overall caring attitude towards this woman. I believe this to be the case, and I hope she derives some comfort from the support of those who do so care.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —About three weeks ago I was in my office in Parliament House and I received a phone call from the Alice Springs Hospital, where the parents of a child who had just been born with a serious medical problem were looking for some relief. Very fortunately, as I happened to look into the situation, I found that the Royal Australian Air Force was available. On this occasion the parents of the baby asked that the Royal Australian Air Force authorities be thanked for the mercy dash they carried out in an aircraft across Australia from Sydney to Alice Springs and then down to Adelaide. On that flight there were a teenage girl and four infant children with serious medical problems. I asked myself then: 'What does the RAAF do for the people of Australia?' We often hear criticisms in the Senate of the RAAF whether for VIP flights, flights across Tasmania, or various other things. The RAAF cops a lot of criticism. Of course, at times we hear of flights bringing refugees into Australia and all the things that the 707s are being used for.

SPEECH.PARA: In this situation I asked the RAAF what types of mercy flights it had carried out recently. Having in mind the thankfulness of the parents of this particular child in Alice Springs, I looked further into the matter. I have a document that I wish to be incorporated in Hansard which indicates that the RAAF in the last few months has flown mercy flights during all hours of the day and particularly, it seems, at night. They have flown to Norfolk Island, Lismore, Honiara, Singapore, Madang, Cocos, Tarawa, Adelaide, Norfolk Island, Alice Springs, Albury, Shoalwater Bay, Townsville, again to Norfolk Island, Port Moresby, Lismore and again to Alice Springs. It is timely, having in mind that it is not too often that the Royal Australian Air Force receives a few words of thanks or praise in this place, to recognise it publicly for the work it does on behalf of those very many people not only in Australia but in other parts of South East Asia to which it brings mercy and undertakes compassionate trips so that seriously ill people can be brought to Australia for medical attention. I have no doubt that we hope that the people listed in the document survived. I take this opportunity to recognise the worth of the RAAF and the things that it does very quietly without praise. I ask that this document be incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three speakers have raised matters on the adjournment tonight. Senator Reid made some pertinent comments about the inconvenience and worse which has been caused to many people by the continuing industrial dispute at the Canberra Mail Exchange. The Government certainly acknowledges the force of Senator Reid's comments in this respect, and the continuing dispute is a matter of concern to us. The position we have taken so far is essentially that of monitoring the dispute in the hope that it could be resolved by ordinary industrial processes. Robust intervention by government at ministerial or any other level is not always the most sensible way of resolving a dispute of this kind, particularly one where there appears on the face of it to be a degree of blame to be attached to both sides. I refer to the initial mishandling of the investigation which promoted the strike and to the arguably overreaction of the union workers to it.

SPEECH.PARA: The process of dispute resolution which has been going on does not, however, give one at this stage a great deal of cause for encouragement. The dispute first went before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on Wednesday, 21 September and consultations between the parties have, I understand , continued since the dispute commenced. The most recent hearing of the matter was this morning by Deputy President Maddern. I am told that he said that it was not within his power to award pay while people were on strike, which was the particular matter before him today. But he concluded that, if it had been within his power, he would not have awarded it in this case. He ordered the parties into compulsory conference this afternoon and we have not heard the result of that. So any possible intervening role the Government might play will still be contingent on the success of the outcome of those negotiations. Obviously we all hope that it can be brought to a sensible solution before too much further time has elapsed.

As to the matter of Anna Franke raised by Sentator Tate, it is the case that these domestic violence cases, and the responses they arouse which do not rarely result in murder cases of the kind in issue here, are very tragic and put a real test on the principles to be applied both in conviction and sentencing by the legal system. There is, of course, nothing that the Federal Government can do about this particular case. It is within the Tasmanian jurisdiction and a matter for the Tasmanian Government to resolve. I certainly did not understand Senator Tate to be suggesting that there was anything that could be done about this case , but I note it as yet another example of the tragedy of domestic violence in this country and hope that it will serve to throw another kind of spotlight on the extent and magnitude of that particular social problem.

The larger question that Senator Tate adverted to was the desirability of getting some uniformity and rationality into sentencing practices around Australia. In this respect, I wholeheartedly endorse his remarks, based as they were on the very substantial report of the Law Reform Commission several years ago. The main recommendation-or the most readily able to be implemented recommendation-of the Law Reform Commission was, as Senator Tate said, the establishment of a federal sentencing council. I have endeavoured since assuming office to get such a council set up, but regrettably I have to report that I have not had much by way of useful co-operation from the States in this respect, with several States being wholly unsympathetic, partly I suspect as a result of the attitudes of their own judiciaries. Even those States which are sympathetic in principle are having budgetary problems, so they tell me, which would inhibit their paying the fares of members to participate effectively in such a council.

Nonetheless, I remain firmly wedded to the belief that the establishment of such a body, even if at the outset only in relation to federal offences, would be wholly desirable. I understand that Professor Richard Harding, who is to take up an appointment early next year as the new Director of the Australian Institute of Criminology, shares that view. I hope as a result that one way or another we can move early next year to proceed with the establishment of some form of sentencing body to begin the task of rationalising what is at present a very considerable muddle so far as sentencing practices are concerned.

Finally, we had Senator Kilgariff bringing us some welcome good news-we do not hear much of it in this place-about the role that is being played by the Royal Australian Air Force in mercy flights all around the country and, indeed, outside the country. I am sure that all honourable senators will agree with Senator Kilgariff that the RAAF's role in this respect is deserving of very high praise indeed. On behalf of the Government, I thank Senator Kilgariff for bringing forward the matter in the way he has tonight.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.22 p.m.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What authority and control has Australia by way of limitation of operation over United States bases in Australia.
(2) How many times have the North West Cape and Pine Gap bases been put on red alert without prior consultation with the Australian Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Control over the operations of the Joint Australia/ United States defence facilities is shared by Australia and the United States in accordance with the provisions of the various agreements and arrangements between the Australian and United States governments that relate to those facilities. In all cases, activities at the facilities are carried out only with the full knowledge and concurrence of appropriate Australian personnel.

(2) No such incidents have occurred since the then Minister for Defence, Mr Barnard, secured the agreement of the United States Secretary of Defence, Dr Schlesinger in January 1974 to the establishment of procedures to ensure that the Australian Government was advised promptly of changes in the alert status of joint Australian/ United States defence facilities in Australia. The only occasion prior to that date on which the alert status of any of the joint defence facilities is known to have been changed without consultation with the Australian Government was in October 1973.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 8 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the purpose of the open employment incentive bonus.
(2) Will it replace any pension or benefit.
(3) How many people will be eligible for the bonus.
(4) What measures will be undertaken to make potential recipients aware of the availability of this bonus.
(5) What will be the estimated take-up rate of this bonus.
(6) What is the estimated full year cost.
(7) Will the bonus be subject to an income and/or asset test.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) To encourage disabled people to enter and remain in open employment ( including self-employment).

(3) All disabled people who have worked in sheltered employment for a minimum period of six months and who subsequently hold full time paid employment ( including self-employment) for a continuous period of not less than 12 months will be eligible to receive the bonus. As an indicator of potential demand, at 30 June 1983, there were 9,342 persons in receipt of sheltered employment allowance, through their work in sheltered employment.
(4) My Department is currently examining special measures to make the bonus more widely known to disabled people.

(5) Provision has been made in 1983-84 for an estimated 36 bonus payments. However, as the bonus has been introduced to encourage disabled people to move to open employment, it is hoped that the take up rate will increase in future years.
(6) This is difficult to determine, but on present indications the cost would be approximately $25,000 in a full year.
